headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the JCPenney Fourth Quarter and Year End 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations. Thank you, Ms. Hays. You may begin.
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the JCPenney Fourth Quarter and Year End 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations. Thank you, Ms. Hays. You may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie and Thank you, all for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's fourth quarter and the year end financial results. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statemen
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie and Thank you, all for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's fourth quarter and the year end financial results. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, and the company's future results of operation could differ materially from historical results or current expectation. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also please note that no portion of this call maybe rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of JCPenney. Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after February 25, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have Mike Ullman, JCPenney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mike Dastugue, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll start the call a little differently this morning. I'll start with just the comment, hand the call over to Michael Dastugue, our recently appointed Chief Financial Officer, who will give you an overvie
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll start the call a little differently this morning. I'll start with just the comment, hand the call over to Michael Dastugue, our recently appointed Chief Financial Officer, who will give you an overview of the fourth quarter and the full year 2010 results. After that, Kristin Hays, our Vice President of Investor Relations, will discuss our 2011 strategic initiatives followed with Michael providing quarterly and full year guidance. I will then join you back through the Q&A portion of the call. 
As you know, I'll ordinarily provide more insight and leave that to Michael and Kristin because I was a passenger on a car accident earlier this week. Fortunately, no one was seriously hurt but I've been left kind of beat up with some aches and bruises. In any case, I'm very glad to be on the call this morning. So outside my excited game of bumper cars this week, I'm happy to report as the results reported this morning demonstrate that 2010 was a very good year for JCPenney as we made significant progress toward the transformation of our company, in the eyes of our customers and working towards our goal of being a retail industry leader. 
Our holiday season was particularly strong. With the positive recession we have seen and initiatives that we've implemented, which really began to take hold of the latter part of the year. Importantly, the business is going well in 2011. 
We were particularly pleased with the performance of our Men's apparel and Women's businesses in the quarter. We also saw strength in our accessories and shoes and handbags businesses and of course, Sephora. Thanks to our sales performance, coupled with managing our gross margins to plan and better SG&A performance in the expense control, we were able to outperform our expectations at the bottom line. By leveraging our strong momentum we created in 2010, in order to move us closer and faster to our goal of being our retail industry leader. 
Over last several years we've infused great style in our assortments, delivered world-class customer service, introduced new and innovative retail technologies that made a JCPenney a retail leader in the digital age. And now, we have a new JCPenney brand logo that symbolizes this transformation. 
Our new logo continues to honor our rich legacy, reflecting the modern retail that we become. The logo will make its debut during our Spring Fashion launch on the Academy Awards this Sunday evening. 
So with that, I'll now turn the call over to Michael Dastugue.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. I will first cover the highlights of our very solid fourth quarter and full year performance, and then we'll move on to 2011. As Mike mentioned, our financial results reflect the progress we made in 2010 and the conti
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. I will first cover the highlights of our very solid fourth quarter and full year performance, and then we'll move on to 2011. As Mike mentioned, our financial results reflect the progress we made in 2010 and the continued work we are doing to transform the JCPenney brand in the minds of our customers and position JCPenney as the growth leader in the industry. 
This morning, we reported strong results for the fourth quarter. The company's comp store sales grew 4.5%, an increase for the fourth consecutive quarter and ahead of our expectations. Earnings from continuing operations for the fourth quarter were $1.09 per share, an impressive 30% growth over last year, and after the $0.08 of one-time charges in this year's number that we announced a few weeks ago. 
Our fourth quarter performance can be attributed to three factors. First, the company's growth initiatives growth topline sales. Second, we managed gross margins well and third, the team exhibited disciplined expense control. 
Total sales for the quarter grew 2.8% to $5.7 billion. As a percent of sales, gross margin was in line with our expectations and decreased approximately 60 basis points to 37.6% of sales. We are pleased with this result as we were up against the company's historic peak margins achieved in the fourth quarter of last year. 
SG&A for the quarter was better than we expected, at $1.46 billion or 25.7% sales. Lower SG&A was primarily driven by expense controls with salary and related benefits and marketing expenses coming in better than planned. Our tax rate was also lower at 35% due to a true up of our state tax reserves of the close of the year as various issues were resolved in favor of the company. 
Moving on to the full year performance. In 2010, comp store sales increased 2.5% in line with our guidance for an increase of low-single digits for the year. Total sales increased 1.2% for the year. Catalog sales added $454 million to our revenues in 2010. Going forward, we anticipate that the increasing contribution from our growth initiatives and sales from jcp.com will not only replace this revenue overtime but also significantly contribute to our topline growth. 
For the full year, the company's gross margin dollars increased $50 million over last year. As a percent of sales, gross margins decreased just 20 basis points to 39.2% when compared to last year's historic peak of 39.4%. 
SG&A was also well-controlled at approximately 30.1% of sales pick. This is about $32 million below a year ago and 60 basis points lower as a percent of sales. In 2010, we generated $158 million in free cash flow and continue to have a very strong balance sheet with flexibility to support the key components of our growth initiatives. 
Capital expenditures for the year were $499 million, in line with our plan and included investments in our digital initiatives, as well as two new JCPenney stores, 44 renovations, over 100 store updates and 76 new support inside JCPenney locations. Our year-end inventory levels are in line with expected sales trends and position us well as we head into the first half of 2011 with the expansion of Liz Claiborne into additional categories, the rollout of additional support inside JCPenney locations and sufficient levels of inventories to support our growth initiatives, which are non-comparable for the first half of 2011. Specifically, we ended the year with customer-facing inventory up about 5% year-over-year and approximately 6% on a total basis, which includes what we currently call, on the water inventory. 
In summary, JCPenney's 2010 results reflect the team's focus on the execution of our initiatives in order to deliver profitable sales growth while effectively managing gross margin and leveraging our SG&A. 
With that, I'll now turn it over to Kristin to cover the company's key area of focus for 2011. I'll then come back in a moment to provide our financial outlook for 2011 before turning the call over for questions. Kristin?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. We are getting off to a fast start in 2011 as our teams continue to work hard to deliver profitable sales growth by focusing on four key areas. First, we will continue to deliver great style at compelling prices, heightening our styl
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. We are getting off to a fast start in 2011 as our teams continue to work hard to deliver profitable sales growth by focusing on four key areas. 
First, we will continue to deliver great style at compelling prices, heightening our style authority. We are doing this through offering a balance of the best private, exclusive and national brands. For example, we are expanding Liz Claiborne across a range of category and home, petite women sizes, and introducing activewear, dresses and swimwear this year. 
We are also expanding MNG by Mango and Call it Spring by the ALDO Group to an additional 500 doors. We're continuing to rollout support inside JCPenney and center core with 76 new locations opening this year. Finally, our new modern bride collection, which is a partnership with Cond√© Nast, got off to a great start for Valentine's Day. It is in bridal boutiques in 1,068 stores and on jcp.com. 
These attractions are exclusive to JCPenney and bring new customers to our stores and to jcp.com. We recognize that we have an opportunity to improve our sales productivity per net square foot primarily in the center core of our store. 
Our ability to deliver unparalleled value through offering stylish and quality merchandise at great prices sets us apart from our competitors and we fully intend to capitalize on this strength. 
Our second major area of focus is continuing to deliver a differentiated and industry-leading customer experience, delivering an interaction not just the transaction. We are giving our associates the tools to build loyalty through individualized memorable interactions with our customers. 
The value of the superior customer service is not new to us. We've been successfully focused on it for years with our customer first training and our customer satisfaction scores have been steadily on the rise. In January, we remained the top department store for the third year running in the annual NRS American Express Customer Choice Survey. We could not deliver on this important point of differentiation without highly engaged and talented associates and we appreciate their efforts. 
We also continue to expand our JCP rewards program, which has grown to 26 million members and these customers spend more per year than our average customer and shop with us more frequently. In the third area, we are focused on offering personalized, impactful digital experiences that allow us to connect with our customers in a different and more direct way. 
This starts with continuing to dramatically improve the shopping experience on jcp.com, which we've been doing by introducing guided navigation, launching a new mobile site, connecting with our customers through social media, bringing in digital coupons and other new features in addition to the rollout of Find More in our stores. 
Taken together with the changes we are making to our online merchandise assortment, our objective is to build upon the strong growth we experienced online in 2010 in order to grow jcp.com sales by double digits in 2011. 
Fourth, and very importantly, across our organization we are focused on continuing to optimize our resources and reduce expenses where appropriate. For example, we are continuing to optimize our marketing expense in order to get a better return on our spend with a new more localized approach and enhanced digital marketing. We will continue to develop our expense-minded culture and maintain rigorous cost disciplines including across our home office. We are driving efficiencies through our second-generation markdown and size optimization tools as well as the pulling RF ID to allow us to better control our inventory and turn it more effectively. 
We are also instituting new pricing tools to increase sales, profits and the customer's perception of value, enabling us to increase our AUR. And we will further capitalize on our jTime's store staffing tool to control salary dollars and continue to manage our SG&A expense. These initiatives come on top of the significant steps we announced last month to complete the wind down of catalog and streamline certain areas of the business. 
As we proceed these expense savings, we are also taking a number of important steps to mitigate the impact of input cost increases. We are leveraging supplier relationships that we've built over the years, which enable us to place orders for goods earlier than most other retailers. 
We are also capitalizing on our vertically integrated product team to optimize the product cycle through product engineering, strategic and alternative raw material acquisitions, advanced production planning and taking even greater control over the supply chain, especially overseas, where we have leverage that others don't, in order to reduce our shipping costs. 
At the same time, we've been testing price elasticity city for the past year to identify where we can opportunistically increase prices. In the better and best pricing tiers, we've had success in modestly increasing ticket in certain areas. 
And finally, we focus on increasing private and inclusive brands in our merchandise mix as we have the greatest control over cost and they allow us to best address our customers' needs for affordability. Even with lower price points in national brands, our private brand margin is a typically 300 to 500 basis points higher than our national brand. 
In short, these four key areas of focus are designed to deliver profitable sales growth, maintain margins while controlling our expenses and in the end, should enable JCPenney to return value to our shareholders. 
Now I will turn the call back over to Michael to go over the company's financial outlook for 2011.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kristin. As we look to 2011, the consumer environment remains uncertain and budgets for the moderate customer we serve remain tight. As a result, we are continuing to plan our business conservatively. Specifically, our outlook for 2011 is as follo
componenttext:
Thanks, Kristin. As we look to 2011, the consumer environment remains uncertain and budgets for the moderate customer we serve remain tight. As a result, we are continuing to plan our business conservatively. Specifically, our outlook for 2011 is as follows. 
We are planning our same-store sales to increase low- to mid- single digits for the year. Similar with what we experienced in 2010, we expect total sales to increase approximately 300 basis points less than our comparable store sales. Again, I would like to remind you that this is due to the elimination of our Catalog and the Outlet business and this is a temporary impact. 
The gross margin rate is expected to be about flat year-over-year. As Kristin mentioned, we are managing pricing pressures in 2011 by adjusting our product mix, leveraging our sourcing capabilities and where appropriate, increasing prices. We believe we have the strategies in place to successfully navigate this play inflationary environment, which is a testament to our strength in sourcing goods and flexibility we have with our private brands. 
We will continue to aggressively manage SG&A in 2011 with expectations that will remain flat as a percent of sales year-over-year. Taking these parameters together, the company expects 2011 earnings to increase by about 45% to be in the range of $2 to $2.10 per share. This does not take into account the impact of our newly approved $900 million share repurchase program that we announced today. 
As noted in the earnings release we intend to repurchase common stock through an open-market program beginning in March. We will update our annual guidance when we report first quarter results in May as we will have better visibility to the impact of our share repurchase program on our earnings target. 
Finally, let me add two more quick notes on 2011. Our capital expenditures are planned at $650 million for the year, which includes investments in important planning and allocation such as size and markdown optimization, our digital initiatives, the expansion of MNG by Mango and Call it Spring, three new department stores, 70 renovations and the 76 new support inside JCPenney locations. 
Also the 2011 pension expense for our qualified pension plan will be $87 million or $0.22 per share for the year. This is a $134 million reduction from our 2010 expense. Looking at the first quarter specifically, we anticipate 3% to 5% growth in comp store sales. On a monthly basis, February is expected to be towards at the higher end of the range. March is expected to be negative and April is expected to be significantly better mostly due to the Easter holidays shifting into April reporting period of this year. 
As I mentioned overall for 2011, we expect gross margins to be about flat to last year with the first quarter remaining under pressure as we work to improve the company's AUR under our pricing strategies and initiatives such as the markdown optimization. Those initiatives really won't take hold until later in the year. 
In addition, margins in the first quarter will be negatively impacted as we cycle against the profitable tale of our last big book that was still active in the first quarter of 2010. This impact is not expected to continue beyond Q1. 
For the first quarter earnings, we expect to be in the range of $0.18 to $0.23 per share, which includes about $0.05 of some noncomparable items, including the renewal of our revolving credit facility which matures next year, charges related to the exit of Catalog and Outlet business that we announced earlier and modest expenses related to our new growth initiatives of the foundry, Gifting Grace and Clad. 
In summary, we are excited about the potential for additional growth in 2011. We expect the first quarter will be the smallest of the year and our earnings growth will accelerate after the first quarter as our initiatives take hold. 
Now we will open the call for questions.

componenttext: Well, Penney really never had a compelling cosmetics and fragrance offer. Obviously, as we move to over 300 stores to support this year that's the biggest productivity aid to the center core. We are also very committed to the Handbag business, the Shoe business and the Apparel business. And we believe we have the opportunity to improve our conversion from many customers who buy sportswear unless they are buying accessories with the sportswear. So we've organized our merchant group in the way we're focusing our space and sales promotion activity we'll continue to focus on we perceive to be a good upside opportunity productivity.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it was clearly a number of things. I'm in the salary and related benefits and marketing, those are the biggest expenditures we had. And they came in not only better than what we would've expected but better than last year but it was also acr
componenttext: Well, I think it was clearly a number of things. I'm in the salary and related benefits and marketing, those are the biggest expenditures we had. And they came in not only better than what we would've expected but better than last year but it was also across a number of categories. I would say across the board, we did a great job in the organization managing our expenses. Our store managers made the right decisions throughout the quarter. Weather issues as an example in January, they made the right decisions because you're not going to have customer traffic. You don't have to staff at the same level. So those types of things that I think we did a very good job of the during the fourth quarter.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011

componenttext: Kristin, do you want to answer it?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. sure. We have, of the Women's division are testing it in the spring of last year and we rolled out some testing companywide over the summer. Overall, what we were seeing in a good price point when you raise prices, let's just say $1 on an opening pri
componenttext: Yes. sure. We have, of the Women's division are testing it in the spring of last year and we rolled out some testing companywide over the summer. Overall, what we were seeing in a good price point when you raise prices, let's just say $1 on an opening price point, units did go down, which is what we would expect. And that's why it's important to us because you are not only the pricing issues but also customer behavior around that. What we did learn also is in a better and best price points that really raised the price, let's say $1. We filled enough units to cover what we lost in the good price point and at better margins. So the behavior that we learned of the customer around that was that we can actually raise prices in certain categories on better invest items to make up for the loss of demand when you raised it and the opening price point. And what we are doing with those of learnings going forward in 2011 is that around the important key promotional times of Mother's Day and Father's Day and back-to-school, we understand that we can offer the opening price point of a $3.99 towel or $7.99 t-shirt and offer it during a promotional times, very important to have that compelling value to the customer. And you take the price back up during those non-promotional and appointment shopping times and continue to sell enough the better invest price points to make up for the change in demand at the higher price.

componenttext: All I can say, Chuck, is that we feel good about having a strong private brand presence in our flex sourcing is the advantages that our national brand manufacturers, they take the prices even more aggressively, the gap between that pricing and our private brand pricing obviously increase it, it makes our proposition more compelling as well as those retailers that are below us in price point, is a cost increase for them and the retail has obviously a higher percentage. So we think we have an opportunity in the commodity items in our price point. We think we have a compelling opportunity to customer a choice between the best of national brands and our best private brands.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We feel very good about the way we placed in spring and we're getting in front of it and working directly with our brand manufacturers, suppliers. We feel we've got some advantage to some competitors. I think it's also important to recognize that we have
componenttext: We feel very good about the way we placed in spring and we're getting in front of it and working directly with our brand manufacturers, suppliers. We feel we've got some advantage to some competitors. I think it's also important to recognize that we have another initiatives that are accretive to margin. Our new size optimization, our new market  optimization and our pricing tools are designed to help offset the cost in headwinds. And we also believe we are now up against the same strategies as a year ago much of our lack of visibility of the margin number in 2010 was a noncomparable clearance initiation, which we manage to better and sometime and depends on others. We're also looking very strong at some of the promotional double couponing. We think our rewards program is the best way for us to speak to our best customers and we believe there are some opportunities there to deliver terrific value but without giving the customer more than what they are really expecting.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So Mike, any sense of magnitude, how we should be thinking about the first half versus the back half in terms of margin opportunity and then perhaps flip that with sort of any thoughts on the inflationary what are you seeing in the near-term versus the ba
componenttext: So Mike, any sense of magnitude, how we should be thinking about the first half versus the back half in terms of margin opportunity and then perhaps flip that with sort of any thoughts on the inflationary what are you seeing in the near-term versus the back half?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I won't get very, very specific except to say that we feel in the first half, we got a bit of cost because we got ahead of it. The back half where we see product more cost an issue we'd be able to get more impact out of productivity tools. So I think flat
componenttext: I won't get very, very specific except to say that we feel in the first half, we got a bit of cost because we got ahead of it. The back half where we see product more cost an issue we'd be able to get more impact out of productivity tools. So I think flat for the year is the rate in the guidance and it will be coming from different directions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then my second question on the expenses, Kristin, you mentioned the fourth initiative some major plans of attack and you're sort of tackling a lot of areas whether it's marketing, turns, salary dollars. Can you give us some sense of some quantificatio
componenttext: And then my second question on the expenses, Kristin, you mentioned the fourth initiative some major plans of attack and you're sort of tackling a lot of areas whether it's marketing, turns, salary dollars. Can you give us some sense of some quantification, what sort of the targets you got there as you identify some expense opportunities?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. I think it's not like we're going to provide financial target today, obviously, Adrianne otherwise we would've outlined of those already for you. But understand that we are focused on these four key areas and across the organization both in stores
componenttext: Right. I think it's not like we're going to provide financial target today, obviously, Adrianne otherwise we would've outlined of those already for you. But understand that we are focused on these four key areas and across the organization both in stores and home office, we recognize there's opportunities not just to cut expenses. We've said for last three or four years, we don't believe in just percentage cuts across the board. It's really more about optimizing resources that you do have and leveraging the return on your investment and improving that return. So the center core productivity as Mike said with modern shoes and handbags and support inside JCPenney, improving cost shopping, the cost in those areas, those are the things that we're focused on and we have been focused on. Marketing is looking at local market optimization, understanding what works in the market, preprint versus television and the right mix of those to get a better return on your invested dollar from a marketing perspective. So it's really more about looking at things across the board group by group as opposed to some sort of expense cut across the organization.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So if I understand correctly, at marketing as a percentage of sales or spend, is not going to change, it's just a reallocation of those dollars?
componenttext: So if I understand correctly, at marketing as a percentage of sales or spend, is not going to change, it's just a reallocation of those dollars?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We haven't really provided guidance on marketing spend for the year. Just understand that we're going to be, we have been, we started local market optimization and looking at that last year. And marketing expenses were down in the fourth quarter. So under
componenttext: We haven't really provided guidance on marketing spend for the year. Just understand that we're going to be, we have been, we started local market optimization and looking at that last year. And marketing expenses were down in the fourth quarter. So understand that as we go forward in 2011, we know that we can take some of those learnings and deploy those in 2011 but we haven't provided specific guidance around marketing expense.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011

componenttext: There's also some shifts, Adrianne, regarding the catalog because some of those media costs, the catalog reflected marketing expenses. So we're not going out of Print Media business because obviously, we have direct mail and other Find More about the customer, navigate the shopping with us or whatever channel they choose, but there will be some transition on comparable the during the year.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the discontinued business. It looks like it will be weighing on sales growth by 300 basis points. What types of margin was that business running at and will you see a margin benefit from shutting those down this year?
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the discontinued business. It looks like it will be weighing on sales growth by 300 basis points. What types of margin was that business running at and will you see a margin benefit from shutting those down this year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think as you probably heard in some of the comments, I think the impact on the margins are primarily going to be in the first quarter because that probably had the biggest impact from our Big Book as we transitioned out of the Big Book, there was
componenttext: Sure. I think as you probably heard in some of the comments, I think the impact on the margins are primarily going to be in the first quarter because that probably had the biggest impact from our Big Book as we transitioned out of the Big Book, there was a still a fair amount of sales that we reported in first quarter of 2010. So I think as you move out of the first quarter that would be the impact of getting out of catalog will be much less throughout the remainder of the year. In terms of where as Mike said, we're not totally getting out of the Print business but we will not be sending out dedicated catalog books going forward. Additionally, we are transitioning out of our outlets stores over the next couple of years. We announced that here about a month ago. So it will be this a 300 basis point differential throughout the year and that relates to that $454 million of catalog sales that I talked about earlier.

componenttext: And then finally just wanted to ask about Mango, what you are seeing from the test stores? Are you attracting new customer? And what's happening with price points there?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We opened 77 Mango stores in and we have the intention to get a read on various markets and varies customer segments. I had a terrific reaction by those who have non-Mango overseas. So however, international visitors may or may not recognize the brand but
componenttext: We opened 77 Mango stores in and we have the intention to get a read on various markets and varies customer segments. I had a terrific reaction by those who have non-Mango overseas. So however, international visitors may or may not recognize the brand but recognize how sharp the pricing was compared with what they were used to. So we've worked with the Mango organization and we've modified a lot of things in the learnings. And we feel very good that our existing customers as they get well understanding of the brand will respond very well. Interestingly, when they buy the first purchase, they buy up one to four pieces. The second purchase is maybe an additional piece. The third purchase an additional piece. So I think it's going to be a lot of expense for the customers for us. There really is on the private fashion brands in the world. And so Unocode, Forever 21, H and M and Mango, and be able to offer that kind of fashion in a JCPenney store for the modern customer at modern prices I think it's a terrific attraction and I think over time will bring new customers to the store.

componenttext: I think if you look at the fourth quarter, which is obviously the most relevant we have 4.5% so it's right smack at the top of the range. As you probably remember, we messaged last year that our growth initiatives in the second half but if you look at our, there is, competitively, we did extremely well in the season. I think five to six months, we led. So we don't think it is a logic to move from the fourth quarter to the first quarter. The March timeframe is obviously impacted by the Easter shift particularly close relationships that to Mother's Day. But I think it's been mentioned earlier on the call that February is going to be the weakest in terms of the transition. But beyond that, we feel very good about it.

componenttext: As a retail, we continue to look at the store base. The vast majority of our stores are contributing even during the recession from any well and above the way we would have. We're opening two new stores this weekend. On basis, one in Washington and Maryland, and the other one in Brisbane, California and probably store in mall. We have one more store in the full year in Dallas. As we mentioned earlier, we touched over 100 stores year in terms of renovation and we have some of our new growth concepts we'll be opening. I think the commercial real estate market going forward is still fairly uncertain. We have a lot of opportunities in our existing towards increased productivity and we will continue to invest in new attractions and new ways to improve our performance in our existing stores.

componenttext: For the fourth quarter, can you give us a breakdown on the composition on the comp traffic UBT, AUR and sort of how you see that playing into the comp guidance that you've given us this morning for 2011?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. For the year last year, we said our AUR went down and we got a couple other promotional to drive the business as well as our noncomparable clearance strategy had an impact and our promotional strategy. Our units for the year were up about 9.6%. Our
componenttext: Sure. For the year last year, we said our AUR went down and we got a couple other promotional to drive the business as well as our noncomparable clearance strategy had an impact and our promotional strategy. Our units for the year were up about 9.6%. Our transactions were up 7.5%. Our units per transaction were at 1.9%. So aside from a modest decline in AUR, our metrics are pretty strong and pretty much reflected in the comps. As we transition into 2011, we've said we're conscious in working on improve AUR where things as mentioned. We believe that we continue to overperform in the opening price point item because we think that the strong merchandise performance we had in 2010 in Men's, Women's and Kids, particularly in the opening price point, that gives us confidence that we're resonating not only the quality of the merchandise but also the presentation that's impactful and it works very well for us. So I think on the metrics, we feel we got it planned properly. The big unknown, of course, is the appetite for pricing like across all categories, all price points.

componenttext: Yes. We've said over last year. So we've had about a 300 basis points difference in the trend of our top private brands versus our top national brands as much as a 600 or 700 basis points GP differential. So that continues to be the case and we have two brands that are over $1 billion in size in Arizona and a number of other brands that are obviously about $100 million. So we think that the legitimate brands with brand attributes and the customer recognizes and comes to expect and gives us I think a strong traction beyond just saying we have labels. And we do a lot of research and we're actually encouraged by how much of unaided awareness of our of our private brands.

componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, as we rolled out with $87 million for our qualified pension plan for 2011, I think I should also call out the fact that we've lowered our expected rate of return from 8.4% to 7.5%. And we did that along the lines of what we've been talking abou
componenttext: Yes, Mike, as we rolled out with $87 million for our qualified pension plan for 2011, I think I should also call out the fact that we've lowered our expected rate of return from 8.4% to 7.5%. And we did that along the lines of what we've been talking about here for the last couple of years as we've we think about our pension plan. And as you know, we froze that to new entrants about well over four years ago. And over time, we're gradually reducing the amount of equity allocated of the plan and increasing the amount of fixed income and so we thought that made sense. And so I think as we called out impact of about, it's impacting our earnings this year about $0.22. So I don't know if that answers your question assets a little over about $5.25 billion at the end of 2010.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's two aspects to that. First of all, obviously by definition, catalog inventories invisible to the customer is how we ship to each of the stores. To the extent that we start to align our inventory for online with the store inventory. It's much more
componenttext: There's two aspects to that. First of all, obviously by definition, catalog inventories invisible to the customer is how we ship to each of the stores. To the extent that we start to align our inventory for online with the store inventory. It's much more effective to clear the inventory, we have extra inventory, to sort of the same items, much easier to clear in the store much more profitably in our existing stores. So aside from product churn some of the very big-ticket items that are not in our store inventory like say, baby cribs and real goods and somewhat. We feel much more confident about getting higher GP by with our existing store footprint. And I will say that with our  clearance strategy gives us some confidence that by having clearance on the floor everyday, the customer really enjoys that rather than these five or six big events a year that also supports doing clear goods of that comp space on the same basis.

componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the JCPenney Fourth Quarter and Year End 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations. Thank you. Ms. Hays, you may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's fourth quarter and year end financial results. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's fourth quarter and year end financial results. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, and the company's future results of operation could differ materially from historical results or current expectation. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also, please note that no portion of this call maybe rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of JCPenney. Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after February 25, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have Mike Ullman, JCPenney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Michael Dastugue, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Now, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'm going to start the call a little differently this morning. I'll start with just some opening comments, hand the call over to Michael Dastugue, our recently appointed Chief Financial Officer, who will g
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'm going to start the call a little differently this morning. I'll start with just some opening comments, hand the call over to Michael Dastugue, our recently appointed Chief Financial Officer, who will give you an overview of the fourth quarter and the full year 2010 results. After that, Kristin Hays, our Vice President of Investor Relations, will discuss our 2011 strategic initiatives followed with Michael providing quarterly and full year guidance. I will then join back for the Q&A portion of the call. 
As you know, I would ordinarily provide more insight and we'll leave that to Michael and Kristin today because I was a passenger on a car accident earlier this week. Fortunately, no one was seriously hurt but I've been left kind of beat up with some aches and bruises. In any case, I'm very glad to be with you on the call this morning. So outside my exciting game of bumper cars this week, I'm happy to report as the results reported this morning demonstrate that 2010 was a very good year for JCPenney, as we made significant progress toward the transformation of our company in the eyes of our customers and working towards our goal of being a retail industry leader. 
Our holiday season was particularly strong reflecting the positive reception we have seen in the merchandising initiatives that we've implemented, which really began to take hold the latter part of the year. Importantly, they position us well going in 2011. 
We were particularly pleased with the performance of our Men's Apparel and Women's businesses in the quarter. We also saw strength in our Accessories and Shoes and Handbags businesses and of course, Sephora. Thanks to our sales performance, coupled with managing our gross margins to plan and better SG&A performance and expense control, we were able to outperform our expectations at the bottom line. We're leveraging on the strong momentum we created in 2010, in order to move us closer and faster to our goal of being a retail industry leader. 
Over the last several years we've infused great style in our assortments, delivered world-class customer service, introduced new and innovative retail technologies that made JCPenney a retail leader in the digital age. And now, we have a new JCPenney brand logo that symbolizes this transformation.  Our new logo continues to honor our rich legacy, while reflecting the modern retailer we've become. The logo will make its debut during our spring fashion ad launch and the Academy Awards this Sunday evening. 
So with that, I'll now turn the call over to Michael Dastugue.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. I will first cover the highlights of our very solid fourth quarter and full year performance, and then we'll move on to 2011. As Mike mentioned, our financial results reflect the progress we made in 2010 and the conti
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. I will first cover the highlights of our very solid fourth quarter and full year performance, and then we'll move on to 2011. As Mike mentioned, our financial results reflect the progress we made in 2010 and the continued work we are doing to transform the JCPenney brand in the minds of our customers and position JCPenney as a growth leader in the industry. 
This morning, we reported strong results for the fourth quarter. The company's comp store sales grew 4.5%, an increase for the fourth consecutive quarter and ahead of our expectations. Earnings from continuing operations for the fourth quarter were $1.09 per share, an impressive 30% growth over last year, and after the $0.08 of one-time charges in this year's number that we announced a few weeks ago. 
Our fourth quarter performance can be attributed to three factors. First, the company's growth initiatives grow top line sales. Second, we managed gross margins well and third, the team exhibited disciplined expense control. 
Total sales for the quarter grew 2.8% to $5.7 billion. As a percent of sales, gross margin was in line with our expectations and decreased approximately 60 basis points to 37.6% of sales. We are pleased with this result as we were up against the company's historic peak margins achieved in the fourth quarter of last year. 
SG&A for the quarter was better than we expected, at $1.46 billion or 25.7% of sales. Lower SG&A was primarily driven by expense controls with salary and related benefits and marketing expenses coming in better than planned. Our tax rate was also lower at 35% due to a true up of our state tax reserves at the close of the year as various issues were resolved in favor of the company. 
Moving on to the full year performance. In 2010, comp store sales increased 2.5% in line with our guidance for an increase of low-single digits for the year. Total sales increased 1.2% for the year. Catalog sales added $454 million to our revenues in 2010. Going forward, we anticipate that the increasing contribution from our growth initiatives and sales from jcp.com will not only replace this revenue over time but also significantly contribute to our top line growth. 
For the full year, the company's gross margin dollars increased $50 million over last year. As a percent of sales, gross margin decreased just 20 basis points to 39.2% when compared to last year's historic peak of 39.4%. 
SG&A was also well-controlled at approximately 30.1% of sales. This is about $32 million below a year ago and 60 basis points lower as a percent of sales. In 2010, we generated $158 million in free cash flow and continue to have a very strong balance sheet with flexibility to support the key components of our growth initiatives. 
Capital expenditures for the year were $499 million, in line with our plan and included investments in our digital initiatives, as well as two new JCPenney stores, 44 renovations, over 100 store updates and 76 new Sephora inside JCPenney locations. Our year-end inventory levels are in line with expected sales trends and position us well as we head into the first half of 2011 with the expansion of Liz Claiborne into additional categories, the rollout of additional Sephora inside JCPenney locations and sufficient levels of inventory to support our growth initiatives, which are non-comparable for the first half of 2011. Specifically, we ended the year with customer-facing inventory up about 5% year-over-year and approximately 6% on a total basis, which includes what we currently call, on-the-water inventory. 
In summary, JCPenney's 2010 results reflect the team's focus on the execution of our initiatives in order to deliver profitable sales growth, while effectively managing gross margin and leveraging our SG&A. 
With that, I'll now turn it over to Kristin, who will cover the company's key areas of focus for 2011. I'll then come back in a moment to provide our financial outlook for 2011 before turning the call over for questions. Kristin?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. We are getting off to a fast start in 2011 as our teams continue to work hard to deliver profitable sales growth by focusing on four key areas. First, we will continue to deliver great style at compelling prices, heightening our styl
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. We are getting off to a fast start in 2011 as our teams continue to work hard to deliver profitable sales growth by focusing on four key areas. 
First, we will continue to deliver great style at compelling prices, heightening our style authority. We're doing this through offering a balance of the best private, exclusive and national brands. For example, we are expanding Liz Claiborne across a range of categories in home, petites in women sizes, and introducing activewear, dresses and swimwear this year. 
We are also expanding MNG by Mango and Call it Spring by The ALDO Group to an additional 500 doors. We're continuing to rollout Sephora inside JCPenney and center core with 76 new locations opening this year. Finally, our new Modern Bride collection, which is a partnership with Cond√© Nast, got off to a great start for Valentine's Day. It is in bridal boutiques in 1,068 stores and on jcp.com. 
These attractions are exclusive to JCPenney and bring new customers to our stores and to jcp.com. We recognize that we have an opportunity to improve our sales productivity per net square foot primarily in the center core of our store. 
Our ability to deliver unparalleled value through offering stylish and quality merchandise at great prices sets us apart from our competitors and we fully intend to capitalize on this strength. 
Our second major area of focus is continuing to deliver a differentiated and industry-leading customer experience, delivering an interaction not just the transaction. We're giving our associates the tools to build loyalty through individualized memorable interactions with our customers. 
The value of superior customer service is not new to us. We've been successfully focused on it for years with our CustomerFIRST training and our customer satisfaction scores have been steadily on the rise. In January, we were named the top department store for the third year running in the annual NRF American Express Customer Choice Survey. We could not deliver on this important point of differentiation without highly engaged and talented associates and we appreciate their efforts. 
We also continue to expand our JCP Rewards program, which has grown to 26 million members and these customers spend more per year than our average customer and shop with us more frequently. In the third area, we are focused on offering personalized, impactful digital experiences that allow us to connect with our customers in a different and more direct way. 
This starts with continuing to dramatically improve the shopping experience on jcp.com, which we've been doing by introducing guided navigation, launching a new mobile site, connecting with our customers through social media, bringing in digital coupons and other new features in addition to the rollout of Find More in our stores. 
Taken together, with the changes we are making to our online merchandise assortment, our objective is to build upon the strong growth we experienced online in 2010 in order to grow jcp.com sales by double digits in 2011. 
Fourth and very importantly, across our organization we are focused on continuing to optimize our resources and reduce expenses where appropriate. For example, we are continuing to optimize our marketing expense in order to get a better return on our spend with a new more localized approach and enhanced digital marketing. We will continue to develop our expense-minded culture and maintain rigorous cost disciplines including across our home office. We are driving efficiencies through our second-generation markdown and size optimization tools, as well as deploying RFID to allow us to better control our inventory and turn it more effectively. 
We are also instituting new pricing tools to increase sales, profits and the customer's perception of value, enabling us to increase our AUR.  And we will further capitalize on our jTime's store staffing tool to control salary dollars and continue to manage our SG&A expense. These initiatives come on top of the significant steps we announced last month to complete the wind down of catalog and streamline certain areas of the business. 
As we pursue these expense savings, we are also taking a number of important steps to mitigate the impact of input cost increases. We are leveraging supplier relationships that we've built over the years, which enable us to place orders for goods earlier than most other retailers. 
We are also capitalizing on our vertically integrated product team to optimize the product cycle through product engineering, strategic and alternative raw material acquisitions, advanced production planning and taking even greater control over the supply chain, especially overseas, where we have leverage that others don't, in order to reduce our shipping costs. 
At the same time, we've been testing price elasticity for the past year to identify where we can opportunistically increase prices. In the better and best pricing tiers, we've had success in modestly increasing ticket in certain areas. 
And finally, we focus on increasing private and exclusive brands in our merchandise mix as we have the greatest control over cost and they allow us to best address our customers' needs for affordability. Even with lower price points than national brands, our private brand margin is typically 300 to 500 basis points higher than our national brand. 
In short, these four key areas of focus are designed to deliver profitable sales growth, maintain margins, while controlling our expenses. And in the end, should enable JCPenney to return value to our shareholders. 
Now, I will turn the call back over to Michael to go over the company's financial outlook for 2011.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kristin. As we look to 2011, the consumer environment remains uncertain and budgets for the moderate customer we serve remain tight. As a result, we are continuing to plan our business conservatively. Specifically, our outlook for 2011 is as follo
componenttext:
Thanks, Kristin. As we look to 2011, the consumer environment remains uncertain and budgets for the moderate customer we serve remain tight. As a result, we are continuing to plan our business conservatively. Specifically, our outlook for 2011 is as follows. 
We are planning our same-store sales to increase low- to mid- single digits for the year. Similar with what we experienced in 2010, we expect total sales to increase approximately 300 basis points less than our comparable store sales. Again, I would like to remind you that this is due to the elimination of our Catalog and the Outlet business and this is a temporary impact. 
The gross margin rate is expected to be about flat year-over-year.  As Kristin mentioned, we are managing pricing pressures in 2011 by adjusting our product mix, leveraging our sourcing capabilities and where appropriate, increasing prices. We believe we have the strategies in place to successfully navigate this inflationary environment, which is a testament to our strength in sourcing goods and flexibility we have with our private brands. 
We will continue to aggressively manage SG&A in 2011 with expectations that will remain flat as a percent of sales year-over-year. Taking these parameters together, the company expects 2011 earnings to increase by about 45% to be in the range of $2 to $2.10 per share. This does not take into account the impact of our newly approved $900 million share repurchase program that we announced today. 
As noted in the earnings release, we intend to repurchase common stock through an open-market program beginning in March. We will update our annual guidance when we report first quarter results in May, as we will have better visibility to the impact of our share repurchase program on our earnings target. 
Finally, let me add two more quick notes on 2011. Our capital expenditures are planned at $650 million for the year, which includes investments in important planning and allocation tools such as size and markdown optimization, our digital initiatives, the expansion of MNG by Mango and Call it Spring, three new department stores, 70 renovations and the 76 new Sephora inside JCPenney locations. 
Also the 2011 pension expense for our qualified pension plan will be $87 million or $0.22 per share for the year. This is a $134 million reduction from our 2010 expense. Looking at the first quarter specifically, we anticipate 3% to 5% growth in comp store sales. On a monthly basis, February is expected to be towards the higher end of the range, March is expected to be negative and April is expected to be significantly better mostly due to the Easter holidays shifting into April reporting period this year. 
As I mentioned overall for 2011, we expect gross margins to be about flat to last year, with the first quarter remaining under pressure as we work to improve the company's AUR under our pricing strategies and initiatives such as the markdown optimization. Those initiatives really won't take hold until later in the year. 
In addition, margins in the first quarter will be negatively impacted as we cycle against the profitable tail of our last Big Book that was still active in the first quarter of 2010. This impact is not expected to continue beyond Q1. 
For the first quarter earnings, we expect to be in the range of $0.18 to $0.23 per share, which includes about $0.05 of some non-comparable items, including the renewal of our revolving credit facility which matures next year, charges related to the exit of the Catalog and Outlet business that we announced earlier and modest expenses related to our new growth initiatives of The Foundry, Gifting Grace and CLAD. 
In summary, we are excited about the potential for additional growth in 2011. We expect the first quarter will be the smallest of the year and our earnings growth will accelerate after the first quarter as our initiatives take hold. 
Now, we will open the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: Well, Penney's really never had a compelling cosmetics and fragrance offer. Obviously, as we move to over 300 stores with Sephora this year, that's the biggest productivity aid to the center core. We also are very committed to the Handbag business, the Sh
componenttext: Well, Penney's really never had a compelling cosmetics and fragrance offer. Obviously, as we move to over 300 stores with Sephora this year, that's the biggest productivity aid to the center core. We also are very committed to the Handbag business, the Shoe business and the Apparel business. And we believe we have an opportunity to improve our conversion from the many customers who buy sportswear with us that are not buying their accessories with the sportswear. So we've organized our merchant group in the way we're focusing our space and sales promotion activity, we'll continue to focus on what we perceive to be a good upside opportunity productivity.

componenttext: Well, we have a number of merchandising initiatives that are rolling out, as well as a number of new Sephoras, so there are some cost. The increase, we have to offset but we've been very consistent in improving SG&A as we've gone along versus our plan and we'll be as diligent as ever focusing on it this year as well.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011

componenttext: And in the past, Michael, you guys have given us a little bit of help on what you think from depreciation to real estate, the tax rate, the interest expense. Can you -- just a little bit of handholding on that for 2011?

componenttext: Michael?

I think from a tax rate perspective, you're going to see a back to kind of a historical norm on the tax rate base, if you go back to like the 2008-2009 time frame. And I think -- I'm sorry, is there anything else?

componenttext: Yes, just interest expense and real estate?

componenttext: I think with regard to interest expense, as I mentioned earlier, there will be an impact as it relates to the renewal of our bank line that we expect to be targeting for the first quarter. So there will be somewhat of a non-comparable impact there. And then real estate taxes?

componenttext: Real estate and other. Yes, taxes.
