componenttext: Keep in mind that real estate and other will also reflect the impact of the restructuring charges, which about a month ago we announced that there's probably about $20 million or $0.05 a share that will reflect in real estate and other. It's kind of the non-comparable impact in 2011.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just going back to the fourth quarter, SG&A growth down 3%. Can you just sort of elaborate on exactly how you got there?
componenttext: And then just going back to the fourth quarter, SG&A growth down 3%. Can you just sort of elaborate on exactly how you got there?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it was clearly a number of things. I mean, the salary and related benefits and marketing, those are the biggest expenditures we had. And they came in not only better than what we would've expected but better than last year. But it was also a
componenttext: Well, I think it was clearly a number of things. I mean, the salary and related benefits and marketing, those are the biggest expenditures we had. And they came in not only better than what we would've expected but better than last year. But it was also across a number of categories. I would say across the board, we did a great job in the organization managing our expenses. Our store managers made the right decisions throughout the quarter. There was tough weather issues as an example in January, they made the right decisions because you're not going to have customer traffic. You don't have to staff at the same level. So those types of things that I think we did a very good job of the during the fourth quarter.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the last question, just can you give us a little bit of color on the elasticity testing that you did. Prices are up 5%, what happened to units if prices are up 10%? It's interesting to see you guys have tested it and I'll be curious to see the le
componenttext: And then the last question, just can you give us a little bit of color on the elasticity testing that you did. Prices are up 5%, what happened to units if prices are up 10%? It's interesting to see you guys have tested it and I'll be curious to see the learnings.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Kristin, do you want to mention that?
componenttext: Kristin, do you want to mention that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. sure. We have, Chuck, been testing, I think, the Women's division are testing it in the spring of last year and we rolled out some testing company-wide over the summer. Overall, what we were seeing in a good price point when you raise prices, let's j
componenttext: Yes. sure. We have, Chuck, been testing, I think, the Women's division are testing it in the spring of last year and we rolled out some testing company-wide over the summer. Overall, what we were seeing in a good price point when you raise prices, let's just say $1 on an opening price point, units did go down, which is what we would expect. And that's why it's important to test because you learn not only the pricing issues but also customer behavior around that. What we did learn also is in the better and best price points that when we raised the price, let's say $1. We filled enough units to cover what we lost in the good price point and at better margins. So the behavior that we learned of the customer around that was that we can actually raise prices in certain category on better and best items to make up for the loss of demand when you raised it and the opening price point. And what we're doing with those learnings going forward in 2011 is that around the important key promotional times of Mother's Day and Father's Day and back-to-school, we understand that we can offer the opening price point of a $3.99 towel or $7.99 t-shirt and offer it during that promotional time, when it's very important to have that compelling value to the customer. And then take the price back up during those non-promotional and appointment shopping times, and continue to sell enough at the better and best price points to make up for the change in demand at a higher price.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So in light of that, how are you guys planning like inventory dollars and then the unit part of the dollar?
componenttext: So in light of that, how are you guys planning like inventory dollars and then the unit part of the dollar?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we're going to disclose that level of specificity, Chuck. But certainly, understand that we fully recognize that when you are taking your prices up, especially at the good price point, we recognize that units come down, so we're planning
componenttext: I don't know that we're going to disclose that level of specificity, Chuck. But certainly, understand that we fully recognize that when you are taking your prices up, especially at the good price point, we recognize that units come down, so we're planning that accordingly.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: One thing I'd mention, Chuck, is I think we feel very good about having a strong private brand presence and our direct sourcing gives us an advantage. As our national brand manufacturers may take the prices even more aggressively, the gap between that pri
componenttext: One thing I'd mention, Chuck, is I think we feel very good about having a strong private brand presence and our direct sourcing gives us an advantage. As our national brand manufacturers may take the prices even more aggressively, the gap between that pricing and our private brand pricing obviously increases, it makes our value proposition more compelling. As well as those retailers that are below us in price point, the percent of cost increase for them and their unit retail is obviously a higher percentage. So we think we have an opportunity in the commodity items at our opening price point. We think we have a compelling opportunity to give the customer the choice between the best of national brands and our best private brands.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Adrianne Shapira of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Adrianne Shapira of Goldman Sachs.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a few questions on the margin and perhaps help us share your confidence for flat margins this year. We know you've just seen some contraction in the back half and it sounds like you're looking for pressure in the first quarter as it relates to margin
componenttext: Just a few questions on the margin and perhaps help us share your confidence for flat margins this year. We know you've just seen some contraction in the back half and it sounds like you're looking for pressure in the first quarter as it relates to margins. So kind of help us think about how we get to flat margins for the year especially at the back half, we are looking for some steeper inflationary pressures?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We feel very good about the way we placed spring and by getting out in front of it and working directly with our brand manufacturers, suppliers, we feel we've got some advantage to some of our competitors. I think it's also important to recognize that we
componenttext: We feel very good about the way we placed spring and by getting out in front of it and working directly with our brand manufacturers, suppliers, we feel we've got some advantage to some of our competitors. I think it's also important to recognize that we have other initiatives that are accretive to margin. Our new size optimization, our new markdown optimization and our pricing tools are designed to help offset the costing headwinds. And we also believe that now we're up against the same clearance strategy as a year ago, much of our lack of visibility of the margin number in 2010 was a non-comparable clearance initiation, which we've managed better in some time frames than others. We're also looking very strongly at some of the promotional double couponing. We think our rewards program is the best way for us to speak to our best customers and we believe there's some opportunities there to deliver terrific value but without giving the customer more than maybe they're expecting.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So, Mike, any sense of magnitude, how we should be thinking about the first half versus the back half in terms of margin opportunity and then perhaps flip that with any sort of thoughts on the inflationary, what you're seeing in the near term versus in th
componenttext: So, Mike, any sense of magnitude, how we should be thinking about the first half versus the back half in terms of margin opportunity and then perhaps flip that with any sort of thoughts on the inflationary, what you're seeing in the near term versus in the back half?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't know if we're going to get very, very specific except to say we feel in the first half, we got a bit more cost forgiveness because we got ahead of it. In the back half where we see probably more costing issue, we'd be able to get more impact out o
componenttext: I don't know if we're going to get very, very specific except to say we feel in the first half, we got a bit more cost forgiveness because we got ahead of it. In the back half where we see probably more costing issue, we'd be able to get more impact out of productivity tools. So I think flat for the year is the rate, the guidance and it will be coming from different directions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then my second question on the expenses. Kristin, you mentioned the fourth initiative, some major plans of attack and you're sort of tackling a lot of areas whether it's marketing, turns, salary dollars. Maybe give us a sense of some quantification, w
componenttext: And then my second question on the expenses. Kristin, you mentioned the fourth initiative, some major plans of attack and you're sort of tackling a lot of areas whether it's marketing, turns, salary dollars. Maybe give us a sense of some quantification, what sort of the targets you've  got there as you identify some expense opportunities?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. I think it's not something that we're going to provide financial target today, obviously, Adrianne. Otherwise, we would've outlined those already for you. But understand that we are focused on these four key areas and across the organization both i
componenttext: Right. I think it's not something that we're going to provide financial target today, obviously, Adrianne. Otherwise, we would've outlined those already for you. But understand that we are focused on these four key areas and across the organization both in stores and home office, we recognize there's opportunities not just to cut expenses. As we've said for last three or four years, we don't believe in just percentage cuts across the board. It's really more about optimizing the resources that you do have and leveraging the return on your investment and improving that return. So the center core productivity as Mike said with modern shoes and handbags and Sephora inside JCPenney, improving cross shopping across those areas. Those are things that we're focused on and we have been focused on. Marketing is looking at local market optimization, understanding what works in the market, pre-print versus television and the right mix of those to get a better return on your invested dollar from a marketing perspective. So it's really more about looking at things across the board, group by group as opposed to some sort of expense cut across the organization.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So if I understand correctly at marketing as a percentage of sales, spend is not going to change, it's just a reallocation of those dollars?
componenttext: So if I understand correctly at marketing as a percentage of sales, spend is not going to change, it's just a reallocation of those dollars?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We haven't really provided guidance on marketing spend for the year. Just understand that we're going to be, as we have been, we started local market optimization and looking at that last year. And marketing expenses were down in the fourth quarter. So un
componenttext: We haven't really provided guidance on marketing spend for the year. Just understand that we're going to be, as we have been, we started local market optimization and looking at that last year. And marketing expenses were down in the fourth quarter. So understand that as we go forward into 2011, we know that we can take some of those learnings and deploy those in 2011. But we haven't provided specific guidance around marketing expense.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's also some shifts, Adrianne, regarding the Catalog business because some of those media costs, the catalog were reflected in marketing expenses. So we're not going out of Print Media business because obviously, we have direct mail and other Find Mo
componenttext: There's also some shifts, Adrianne, regarding the Catalog business because some of those media costs, the catalog were reflected in marketing expenses. So we're not going out of Print Media business because obviously, we have direct mail and other Find More documents that help the customer navigate the shopping with us or whatever channel they choose. But there will be some transition, non-comparability during the year.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Lorraine Hutchinson of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Lorraine Hutchinson of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the discontinued business. It looks like it will be weighing on sales growth by about 300 basis points. What types of margin was that business running at and will you see a margin benefit from shutting those down this year?
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the discontinued business. It looks like it will be weighing on sales growth by about 300 basis points. What types of margin was that business running at and will you see a margin benefit from shutting those down this year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think as you probably heard in some of the comments. I think the impact on the margins are primarily going to be in the first quarter because that probably had the biggest impact from our Big Book, as we transitioned out of the Big Book, there was
componenttext: Sure. I think as you probably heard in some of the comments. I think the impact on the margins are primarily going to be in the first quarter because that probably had the biggest impact from our Big Book, as we transitioned out of the Big Book, there was still a fair amount of sales that we reported in first quarter of 2010. So I think as you move out of first quarter, that would be the impact of getting out of the catalog will be much less throughout the remainder of the year. In terms of -- as Mike said, we're not totally getting out of the Print business but we will not keep sending out dedicated catalog books going forward. Additionally, we're transitioning out of our outlets stores over the next couple of years. We announced that here about a month ago. So it will be this 300 basis point differential throughout the year and that relates to that $454 million of catalog sales that I talked about earlier.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the $87 million of pension expense, is that just primary or does that include the supplemental as well?
componenttext: And then the $87 million of pension expense, is that just primary or does that include the supplemental as well?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: That is just the qualified pension plan.
componenttext: That is just the qualified pension plan.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And finally, just wanted to ask about Mango, what you're seeing from the test stores? Are you attracting a new customer? And what's happening with the price points there?
componenttext: And finally, just wanted to ask about Mango, what you're seeing from the test stores? Are you attracting a new customer? And what's happening with the price points there?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's interesting, we opened 77 Mango stores in the fall intentionally to get a read on various markets and various customer segments. I had a terrific reaction by those who have known Mango from overseas. So, a lot of our international visitors immediatel
componenttext: It's interesting, we opened 77 Mango stores in the fall intentionally to get a read on various markets and various customer segments. I had a terrific reaction by those who have known Mango from overseas. So, a lot of our international visitors immediately not only recognize the brand but recognize how sharp the pricing was compared with what they were used to. So we've worked with the Mango organization and we've modified a lot of things in the learnings. And we feel very good that our existing customers as they get more understanding of the brand will respond very well. Interestingly, when they buy the first purchase, they maybe buy 1.4 pieces. The second purchase is maybe additional piece. The third purchase an additional piece. So I think it's going to be a learning experience for the customers, as well as for us. There really only five true fast fashion brands in the world. It's Zara, Uniqlo, Forever 21, H&M and Mango. And to be able to offer that kind of fast fashion in a JCPenney store for the modern customer at modern prices, I think, is a terrific attraction and I think over time will bring a new customer to the store.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: If you take a look at your first quarter comp guidance, it's up 3% to 5%. The high end of that is implying significant acceleration in the two-year comp trend. Is there any change in the promotional calendar 1Q of '11 versus 1Q '10?
componenttext: If you take a look at your first quarter comp guidance, it's up 3% to 5%. The high end of that is implying significant acceleration in the two-year comp trend. Is there any change in the promotional calendar 1Q of '11 versus 1Q '10?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at our performance in the fourth quarter,  which is obviously the most relevant, we are at 4.5%. So it's right smack at the top of the range. As you probably remember, we messaged last year that our growth initiatives really kick in th
componenttext: I think if you look at our performance in the fourth quarter,  which is obviously the most relevant, we are at 4.5%. So it's right smack at the top of the range. As you probably remember, we messaged last year that our growth initiatives really kick in the second half.  And if you look at our performance either in absolute form or competitively, we did extremely well in the fall season. I think five to six months, we led. So we don't think it's a leap of logic to move from the fourth quarter to the first quarter. The March time frame is obviously impacted by the Easter shift and the particularly close relationship of that to Mother's Day. But I think it's been mentioned earlier on the call that February is going to be probably the weakest in terms of the transition. But beyond that, we feel very good about it.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, Mike, maybe share with us your thoughts in your real estate strategy go forward, any plans to further rationalize the store base?
componenttext: And then, Mike, maybe share with us your thoughts in your real estate strategy go forward, any plans to further rationalize the store base?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as I think any other retailer will tell you, we continue to look at the store base. The vast majority of our stores are contributing even during the recession well above any hurdle rate we would have. We're opening two new stores this weekend on a s
componenttext: Well, as I think any other retailer will tell you, we continue to look at the store base. The vast majority of our stores are contributing even during the recession well above any hurdle rate we would have. We're opening two new stores this weekend on a soft opening basis, one in suburban Washington and Maryland, and the other one in Brisbane, California, a former Mervyn's store in the Serramonte Mall. We have one more store in the fall here in Dallas. As mentioned earlier, we touched over 100 stores a year in terms of renovation and we have some of our new growth concepts that will be opening. I think the commercial real estate market going forward is still fairly uncertain. We have a lot of opportunities in our existing stores for increased productivity and we will continue to invest in new attractions and new ways to improve our performance in our existing stores.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the last question on inventory, the spread improved at the end of fourth quarter versus third quarter but we're still seeing inventory outpace sales on a per square foot basis. When should we expect those two metrics to be aligned? Is it at the e
componenttext: And then the last question on inventory, the spread improved at the end of fourth quarter versus third quarter but we're still seeing inventory outpace sales on a per square foot basis. When should we expect those two metrics to be aligned? Is it at the end of the first quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, it's been called out the last three quarters and each time we have proved we sold the stuff we had. So I would say, that is the same response I would have. We obviously think we have the inventory necessary to support our plans and asp
componenttext: Well, first of all, it's been called out the last three quarters and each time we have proved we sold the stuff we had. So I would say, that is the same response I would have. We obviously think we have the inventory necessary to support our plans and aspirations going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And, Mike, if I can just add that if you think about our first quarter in 2010 as we were getting through 2009, we ended pretty light. And I think we called out the fact that our first quarter results in 2010, we felt like we lost some business. So we wan
componenttext: And, Mike, if I can just add that if you think about our first quarter in 2010 as we were getting through 2009, we ended pretty light. And I think we called out the fact that our first quarter results in 2010, we felt like we lost some business. So we wanted to get back in business especially in the Women's Apparel area.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: The first quarter and second quarter, actually.
componenttext: The first quarter and second quarter, actually.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Bob Drbul of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Bob Drbul of Barclays Capital.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: For the fourth quarter, can you give us a breakdown on the composition on the comp traffic, UPT, AUR and sort of how you see that playing into the comp guidance that you've given us this morning for 2011?
componenttext: For the fourth quarter, can you give us a breakdown on the composition on the comp traffic, UPT, AUR and sort of how you see that playing into the comp guidance that you've given us this morning for 2011?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. For the year, last year, we said our AUR went down. We intentionally got more promotional to drive the business, as well as our non-comparable clearance strategy had an impact in our promotional strategy. Our units for the year were up about 9.6%. O
componenttext: Sure. For the year, last year, we said our AUR went down. We intentionally got more promotional to drive the business, as well as our non-comparable clearance strategy had an impact in our promotional strategy. Our units for the year were up about 9.6%. Our transactions were up 7.5%. Our units per transaction were up 1.9%. So aside from a modest decline in AUR, our metrics are pretty strong and pretty much reflected in the comps. As we transition in 2011, we said, we're consciously going to work on improving our AUR for the variety of things that were mentioned. We believe that we continue to overperform in the opening price point items because we think that the strong merchandising performance we had in 2010 in Men's, Women's and Kids, particularly in the opening price points, that gives a lot of confidence that we're resonating not only the quality of the merchandise but also the presentation that's impactful and has work very well for us. So I think on the metrics, we feel we got it planned properly. The big unknown, of course, is the appetite for pricing  across all categories, all price points.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And could you give us a breakdown on how private brands are doing versus national brands on a comp basis and maybe just sort of how the gross margins on those are benefiting?
componenttext: And could you give us a breakdown on how private brands are doing versus national brands on a comp basis and maybe just sort of how the gross margins on those are benefiting?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've said over the last year or so, we've had about 300 basis points difference in the trend of our top private brands versus our top national brands, as much as a 600 or 700 basis point GP  differential. So that continues to be the case and we have
componenttext: Yes. We've said over the last year or so, we've had about 300 basis points difference in the trend of our top private brands versus our top national brands, as much as a 600 or 700 basis point GP  differential. So that continues to be the case and we have two brands that are over $1 billion in size, St. John's Bay in Arizona and a number of other brands that are obviously hundred million of dollars. So we think that the legitimate brands with brand attributes the customer recognizes and comes to expect and gives us a, I think, a strong traction beyond just saying we have labels. And we do a lot of aided and unaided research and we are constantly encouraged by how much unaided awareness there are of our private brands.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Michael Exstein [Cr√©dit Suisse].
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michael Exstein [Cr√©dit Suisse].

componenttext: Can you just give a little bit more detail in terms of some of the expense items, whether changes in any of the accruals were incentive compensation in the quarter? And also, can you talk about the change in guidance in terms of pension from the third quarter guidance, what we're just getting now in terms of impact to the year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start out and maybe Michael can finish off. I think, our incentive comp is modestly below our budget as we had some people made their plans and others didn't, which is also reflected in insurance and benefits that went along with it. But generally, w
componenttext: I'll start out and maybe Michael can finish off. I think, our incentive comp is modestly below our budget as we had some people made their plans and others didn't, which is also reflected in insurance and benefits that went along with it. But generally, we're on plan and, Michael, you want to take up the other pieces?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, as we called out, with $87 million for our qualified pension plan for 2011, I think I should also call out the fact that we've lowered our expected rate of return from 8.4% to 7.5%. And we did that along the lines of what we've been talking
componenttext: Yes, Michael, as we called out, with $87 million for our qualified pension plan for 2011, I think I should also call out the fact that we've lowered our expected rate of return from 8.4% to 7.5%. And we did that along the lines of what we've been talking about here for the last couple of years as we've think about our pension plan and as you know, we froze that to new entrants about well over four years ago. And over time, we're gradually reducing the amount of equity allocated to the plan and increasing the amount of fixed income, and so we thought that made sense. And so I think as we called out, that has an impact of about -- it's impacting our earnings this year about $0.22. So I don't know if that answers your question. Assets are at a little over about $5.25 billion at the end of 2010.

componenttext: And, Mike, can you just talk about the experience on Liz Claiborne? You've changed over a lot of the other Liz names to Liz Claiborne across the store. What's sort of been the total pick up from that change?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It couldn't be a more positive picture, frankly. Not only it has been well ahead of our expectations in the existing categories, which I think numbers something like 30 categories. We're expanding at beyond those categories for spring and beyond. So the b
componenttext: It couldn't be a more positive picture, frankly. Not only it has been well ahead of our expectations in the existing categories, which I think numbers something like 30 categories. We're expanding at beyond those categories for spring and beyond. So the brand has really resonated. We knew it by research ahead of time. It's the number one most recognized brand by our core customer. And I think the fact we've been able to keep the retails very modest and it actually came down a bit with our GP actually going up. The effectiveness of our marketing and the sales associates understanding of the brand and ability to discuss it with the customers has been terrific. So we planned way up for 2011 and continue to feel very strongly about the brand.

componenttextpreview: And then just sort of diving back into this outlet decision. Is part of what's driving that decision to discontinue the outlet, the success you've had with your clearance strategy in store or could you just sort of talk about philosophically why...
componenttext: And then just sort of diving back into this outlet decision. Is part of what's driving that decision to discontinue the outlet, the success you've had with your clearance strategy in store or could you just sort of talk about philosophically why...

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's two aspects to that. First of all, obviously by definition, catalog inventories is invisible to the customer because it's in a warehouse that we ship pieces to the stores. To the extent we start to align our inventory for online with the store inv
componenttext: There's two aspects to that. First of all, obviously by definition, catalog inventories is invisible to the customer because it's in a warehouse that we ship pieces to the stores. To the extent we start to align our inventory for online with the store inventory, it's much more effective to clear the inventory, we have extra inventory, these are the same items. It's much easier to clear in the store, much more profitably in our existing stores. So aside from furniture and some of the very big-ticket items or items that are not in our store inventory like, say, baby cribs and rolled goods and so forth. We feel much more confident about getting higher GP by clearing with our existing store footprint. I will say that our clearance strategy gives us some confidence that by having clearance on the floor everyday, the customer really enjoys that rather than these five or six big events a year. That also supports the idea that we can clear goods out of the dot-com space on the same basis.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just one more regarding marketing, if I may, you've made some changes recently in logo, tagline and I think even just visually, the marketing message seems to be striking a bit of a different tone, more sort of value and more, at least from my perspec
componenttext: And just one more regarding marketing, if I may, you've made some changes recently in logo, tagline and I think even just visually, the marketing message seems to be striking a bit of a different tone, more sort of value and more, at least from my perspective, striking more of a tone of value and really, family. Can you just talk about what you're doing on the marketing front and how that plays into your broader strategy?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We clearly are listening to the customer, that's what she's telling us, that she likes a more youthful feel. There are obviously some customers who have not yet discovered what's happened, the transformation the last several years, so we try to balance th
componenttext: We clearly are listening to the customer, that's what she's telling us, that she likes a more youthful feel. There are obviously some customers who have not yet discovered what's happened, the transformation the last several years, so we try to balance that with the -- to encourage those who haven't tried. Where they are currently shopping at higher-priced department specialty stores or those who are shopping in other channels to try JCPenney. But we're not walking our existing customer, we think that our existing customer also appreciates the fresh look and they've responded very well to Sephora and Mango and Call it Spring and Liz Claiborne. So we'll continue to offer attractions because we think being differentiated makes a huge difference. And when they see the private brand strength we have when they get in the store, we have the best of both worlds by offering terrific value without having to sacrifice quality or style.

componenttextpreview: It's still early days, we did spread the stores out across a wide piece of geography. The coastal stores did much better because obviously that's where more international guests have experienced this brand but it is a higher price basket than our typical
componenttext: It's still early days, we did spread the stores out across a wide piece of geography. The coastal stores did much better because obviously that's where more international guests have experienced this brand but it is a higher price basket than our typical basket, but not so much so that is off-putting. So we think it's within reach of our existing customers. I think Sephora is a good example. Sephora is entirely non-price promotional and we do get a higher basket the way we did in apparel. So we think when the customer sees something exciting and innovative and there's a reason come to the store more often. We think we can earn the basket.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of commercial development, are you seeing anything that would change your view two, three years out of your potential for store additions?
componenttext: In terms of commercial development, are you seeing anything that would change your view two, three years out of your potential for store additions?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, we're big advocates, the regional mall tends to be the biggest beneficiary because there won't be a lot of off-mall retail development and I don't think there will be virtually zero new mall developments. We think the developers are well-financed
componenttext: I guess, we're big advocates, the regional mall tends to be the biggest beneficiary because there won't be a lot of off-mall retail development and I don't think there will be virtually zero new mall developments. We think the developers are well-financed and have alternatives are going to continue to strengthen the offering, that helps us. At the same time, we'll keep our eye open for markets where we may be underpenetrated, although we have a pretty big footprint, about half our stores are off-mall and half of our stores are on-mall. But I don't think we're going to see a resurgence of big suburban housing projects that are going to drive a lot of commercial development around them at least in the near term.

componenttext: Jcpenney.com, you mentioned that you're targeting double-digit growth this year, that would be an acceleration from last year. Is the primary reason for that, the new additional marketing that you have planned?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's a good question but it's a complicated answer. First of all the biggest presence in the Catalog business was in the Home business and much of that was entered online by the customers looking at the catalog. So we have the headwinds of discont
componenttext: I think it's a good question but it's a complicated answer. First of all the biggest presence in the Catalog business was in the Home business and much of that was entered online by the customers looking at the catalog. So we have the headwinds of discontinuation of that piece of the business. Our Apparel business and Accessory business have been running up double-digit all along. So I think as we start this transition year for dot-com or essentially, we appear dot-com without the catalog piece would be much more store facing with the inventory being store related. There's a lot of customers who really have never shopped us online but shop us on the store, who didn't find the merchandise if they're shopping in the store online, that's changing. But we also are doing a better job, I believe, in messaging what our online presence is and we've added a lot of new tools like guided navigation and things to make it easier. So we're quite optimistic about our ability to compete online. We're still are one of the largest sites in retail, and expect to start to reignite double-digit growth.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just a question, are you still seeing the traffic differential between mall and off-mall, with off-mall still exceeding?
componenttext: And then just a question, are you still seeing the traffic differential between mall and off-mall, with off-mall still exceeding?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, particularly in the non-holiday periods. Somehow traffic's been quite weak since the Christmas holiday period. But our off-mall traffic continues to be quite strong. We expect this as holidays come up, we'll continue to overperform the mall traffic.
componenttext: Yes, particularly in the non-holiday periods. Somehow traffic's been quite weak since the Christmas holiday period. But our off-mall traffic continues to be quite strong. We expect this as holidays come up, we'll continue to overperform the mall traffic. Keep in mind, if somebody's coming to the mall oftentimes are cutting through our store getting to the mall, so there's a lot more traffic, that's lower conversion. When they come off-mall, obviously, incoming traffic to our store. So it's not just the traffic it's also the level of conversion. But it's clearly much better than it was during the depths of the recession.

componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the CapEx breakdown and what the buckets that will be there this year. And then also given the cost pressures that are out there, how do you align good, better and best offering and does it change?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the CapEx breakdown and what the buckets that will be there this year. And then also given the cost pressures that are out there, how do you align good, better and best offering and does it change?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: On CapEx, we have a pretty balanced approach. We have a lot of merchandising rollouts with the Mango and Call it Spring and Sephora, as well as center core upgrades. We have a number of large remodels during the year as well. We have a big digital CapEx c
componenttext: On CapEx, we have a pretty balanced approach. We have a lot of merchandising rollouts with the Mango and Call it Spring and Sephora, as well as center core upgrades. We have a number of large remodels during the year as well. We have a big digital CapEx continuing investment. We expect to lead in the digital space. We've done so and we want to continue to invest to be in that position in the future. We also have the normal capital investment and maintenance of our stores whether it's air-conditioning and roofing and escalators and so forth. But we believe that the $650 million that we've targeted is the correct investment for the year and balance across those areas. There are only three new stores. As to the good, better, best investments, I don't see a big shift from what we've done in the past. Obviously, to the extent that Mango and Call it Spring and initiatives like this overperformed that would tend to increase our penetration in the upper price points. But we know that of the cadence of our opening price point offers last year served us very well. I think Men's did it the best but Children's and Women's learned from it and our double tables statements have now become extremely successful.

componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the JCPenney Fourth Quarter and Year End 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations. Thank you. Ms. Hays, you may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's fourth quarter and year end financial results. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's fourth quarter and year end financial results. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, and the company's future results of operation could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also, please note that no portion of this call maybe rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of JCPenney. Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after February 25, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have Mike Ullman, JCPenney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Michael Dastugue, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Now, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'm going to start the call a little differently this morning. I'll start with just some opening comments, hand the call over to Michael Dastugue, our recently appointed Chief Financial Officer, who will g
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'm going to start the call a little differently this morning. I'll start with just some opening comments, hand the call over to Michael Dastugue, our recently appointed Chief Financial Officer, who will give you an overview of the fourth quarter and the full year 2010 results. After that, Kristin Hays, our Vice President of Investor Relations, will discuss our 2011 strategic initiatives followed with Michael providing quarterly and full year guidance. I will then join back for the Q&A portion of the call. 
As you know, I would ordinarily provide more insight and we'll leave that to Michael and Kristin today because I was a passenger on a car accident earlier this week. Fortunately, no one was seriously hurt but I've been left kind of beat up with some aches and bruises. In any case, I'm very glad to be with you on the call this morning. So outside my exciting game of bumper cars this week, I'm happy to report as the results reported this morning demonstrate that 2010 was a very good year for JCPenney, as we made significant progress toward the transformation of our company in the eyes of our customers and working towards our goal of being a retail industry leader. 
Our holiday season was particularly strong reflecting the positive reception we have seen in the merchandising initiatives that we've implemented, which really began to take hold the latter part of the year. Importantly, they positioned us well going in 2011. 
We were particularly pleased with the performance of our Men's Apparel and Women's businesses in the quarter. We also saw strength in our Accessories and Shoes and Handbags businesses and of course, Sephora. Thanks to our sales performance, coupled with managing our gross margins to plan and better SG&A performance and expense control, we were able to outperform our expectations at the bottom line. We're leveraging on the strong momentum we created in 2010, in order to move us closer and faster to our goal of being a retail industry leader. 
Over the last several years we've infused great style in our assortments, delivered world-class customer service, introduced new and innovative retail technologies that made JCPenney a retail leader in the digital age. And now, we have a new JCPenney brand logo that symbolizes this transformation.  Our new logo continues to honor our rich legacy, while reflecting the modern retailer we've become. The logo will make its debut during our spring fashion ad launch and the Academy Awards this Sunday evening. 
So with that, I'll now turn the call over to Michael Dastugue.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. I will first cover the highlights of our very solid fourth quarter and full year performance, and then we'll move on to 2011. As Mike mentioned, our financial results reflect the progress we made in 2010 and the conti
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. I will first cover the highlights of our very solid fourth quarter and full year performance, and then we'll move on to 2011. As Mike mentioned, our financial results reflect the progress we made in 2010 and the continued work we are doing to transform the JCPenney brand in the minds of our customers and position JCPenney as a growth leader in the industry. 
This morning, we reported strong results for the fourth quarter. The company's comp store sales grew 4.5%, an increase for the fourth consecutive quarter and ahead of our expectations. Earnings from continuing operations for the fourth quarter were $1.09 per share, an impressive 30% growth over last year, and after the $0.08 of one-time charges in this year's number that we announced a few weeks ago. 
Our fourth quarter performance can be attributed to three factors. First, the company's growth initiatives grow top line sales. Second, we managed gross margins well and third, the team exhibited disciplined expense control. 
Total sales for the quarter grew 2.8% to $5.7 billion. As a percent of sales, gross margin was in line with our expectations and decreased approximately 60 basis points to 37.6% of sales. We are pleased with this result as we were up against the company's historic peak margins achieved in the fourth quarter of last year. 
SG&A for the quarter was better than we expected, at $1.46 billion or 25.7% of sales. Lower SG&A was primarily driven by expense controls with salary and related benefits and marketing expenses coming in better than planned. Our tax rate was also lower at 35% due to a true up of our state tax reserves at the close of the year as various issues were resolved in favor of the company. 
Moving on to the full year performance. In 2010, comp store sales increased 2.5% in line with our guidance for an increase of low-single digits for the year. Total sales increased 1.2% for the year. Catalog sales added $454 million to our revenues in 2010. Going forward, we anticipate that the increasing contribution from our growth initiatives and sales from jcp.com will not only replace this revenue over time but also significantly contribute to our top line growth. 
For the full year, the company's gross margin dollars increased $50 million over last year. As a percent of sales, gross margin decreased just 20 basis points to 39.2% when compared to last year's historic peak of 39.4%. 
SG&A was also well-controlled at approximately 30.1% of sales. This is about $32 million below a year ago and 60 basis points lower as a percent of sales. In 2010, we generated $158 million in free cash flow and continue to have a very strong balance sheet with flexibility to support the key components of our growth initiatives. 
Capital expenditures for the year were $499 million, in line with our plan and included investments in our digital initiatives, as well as two new JCPenney stores, 44 renovations, over 100 store updates and 76 new Sephora inside JCPenney locations. Our year-end inventory levels are in line with expected sales trends and position us well as we head into the first half of 2011 with the expansion of Liz Claiborne into additional categories, the rollout of additional Sephora inside JCPenney locations and sufficient levels of inventory to support our growth initiatives, which are non-comparable for the first half of 2011. Specifically, we ended the year with customer-facing inventory up about 5% year-over-year and approximately 6% on a total basis, which includes what we currently call, on-the-water inventory. 
In summary, JCPenney's 2010 results reflect the team's focus on the execution of our initiatives in order to deliver profitable sales growth, while effectively managing gross margin and leveraging our SG&A. 
With that, I'll now turn it over to Kristin, who will cover the company's key areas of focus for 2011. I'll then come back in a moment to provide our financial outlook for 2011 before turning the call over for questions. Kristin?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. We are getting off to a fast start in 2011 as our teams continue to work hard to deliver profitable sales growth by focusing on four key areas. First, we will continue to deliver great style at compelling prices, heightening our styl
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. We are getting off to a fast start in 2011 as our teams continue to work hard to deliver profitable sales growth by focusing on four key areas. 
First, we will continue to deliver great style at compelling prices, heightening our style authority. We're doing this through offering a balance of the best private, exclusive and national brands. For example, we are expanding Liz Claiborne across a range of categories in home, petites in women sizes, and introducing activewear, dresses and swimwear this year. 
We are also expanding MNG by Mango and Call it Spring by The ALDO Group to an additional 500 doors. We're continuing to rollout Sephora inside JCPenney and center core with 76 new locations opening this year. Finally, our new Modern Bride collection, which is a partnership with Cond√© Nast, got off to a great start for Valentine's Day. It is in bridal boutiques in 1,068 stores and on jcp.com. 
These attractions are exclusive to JCPenney and bring new customers to our stores and to jcp.com. We recognize that we have an opportunity to improve our sales productivity per net square foot primarily in the center core of our store. 
Our ability to deliver unparalleled value through offering stylish and quality merchandise at great prices sets us apart from our competitors and we fully intend to capitalize on this strength. 
Our second major area of focus is continuing to deliver a differentiated and industry-leading customer experience, delivering an interaction not just the transaction. We're giving our associates the tools to build loyalty through individualized memorable interactions with our customers. 
The value of superior customer service is not new to us. We've been successfully focused on it for years with our CustomerFIRST training and our customer satisfaction scores have been steadily on the rise. In January, we were named the top department store for the third year running in the annual NRF American Express Customer Choice Survey. We could not deliver on this important point of differentiation without highly engaged and talented associates and we appreciate their efforts. 
We also continue to expand our JCP Rewards program, which has grown to 26 million members and these customers spend more per year than our average customer and shop with us more frequently. In the third area, we are focused on offering personalized, impactful digital experiences that allow us to connect with our customers in a different and more direct way. 
This starts with continuing to dramatically improve the shopping experience on jcp.com, which we've been doing by introducing guided navigation, launching a new mobile site, connecting with our customers through social media, bringing in digital coupons and other new features in addition to the rollout of Find More in our stores. 
Taken together, with the changes we are making to our online merchandise assortment, our objective is to build upon the strong growth we experienced online in 2010 in order to grow jcp.com sales by double digits in 2011. 
Fourth and very importantly, across our organization we are focused on continuing to optimize our resources and reduce expenses where appropriate. For example, we are continuing to optimize our marketing expense in order to get a better return on our spend with a new more localized approach and enhanced digital marketing. We will continue to develop our expense-minded culture and maintain rigorous cost disciplines including across our home office. We are driving efficiencies through our second-generation markdown and size optimization tools, as well as deploying RFID to allow us to better control our inventory and turn it more effectively. 
We are also instituting new pricing tools to increase sales, profits and the customer's perception of value, enabling us to increase our AUR.  And we will further capitalize on our jTime's store staffing tool to control salary dollars and continue to manage our SG&A expense. These initiatives come on top of the significant steps we announced last month to complete the wind down of catalog and streamline certain areas of the business. 
As we pursue these expense savings, we are also taking a number of important steps to mitigate the impact of input cost increases. We are leveraging supplier relationships that we've built over the years, which enable us to place orders for goods earlier than most other retailers. 
We are also capitalizing on our vertically integrated product team to optimize the product cycle through product engineering, strategic and alternative raw material acquisitions, advanced production planning and taking even greater control over the supply chain, especially overseas, where we have leverage that others don't, in order to reduce our shipping costs. 
At the same time, we've been testing price elasticity for the past year to identify where we can opportunistically increase prices. In the better and best pricing tiers, we've had success in modestly increasing ticket in certain areas. 
And finally, we focus on increasing private and exclusive brands in our merchandise mix as we have the greatest control over costs and they allow us to best address our customers' needs for affordability. Even with lower price points than national brands, our private brand margin is typically 300 to 500 basis points higher than our national brand. 
In short, these four key areas of focus are designed to deliver profitable sales growth, maintain margins, while controlling our expenses. And in the end, should enable JCPenney to return value to our shareholders. 
Now, I will turn the call back over to Michael to go over the company's financial outlook for 2011.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kristin. As we look to 2011, the consumer environment remains uncertain and budgets for the moderate customer we serve remain tight. As a result, we are continuing to plan our business conservatively. Specifically, our outlook for 2011 is as follo
componenttext:
Thanks, Kristin. As we look to 2011, the consumer environment remains uncertain and budgets for the moderate customer we serve remain tight. As a result, we are continuing to plan our business conservatively. Specifically, our outlook for 2011 is as follows. 
We are planning our same-store sales to increase low- to mid- single digits for the year. Similar with what we experienced in 2010, we expect total sales to increase approximately 300 basis points less than our comparable store sales. Again, I would like to remind you that this is due to the elimination of our Catalog and the Outlet business and this is a temporary impact. 
The gross margin rate is expected to be about flat year-over-year.  As Kristin mentioned, we are managing pricing pressures in 2011 by adjusting our product mix, leveraging our sourcing capabilities and where appropriate, increasing prices. We believe we have the strategies in place to successfully navigate this inflationary environment, which is a testament to our strength in sourcing goods and flexibility we have with our private brands. 
We will continue to aggressively manage SG&A in 2011 with expectations that will remain flat as a percent of sales year-over-year. Taking these parameters together, the company expects 2011 earnings to increase by about 45% to be in the range of $2 to $2.10 per share. This does not take into account the impact of our newly approved $900 million share repurchase program that we announced today. 
As noted in the earnings release, we intend to repurchase common stock through an open-market program beginning in March. We will update our annual guidance when we report first quarter results in May, as we will have better visibility to the impact of our share repurchase program on our earnings target. 
Finally, let me add two more quick notes on 2011. Our capital expenditures are planned at $650 million for the year, which includes investments in important planning and allocation tools such as size and markdown optimization, our digital initiatives, the expansion of MNG by Mango and Call it Spring, three new department stores, 70 renovations and the 76 new Sephora inside JCPenney locations. 
Also the 2011 pension expense for our qualified pension plan will be $87 million or $0.22 per share for the year. This is a $134 million reduction from our 2010 expense. Looking at the first quarter specifically, we anticipate 3% to 5% growth in comp store sales. On a monthly basis, February is expected to be towards the higher end of the range, March is expected to be negative and April is expected to be significantly better mostly due to the Easter holidays shifting into April reporting period this year. 
As I mentioned overall for 2011, we expect gross margins to be about flat to last year, with the first quarter remaining under pressure as we work to improve the company's AUR under our pricing strategies and initiatives such as the markdown optimization. Those initiatives really won't take hold until later in the year. 
In addition, margins in the first quarter will be negatively impacted as we cycle against the profitable tail of our last Big Book that was still active in the first quarter of 2010. This impact is not expected to continue beyond Q1. 
For the first quarter earnings, we expect to be in the range of $0.18 to $0.23 per share, which includes about $0.05 of some non-comparable items, including the renewal of our revolving credit facility which matures next year, charges related to the exit of the Catalog and Outlet business that we announced earlier and modest expenses related to our new growth initiatives of The Foundry, Gifting Grace and CLAD. 
In summary, we are excited about the potential for additional growth in 2011. We expect the first quarter will be the smallest of the year and our earnings growth will accelerate after the first quarter as our initiatives take hold. 
Now, we will open the call for questions.

componenttext: Well, Penney's really never had a compelling cosmetics and fragrance offer. Obviously, as we move to over 300 stores with Sephora this year, that's the biggest productivity aid to the center core. We also are very committed to the Handbag business, the Shoe business and the Apparel business. And we believe we have an opportunity to improve our conversion from the many customers who buy sportswear with us that are not buying their accessories with the sportswear. So we've organized our merchant group in the way we're focusing our space and sales promotion activity, we'll continue to focus on what we perceive to be a good upside opportunity productivity.

componenttext: Well, I think it was clearly a number of things. I mean, the salary and related benefits and marketing, those are the biggest expenditures we had. And they came in not only better than what we would've expected but better than last year. But it was also across a number of categories. I would say across the board, we did a great job in the organization managing our expenses. Our store managers made the right decisions throughout the quarter. There was tough weather issues as an example in January, they made the right decisions because you're not going to have customer traffic. You don't have to staff at the same level. So those types of things that I think we did a very good job of the during the fourth quarter.

componenttext: And then the last question, just can you give us a little bit of color on the elasticity testing that you did. Prices are up 5%, what happened to units if prices are up 10%? It's interesting to see you guys have tested it and I'll be curious to see the learnings.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011

componenttext: Kristin, do you want to mention that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. sure. We have, Chuck, been testing, I think, the Women's division are testing it in the spring of last year and we rolled out some testing company-wide over the summer. Overall, what we were seeing in a good price point when you raise prices, let's j
componenttext: Yes. sure. We have, Chuck, been testing, I think, the Women's division are testing it in the spring of last year and we rolled out some testing company-wide over the summer. Overall, what we were seeing in a good price point when you raise prices, let's just say $1 on an opening price point, units did go down, which is what we would expect. And that's why it's important to test because you learn not only the pricing issues but also customer behavior around that. What we did learn also is in the better and best price points that when we raised the price, let's say $1. We sold enough units to cover what we lost in the good price point and at better margins. So the behavior that we learned of the customer around that was that we can actually raise prices in certain category on better and best items to make up for the loss of demand when you raised it and the opening price point. And what we're doing with those learnings going forward in 2011 is that around the important key promotional times of Mother's Day and Father's Day and back-to-school, we understand that we can offer the opening price point of a $3.99 towel or $7.99 t-shirt and offer it during that promotional time, when it's very important to have that compelling value to the customer. And then take the price back up during those non-promotional and appointment shopping times, and continue to sell enough at the better and best price points to make up for the change in demand at the higher price.

componenttext: I don't know that we're going to disclose that level of specificity, Chuck. But certainly, understand that we fully recognize that when you are taking your prices up, especially at the good price point, we recognize that units come down, so we're planning that accordingly.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: One thing I'd mention, Chuck, is I think we feel very good about having a strong private brand presence and our direct sourcing gives us an advantage. As our national brand manufacturers may take the prices even more aggressively, the gap between that pri
componenttext: One thing I'd mention, Chuck, is I think we feel very good about having a strong private brand presence and our direct sourcing gives us an advantage. As our national brand manufacturers may take the prices even more aggressively, the gap between that pricing and our private brand pricing obviously increases, it makes our value proposition more compelling. As well as those retailers that are below us in price point, the percent of cost increase for them and their unit retail is obviously a higher percentage. So we think we have an opportunity in the commodity items at our opening price points. We think we have a compelling opportunity to give the customer the choice between the best of national brands and our best private brands.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011

componenttext: Just a few questions on the margin and perhaps help us share your confidence for flat margins this year. We know you've just seen some contraction in the back half and it sounds like you're looking for pressure in the first quarter as it relates to margins. So kind of help us think about how we get to flat margins for the year especially as the back half, we are looking for some steeper inflationary pressures?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We feel very good about the way we placed spring and by getting out in front of it and working directly with our brand manufacturers, suppliers, we feel we've got some advantage to some of our competitors. I think it's also important to recognize that we
componenttext: We feel very good about the way we placed spring and by getting out in front of it and working directly with our brand manufacturers, suppliers, we feel we've got some advantage to some of our competitors. I think it's also important to recognize that we have other initiatives that are accretive to margin. Our new size optimization, our new markdown optimization and our pricing tools are designed to help offset the costing headwinds. And we also believe that now we're up against the same clearance strategy as a year ago, much of our lack of visibility of the margin number in 2010 was a non-comparable clearance initiation, which we've managed better in some time frames than others. We're also looking very strongly at some of the promotional double couponing. We think our rewards program is the best way for us to speak to our best customers and we believe there's some opportunities there to deliver terrific value but without giving the customer more than maybe they're expecting.

componenttext: So, Mike, any sense of magnitude, how we should be thinking about the first half versus the back half in terms of margin opportunity and then perhaps flip that with any sort of thoughts on the inflationary, what you're seeing in the near term versus in the back half?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't know if we're going to get very, very specific except to say we feel in the first half, we got a bit more cost forgiveness because we got ahead of it. In the back half where we see probably more costing issue, we'd be able to get more impact out o
componenttext: I don't know if we're going to get very, very specific except to say we feel in the first half, we got a bit more cost forgiveness because we got ahead of it. In the back half where we see probably more costing issue, we'd be able to get more impact out of productivity tools. So I think flat for the year is the right guidance and it will be coming from different directions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then my second question on the expenses. Kristin, you mentioned the fourth initiative, some major plans of attack and you're sort of tackling a lot of areas whether it's marketing, turns, salary dollars. Maybe give us a sense of some quantification, w
componenttext: And then my second question on the expenses. Kristin, you mentioned the fourth initiative, some major plans of attack and you're sort of tackling a lot of areas whether it's marketing, turns, salary dollars. Maybe give us a sense of some quantification, what sort of the targets you've  got there as you identify some expense opportunities?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. I think it's not something that we're going to provide financial target today, obviously, Adrianne. Otherwise, we would've outlined those already for you. But understand that we are focused on these four key areas and across the organization both i
componenttext: Right. I think it's not something that we're going to provide financial target today, obviously, Adrianne. Otherwise, we would've outlined those already for you. But understand that we are focused on these four key areas and across the organization both in stores and home office, we recognize there's opportunities not just to cut expenses. As we've said for last three or four years, we don't believe in just percentage cuts across the board. It's really more about optimizing the resources that you do have and leveraging the return on your investment and improving that return. So the center core productivity as Mike said with modern shoes and handbags and Sephora inside JCPenney, improving cross shopping across those areas. Those are things that we're focused on and we have been focused on. Marketing is looking at local market optimization, understanding what works in the market, pre-print versus television and the right mix of those to get a better return on your invested dollar from a marketing perspective. So it's really more about looking at things across the board, group by group as opposed to some sort of expense cut across the organization.

componenttext: We haven't really provided guidance on marketing spend for the year. So understand that as we go forward into 2011, we know that we can take some of those learnings and deploy those in 2011. But we haven't provided specific guidance around marketing expense.

componenttext: There's also some shifts, Adrianne, regarding the Catalog business because some of those media costs, the catalog were reflected in marketing expenses. So we're not going out of the Print Media business because obviously, we have direct mail and other Find More documents that help the customer navigate the shopping with us or whatever channel they choose. But there will be some transition, non-comparability during the year.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011

componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the discontinued business. It looks like it will be weighing on sales growth by about 300 basis points. What types of margin was that business running at and will you see a margin benefit from shutting those down this year?
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the discontinued business. It looks like it will be weighing on sales growth by about 300 basis points. What types of margin was that business running at and will you see a margin benefit from shutting those down this year?

componenttextpreview: Sure. I think as you probably heard in some of the comments. I think the impact on the margins are primarily going to be in the first quarter because that probably had the biggest impact from our Big Book, as we transitioned out of the Big Book, there was
componenttext: Sure. I think as you probably heard in some of the comments. I think the impact on the margins are primarily going to be in the first quarter because that probably had the biggest impact from our Big Book, as we transitioned out of the Big Book, there was still a fair amount of sales that we reported in first quarter of 2010. So I think as you move out of first quarter, that would be the impact of getting out of the catalog will be much less throughout the remainder of the year. In terms of -- as Mike said, we're not totally getting out of the Print business but we will not be sending out dedicated catalog books going forward. Additionally, we're transitioning out of our outlets stores over the next couple of years. We announced that here about a month ago. So it will be this 300 basis point differential throughout the year and that relates to that $454 million of catalog sales that I talked about earlier.
