headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And finally, just wanted to ask about Mango, what you're seeing from the test stores? Are you attracting a new customer? And what's happening with the price points there?
componenttext: And finally, just wanted to ask about Mango, what you're seeing from the test stores? Are you attracting a new customer? And what's happening with the price points there?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's interesting, we opened 77 Mango stores in the fall intentionally to get a read on various markets and various customer segments. I had a terrific reaction by those who have known Mango from overseas. So, a lot of our international visitors immediatel
componenttext: It's interesting, we opened 77 Mango stores in the fall intentionally to get a read on various markets and various customer segments. I had a terrific reaction by those who have known Mango from overseas. So, a lot of our international visitors immediately not only recognize the brand but recognize how sharp the pricing was compared with what they were used to. So we've worked with the Mango organization and we've modified a lot of things from the learnings. And we feel very good that our existing customers as they get more understanding of the brand will respond very well. Interestingly, when they buy the first purchase, they may buy 1.4 pieces. The second purchase is maybe additional piece. The third purchase an additional piece. So I think it's going to be a learning experience for the customers, as well as for us. There really only five true fast fashion brands in the world. It's Zara, Uniqlo, Forever 21, H&M and Mango. And to be able to offer that kind of fast fashion in a JCPenney store for the modern customer at modern prices, I think, is a terrific attraction and I think over time will bring a new customer to the store.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: If you take a look at your first quarter comp guidance, it's up 3% to 5%. The high end of that is implying significant acceleration in the two-year comp trend. Is there any change in the promotional calendar 1Q of '11 versus 1Q '10?
componenttext: If you take a look at your first quarter comp guidance, it's up 3% to 5%. The high end of that is implying significant acceleration in the two-year comp trend. Is there any change in the promotional calendar 1Q of '11 versus 1Q '10?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at our performance in the fourth quarter,  which is obviously the most relevant, we are at 4.5%. So it's right smack at the top of the range. As you probably remember, we messaged last year that our growth initiatives really kicked in
componenttext: I think if you look at our performance in the fourth quarter,  which is obviously the most relevant, we are at 4.5%. So it's right smack at the top of the range. As you probably remember, we messaged last year that our growth initiatives really kicked in the second half.  And if you look at our performance either in absolute form or competitively, we did extremely well in the fall season. I think five to six months, we led. So we don't think it's a leap of logic to move from the fourth quarter to the first quarter. The March time frame is obviously impacted by the Easter shift and the particularly close relationship of that to Mother's Day. But I think it's been mentioned earlier on the call that February is going to be probably the weakest in terms of the transition. But beyond that, we feel very good about it.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, Mike, maybe share with us your thoughts in your real estate strategy go forward, any plans to further rationalize the store base?
componenttext: And then, Mike, maybe share with us your thoughts in your real estate strategy go forward, any plans to further rationalize the store base?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as I think any other retailer will tell you, we continue to look at the store base. The vast majority of our stores are contributing even during recession well above any hurdle rate we would have. We're opening two new stores this weekend on a soft
componenttext: Well, as I think any other retailer will tell you, we continue to look at the store base. The vast majority of our stores are contributing even during recession well above any hurdle rate we would have. We're opening two new stores this weekend on a soft opening basis, one in suburban Washington and Maryland, and the other one in Brisbane, California, a former Mervyn's store in the Serramonte Mall. We have one more store in the fall here in Dallas. As mentioned earlier, we touched over 100 stores a year in terms of renovation and we have some of our new growth concepts that will be opening. I think the commercial real estate market going forward is still fairly uncertain. We have a lot of opportunities in our existing stores for increased productivity and we will continue to invest in new attractions and new ways to improve our performance in our existing stores.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the last question on inventory, the spread improved at the end of fourth quarter versus third quarter but we're still seeing inventory outpace sales on a per square foot basis. When should we expect those two metrics to be aligned? Is it at the e
componenttext: And then the last question on inventory, the spread improved at the end of fourth quarter versus third quarter but we're still seeing inventory outpace sales on a per square foot basis. When should we expect those two metrics to be aligned? Is it at the end of the first quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, it's been called out the last three quarters and each time we have proved we sold the stuff we had. So I would say, that is the same response I would have. We obviously think we have the inventory necessary to support our plans and asp
componenttext: Well, first of all, it's been called out the last three quarters and each time we have proved we sold the stuff we had. So I would say, that is the same response I would have. We obviously think we have the inventory necessary to support our plans and aspirations going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And, Mike, if I can just add that if you think about our first quarter in 2010 as we were getting through 2009, we ended pretty light. And I think we called out the fact that our first quarter results in 2010, we felt like we lost some business. So we wan
componenttext: And, Mike, if I can just add that if you think about our first quarter in 2010 as we were getting through 2009, we ended pretty light. And I think we called out the fact that our first quarter results in 2010, we felt like we lost some business. So we wanted to get back in business especially in the Women's Apparel area.

componenttext: The first quarter and second quarter, actually.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Bob Drbul of Barclays Capital.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: For the fourth quarter, can you give us a breakdown on the composition on the comp traffic, UPT, AUR and sort of how you see that playing into the comp guidance that you've given us this morning for 2011?
componenttext: For the fourth quarter, can you give us a breakdown on the composition on the comp traffic, UPT, AUR and sort of how you see that playing into the comp guidance that you've given us this morning for 2011?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. For the year, last year, we said our AUR went down. We intentionally got more promotional to drive the business, as well as our non-comparable clearance strategy had an impact in our promotional strategy. Our units for the year were up about 9.6%. O
componenttext: Sure. For the year, last year, we said our AUR went down. We intentionally got more promotional to drive the business, as well as our non-comparable clearance strategy had an impact in our promotional strategy. Our units for the year were up about 9.6%. Our transactions were up 7.5%. Our units per transaction were up 1.9%. So aside from a modest decline in AUR, our metrics are pretty strong and pretty much reflected in the comps. As we transition in 2011, we said, we're consciously going to work on improving our AUR for the variety of things that were mentioned. We believe that we continue to overperform in the opening price point items because we think that the strong merchandising performance we had in 2010 in Men's, Women's and Kids, particularly in the opening price points, that gives a lot of confidence that we're resonating not only the quality of the merchandise but also the presentation that's impactful and has work very well for us. So I think on the metrics, we feel we got it planned properly. The big unknown, of course, is the appetite for pricing  across all categories, all price points.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And could you give us a breakdown on how private brands are doing versus national brands on a comp basis and maybe just sort of how the gross margins on those are benefiting?
componenttext: And could you give us a breakdown on how private brands are doing versus national brands on a comp basis and maybe just sort of how the gross margins on those are benefiting?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've said over the last year or so, we've had about 300 basis points difference in the trend of our top private brands versus our top national brands, as much as a 600 or 700 basis point GP  differential. So that continues to be the case and we have
componenttext: Yes. We've said over the last year or so, we've had about 300 basis points difference in the trend of our top private brands versus our top national brands, as much as a 600 or 700 basis point GP  differential. So that continues to be the case and we have two brands that are over $1 billion in size, St. John's Bay in Arizona and a number of other brands that are obviously hundred million of dollars. So we think that the legitimate brands with brand attributes the customer recognizes and comes to expect and gives us a, I think, a strong traction beyond just saying we have labels. And we do a lot of aided and unaided research and we are constantly encouraged by how much unaided awareness there are of our private brands.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011

componenttext: Can you just give a little bit more detail in terms of some of the expense items, were they changes in any of the accruals were incentive compensation in the quarter? And also, can you talk about the change in guidance in terms of pension from the third quarter guidance, what we're just getting now in terms of impact to the year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start out and maybe Michael can finish off. I think, our incentive comp is modestly below our budget as we had some people made their plans and others didn't, which is also reflected in insurance and benefits that went along with it. But generally, w
componenttext: I'll start out and maybe Michael can finish off. I think, our incentive comp is modestly below our budget as we had some people made their plans and others didn't, which is also reflected in insurance and benefits that went along with it. But generally, we're on plan and, Michael, you want to take up the other pieces?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, as we called out, with $87 million for our qualified pension plan for 2011, I think I should also call out the fact that we've lowered our expected rate of return from 8.4% to 7.5%. And we did that along the lines of what we've been talking
componenttext: Yes, Michael, as we called out, with $87 million for our qualified pension plan for 2011, I think I should also call out the fact that we've lowered our expected rate of return from 8.4% to 7.5%. And we did that along the lines of what we've been talking about here for the last couple of years as we've think about our pension plan and as you know, we froze that to new entrants about well over four years ago. And over time, we're gradually reducing the amount of equity allocated to the plan and increasing the amount of fixed income, and so we thought that made sense. And so I think as we called out, that has an impact of about -- it's impacting our earnings this year about $0.22. So I don't know if that answers your question. Assets are at a little over about $5.25 billion at the end of 2010.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And, Mike, can you just talk about the experience on Liz Claiborne? You've changed over a lot of the other Liz names to Liz Claiborne across the store. What's sort of been the total pick up from that change?
componenttext: And, Mike, can you just talk about the experience on Liz Claiborne? You've changed over a lot of the other Liz names to Liz Claiborne across the store. What's sort of been the total pick up from that change?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It couldn't be a more positive picture, frankly. Not only it has been well ahead of our expectations in the existing categories, which I think numbers something like 30 categories. We're expanding it beyond those categories for spring and beyond. So the b
componenttext: It couldn't be a more positive picture, frankly. Not only it has been well ahead of our expectations in the existing categories, which I think numbers something like 30 categories. We're expanding it beyond those categories for spring and beyond. So the brand has really resonated. We knew it by research ahead of time it's the number one most recognized brand by our core customer. And I think the fact we've been able to keep the retails very modest and it actually came down a bit with our GP actually going up. The effectiveness of our marketing and the sales associates understanding of the brand and ability to discuss it with the customers has been terrific. So we planned way up for 2011 and continue to feel very strongly about the brand.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just sort of diving back into this outlet decision. Is part of what's driving that decision to discontinue the outlet, the success you've had with your clearance strategy in store or could you just sort of talk about philosophically why...
componenttext: And then just sort of diving back into this outlet decision. Is part of what's driving that decision to discontinue the outlet, the success you've had with your clearance strategy in store or could you just sort of talk about philosophically why...

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's two aspects to that. First of all, obviously by definition, catalog inventories is invisible to the customer because it's in a warehouse that we ship pieces to the stores. To the extent we start to align our inventory for online with the store inv
componenttext: There's two aspects to that. First of all, obviously by definition, catalog inventories is invisible to the customer because it's in a warehouse that we ship pieces to the stores. To the extent we start to align our inventory for online with the store inventory, it's much more effective to clear the inventory, we have extra inventory, so the same items. It's much easier to clear in the store, much more profitably in our existing stores. So aside from furniture and some of the very big-ticket items or items that are not in our store inventory like, say, baby cribs and rolled goods and so forth. We feel much more confident about getting higher GP by clearing with our existing store footprint. I will say that our clearance strategy gives us some confidence that by having clearance on the floor everyday, the customer really enjoys that rather than these five or six big events a year. That also supports the idea we can clear goods out of the dot-com space on the same basis.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just one more regarding marketing, if I may, you've made some changes recently in logo, tagline and I think even just visually, the marketing message seems to be striking a bit of a different tone, more sort of value and more, at least from my perspec
componenttext: And just one more regarding marketing, if I may, you've made some changes recently in logo, tagline and I think even just visually, the marketing message seems to be striking a bit of a different tone, more sort of value and more, at least from my perspective, striking more of a tone of value and really, family. Can you just talk about what you're doing on the marketing front and how that plays into your broader strategy?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We clearly are listening to the customer, and that's what she's telling us, that she likes a more youthful feel. There are obviously some customers who have not yet discovered what's happened, the transformation the last several years, so we try to balanc
componenttext: We clearly are listening to the customer, and that's what she's telling us, that she likes a more youthful feel. There are obviously some customers who have not yet discovered what's happened, the transformation the last several years, so we try to balance that with the -- to encourage those who haven't tried. Where they are currently shopping at higher-priced department specialty stores or those who are shopping in other channels to try JCPenney. But we're not walking our existing customer, we think that our existing customer also appreciates the fresh look and they've responded very well to Sephora and Mango and Call it Spring and Liz Claiborne. So we'll continue to offer attractions because we think being differentiated makes a huge difference. And when they see the private brand strength we have when they get in the store, we have the best of both worlds by offering terrific value without having to sacrifice quality or style.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Jeff Klinefelter of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jeff Klinefelter of Piper Jaffray.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the pricing, a very helpful detail in terms of your testing during this last year. Just curious now, we're starting to observe more consistent price increase, out the door pricing and more so at the national brands across the channel. Compare your test
componenttext: On the pricing, a very helpful detail in terms of your testing during this last year. Just curious now, we're starting to observe more consistent price increase, out the door pricing and more so at the national brands across the channel. Compare your testing in the results during the year to more kind of what you're seeing realtime now, still seeing the same blended impact to your unit velocity and margins? Any differences from what you were testing in 2010?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the testing that we saw in 2010 really helped us understand the customer's behavior and what we've seen so far year-to-date with the price increases that we have has been consistent with what we learned last year. That's the importance of the test
componenttext: I think the testing that we saw in 2010 really helped us understand the customer's behavior and what we've seen so far year-to-date with the price increases that we have has been consistent with what we learned last year. That's the importance of the testing. That we are in fact seeing a consistent behavior this year versus what we tested last year.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So if you were to net to the results, what kind of net impact to inflation versus trade-off on units would you expect for the year or can you not get that granular?
componenttext: So if you were to net to the results, what kind of net impact to inflation versus trade-off on units would you expect for the year or can you not get that granular?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're not going to get that granular. Not only is the way we're looking at it competitive but also it varies category by category.
componenttext: We're not going to get that granular. Not only is the way we're looking at it competitive but also it varies category by category.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: One other follow-up on Mango. Just curious, Mike, if what you're seeing in terms of the basket to the extent you're doing the basket analysis on those transactions. What are you seeing in terms of the trade up? Is that existing customer trading up? Can yo
componenttext: One other follow-up on Mango. Just curious, Mike, if what you're seeing in terms of the basket to the extent you're doing the basket analysis on those transactions. What are you seeing in terms of the trade up? Is that existing customer trading up? Can you tell to the extent that you are drawing someone in from another channel of distribution, just any other detail around that...

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's still early days, we did spread the stores out across a wide piece of geography. The coastal stores did much better because obviously that's where more international guests have experienced this brand but it's at a higher price basket than our typica
componenttext: It's still early days, we did spread the stores out across a wide piece of geography. The coastal stores did much better because obviously that's where more international guests have experienced this brand but it's at a higher price basket than our typical basket, but not so much so that is off-putting. So we think it's within reach of our existing customers. I think Sephora is a good example. Sephora is entirely non-price promotional and we do get a higher basket the way we did in apparel. So we think when the customer sees something exciting and innovative and there's a reason to come to the store more often. We think we can earn the basket.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of commercial development, are you seeing anything that would change your view two, three years out of your potential for store additions?
componenttext: In terms of commercial development, are you seeing anything that would change your view two, three years out of your potential for store additions?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, we're big advocates, the regional mall tends to be the biggest beneficiary because there won't be a lot of off-mall retail development and I don't think there will be virtually zero new mall developments. We think the developers are well-financed
componenttext: I guess, we're big advocates, the regional mall tends to be the biggest beneficiary because there won't be a lot of off-mall retail development and I don't think there will be virtually zero new mall developments. We think the developers are well-financed and have alternatives are going to continue to strengthen the offering, that helps us. At the same time, we'll keep our eye open for markets where we may be underpenetrated, although we have a pretty big footprint, about half our stores are off-mall and half of our stores are on-mall. But I don't think we're going to see a resurgence of big suburban housing projects that are going to drive a lot of commercial development around them at least in the near term.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Erika Maschmeyer of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Erika Maschmeyer of Robert W. Baird.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jcpenney.com, you mentioned that you're targeting double-digit growth this year, that would be an acceleration from last year. Is the primary reason for that, the new additional marketing that you have planned?
componenttext: Jcpenney.com, you mentioned that you're targeting double-digit growth this year, that would be an acceleration from last year. Is the primary reason for that, the new additional marketing that you have planned?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's a good question but it's a complicated answer. First of all the biggest presence in the Catalog business was in the Home business and much of that was entered online by the customers looking at the catalog. So we have the headwinds of discont
componenttext: I think it's a good question but it's a complicated answer. First of all the biggest presence in the Catalog business was in the Home business and much of that was entered online by the customers looking at the catalog. So we have the headwinds of discontinuation of that piece of the business. Our Apparel business and Accessory business have been running up double-digit all along. So I think as we start this transition year for dot-com or essentially, we appear dot-com without the catalog piece would be much more store facing with the inventory being store related. There's a lot of customers who really have never shopped us online but shop us on the store, who didn't find the merchandise if they're shopping in the store online, that's changing. But we also are doing a better job, I believe, in messaging what our online presence is and we've added a lot of new tools like guided navigation and things to make it easier. So we're quite optimistic about our ability to compete online. We still are one of the largest sites in retail, and expect to start to reignite double-digit growth.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just a question, are you still seeing the traffic differential between mall and off-mall, with off-mall still exceeding?
componenttext: And then just a question, are you still seeing the traffic differential between mall and off-mall, with off-mall still exceeding?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, particularly in the non-holiday periods. Somehow traffic's been quite weak since the Christmas holiday period. But our off-mall traffic continues to be quite strong. We expect this as holidays come up, we'll continue to overperform the mall traffic.
componenttext: Yes, particularly in the non-holiday periods. Somehow traffic's been quite weak since the Christmas holiday period. But our off-mall traffic continues to be quite strong. We expect this as holidays come up, we'll continue to overperform the mall traffic. Keep in mind, if somebody's coming to the mall oftentimes are cutting through our store getting to the mall, so there's a lot more traffic, that's lower conversion. When they come off-mall, obviously coming directly to our store. So it's not just the traffic it's also the level of conversion. But it's clearly much better than it was during the depths of the recession.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to clarify, is the biggest reason for the pension decline year-over-year the assumption change?
componenttext: Just wanted to clarify, is the biggest reason for the pension decline year-over-year the assumption change?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, that actually has a negative impact on the expense. In other words, the expense would've actually been lower if we had not lowered it. But we thought it was an appropriate thing to do. So if you think about it, 90 basis points on $5.25 billion,
componenttext: Actually, that actually has a negative impact on the expense. In other words, the expense would've actually been lower if we had not lowered it. But we thought it was an appropriate thing to do. So if you think about it, 90 basis points on $5.25 billion, you can probably figure out how much lower the expense would've been. But we think that's the appropriate accounting approach.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: But the biggest effect is the market valuation.
componenttext: But the biggest effect is the market valuation.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: The market. Right. The assets performed very well, over 18% return last year.
componenttext: The market. Right. The assets performed very well, over 18% return last year.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Dana Telsey of Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Dana Telsey of Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the CapEx breakdown and what the buckets that will be there this year. And then also given the cost pressures that are out there, how do you align good, better and best offering and does it change?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the CapEx breakdown and what the buckets that will be there this year. And then also given the cost pressures that are out there, how do you align good, better and best offering and does it change?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: On CapEx, we have a pretty balanced approach. We have a lot of merchandising rollouts with the Mango and Call it Spring and Sephora, as well as center core upgrades. We have a number of large remodels during the year as well. We have a big digital CapEx c
componenttext: On CapEx, we have a pretty balanced approach. We have a lot of merchandising rollouts with the Mango and Call it Spring and Sephora, as well as center core upgrades. We have a number of large remodels during the year as well. We have a big digital CapEx continuing investment. We expect to lead in digital space. We've done so and we want to continue to invest to be in that position in the future. We also have the normal capital investment and maintenance of our stores whether it's air-conditioning and roofing and escalators and so forth. But we believe that the $650 million that we've targeted is the correct investment for the year and balance across those areas. There are only three new stores. As to the good, better, best investments, I don't see a big shift from what we've done in the past. Obviously, to the extent that Mango and Call it Spring and initiatives like this overperformed that would tend to increase our penetration in the upper price points. But we know that of the cadence of our opening price point offers last year served us very well. I think Men's did it the best but Children's and Women's learned from it and our double tables statements have now become extremely successful.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2011

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the JCPenney First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations for JCPenney. Thank you, Ms. Hays. You may begin.
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the JCPenney First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations for JCPenney. Thank you, Ms. Hays. You may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney's  First Quarter Earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone the discussion this morning it was forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Pri
componenttext: Thank you, Rob, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney's  First Quarter Earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone the discussion this morning it was forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and the company's future results of operations could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also please note that no portion of this call maybe rebroadcast in any form without prior written consent to JCPenney. Replay of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after May 16, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. On this morning's call, we will have 2 speakers. First, Mike Ullman, JCPenney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Michael Dastugue, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Now I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. We have a great deal to cover so I'll keep our remarks brief and allow time for your questions. Overall, there are a few main points I'd like to make. First, our ability to deliver on our first quarter o
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. We have a great deal to cover so I'll keep our remarks brief and allow time for your questions. 
Overall, there are a few main points I'd like to make. First, our ability to deliver on our first quarter objectives, in fact, a little bit ahead to the progress we're making in transforming our company from a traditional department store to a retail industry leader. Second, our growth industry initiative performing very well and allowing us to drive the top line of our stores and on www.jcpenney.com. 
We are continuing to build on the accomplishments we set in motion over 18 months ago, which are focused on 4 key areas. First, continuing our style of authority by delivering style credibility for the balance of the best private and national brands. Second, we are delivering memorable customer interactions with highly engaged associates, inspire discovery and build loyalty with our customers. Third, to impact our digital experiences that are personalized and impactful. And fourth, by focusing on driving profitable growth through operational effectiveness. 
Based on actions we have taken to improve store execution, customer service and implement technology to streamline our processes like jTime and door to floor, as well as get out of businesses that are no longer delivering for us, we now have a foundation in place to accelerate a series of initiatives that will maximize operational effectiveness and profitability. Executing on these, which we started in the first quarter, is allowing us to achieve significant cost savings, which will grow in magnitude over the next several years in order to allow us to achieve our 5-year earnings target of $5 per share by 2014. 
So with that, let me give you some highlights of our first quarter. We continue to make significant strides in our style transformation with the opening of
[Audio Gap]
 including Modern Bride and sunglasses, and is anchored by support inside JCPenney. We see substantial upside to increasing our focus on these businesses to continue to increase in sales within our stores, as well as further reinforcing JCPenney as a style destination. 
At the same time, men's continues to drive to deliver strong results building on the momentum we've seen since last Father's Day as our customers are responding well to our new updated, modern merchandising offerings led by Claiborne and J. Ferrar. Children's is also a standout business as moms loved the styles and prices we offer on brands such as Carter's and our own billion dollar brand, Arizona. 
And in home, despite the ongoing softness in the housing market, which continues to impact our Furniture business, we are seeing very good performance in our soft home businesses. As we continue to make our stores more exciting and fun to shop, we remain as dedicated as ever to superior customer service. In addition to great associates, we will also this year, put our leading-edge technology to work with our new markdown and size optimization tools and the reduction of RFID across the number of stores, which will help us stay in stock on these key high SKU merchandise categories that customers are shopping in our stores. 
I also want to quickly mention our new Growth Brands Division. A few weeks ago, we of soft opened the first 10 Foundry Big & Tall Supply company stores, our first business under this new division. The Foundry website launched in April. And in the beginning of May, we opened 6 stores in the Dallas-Fort Worth area and Fort in Kansas City. They carry a broad range of higher end great brands and operating in the Southeast experience design for the Big & Tall customer. Initial response has been terrific. 
Private and Growth brands businesses, the launch in the coming months, CLAD in August and Gifting Grace in September. These digital businesses will allow us to make use of the tremendous merchandising expertise we have in our company and to pursue significant long-term revenue streams. We are also proud to be partnering with the Hearst Corporation on these 2 new ventures. 
During the quarter, customers discovered the great style and price in our private brands typically offered in our good and better price points. This resulted in an AUR being down just 1% for the quarter, which was in line with our expectations. At the same time, transactions were up 10% as our compelling offer to have more customers to JCPenney. 
The areas of success we're seeing in our stores are being mirrored online at JCP.com of 6.6% with the strongest performance coming from men's and children's apparel and women's accessories. JCP.com profitability was impacted by free shipping offers, which impacted the sites' conversion rate in sales. All that aside, the business is gaining momentum and we're confident in our ability to deliver an incremental $1 billion of sales by 2014. 
As should I mention, our sourcing relationships continue to allow us to purchase and manufacture our inventory as price effectively as possible, while protecting our margins, we were able to offer customers many pricing options. National brands that they know and trust at better and best price points, as well as our well-known private brands that offer tremendous style and quality at our good and better price points. We have not found any price adversity from our customers to these merchandise areas as we have raised prices. 
We feel very good about our ability to maintain our smart pricing strategy in the back half of this year accordingly, planned on our 3% to 4% for the season. For 2012, there's still quite a bit of price volatility in the raw materials so it is a little too soon to determine the impact. 
As we work to drive the top line, our focus on significantly improving our expense structure and commitment to operational effectiveness was also very clear in the first quarter and it will only accelerate. A key element to this is tight inventory control, which we were able to execute during the central systems that underlie our business. We ended the quarter with total inventory up 6%. However, only 3.5% is this customer facing at this time. The remaining inventory is underwater, mostly Liz Claiborne product and basics is not comparable. We feel very comfortable that our inventory level as this will allow us to support our growth initiatives as well as improve inventory turn. 
Now turning to how we plan to accelerate operational effectiveness. As mentioned in our press release, we are currently in the second year of executing our 2010-2014 Long Range Plan for growth. And with that, we see opportunity to continue to grow sales by improving sales productivity in our stores and in JCP.com. To continued success of our growth initiatives and exclusive attractions like Liz Claiborne, support inside JCPenney, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring. 
We're also increasing profitability at an accelerated rate by optimizing our expense structure. So with these, we are implementing across the company initiatives that will maximize our operational effectiveness. We began this process about 18 months ago with initiatives like jTime for staffing models in our stores, Door to Floor, the discontinuation of our Catalog Outlet business and moving to enterprisewide inventory, tools like markdown utilization, RFID, implementation of our new digital platform and many, many more. The initial steps we'll take include: reducing our SG&A expense, plan to reduce our SG&A expense an additional $50 million, a portion of which is all even realize in the first quarter and we expect much more to come as we continue to reengineer our business in order to maximize our growth opportunities the next couple of years. We'll inform you more about these actions, which include reducing our gross marketing expenses, streamlining our operations and carrying out further process improvements in our stores and home office when we announce the second quarter results. There's great potential ahead on these fronts. Additionally, we started the restructuring of our supply-chain operations, which we can do based on having an enterprisewide visibility and availability of inventory, and these 2 will deliver a significant annualized cost savings coming on top of those are what we announced to you in January, with the wind down of our catalog business and operations related to that. With that, let me now turn the call over to Michael Dastugue, who will provide the numbers around our business during the quarter

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. On today's call, I will summarize the key components of our performance in the quarter and then talk about our outlook for the second quarter and the remainder of the year. We're feeling confident in our long-te
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. On today's call, I will summarize the key components of our performance in the quarter and then talk about our outlook for the second quarter and the remainder of the year. 
We're feeling confident in our long-term strategies and our execution is better than ever before as the combination of our top line growth initiatives, expense-minded culture and operational initiatives are beginning to deliver measurable results. We told you back in February that the first quarter in 2011 will be our smallest in terms of EPS growth. And while we exceeded our initial guidance and delivered solid results, I'm looking forward to outlining our expectations for the second quarter and beyond. 
The key takeaways for the first quarter were that: we reported $0.28 in EPS exceeding our guidance, merchandising initiatives continue to deliver sales growth, our gross margins were in line with expectations, we effectively managed expenses and launched a number of cost-saving restructuring initiatives, we completed our $900 million share buyback program in May and maintained a strong liquidity position. 
Now let's start with our top line. Driven by the continued success of our growth initiatives, the company's comparable store sales grew 3.8%, an increase for the fifth consecutive quarter and right at the midpoint of our guidance. Total sales for the quarter increased to $3.94 billion. As a percent of sales, gross margins came in line with expectations, decreasing approximately 90 basis points to 40.5% of sales. 
It's worth noting that gross margins generated for merchandise sales in our stores were ahead of plan as our growth initiatives delivered profitable sales as expected. But just as we told you, however, overall gross margins in the first quarter were negatively impacted because we cycled against the profitable tail of our last big one that was still active in the first quarter of 2010. 
We also had free shipping promotions on JCP.com that negatively impacted margins year-over-year. I would like to reiterate that our growth initiatives are not only driving top line growth, but also generating healthy gross profit, which will be more apparent going forward. 
SG&A for the quarter was better than expected at $1.28 billion or 32.5% of sales. Lower SG&A was primarily driven by our marketing optimization and home office expense-savings initiatives, which offset moderate expense increases related to the expansions of supporting inside JCPenney, as well as start-up costs associated with our Growth Plans division. 
As Mike said in his remarks, our expense savings initiatives are expected to reduce our SG&A run rate by over $50 million this year. A portion of this savings was realized in the first quarter with significantly more savings expected over the balance of this year and the next several years. 
Turning back to first quarter results. We reported lower-than-expected interest expense of $58 million in the first quarter. Contrary to our prior expectations, we do not write off the $9 million of capitalized costs related to the $750 million bank line of credit. Given that the facility was increased and all the banks in the old facility are in the new facility, the accounting rules require that we continue amortizing fees over the 5-year term of the new facility. 
To cover a few key balance sheet items, we ended the first quarter with approximately $1.8 billion of cash and short-term investments. And earlier this month, we completed our $900 million share repurchase program. Since March, we repurchased 24.4 million shares at an average price of $36.96. We estimate that the shares repurchased in the first quarter added about $0.01 to the first quarter earnings per share. Our fully completed repurchase will have an accumulative impact of an estimated $0.02 per share in the second quarter and approximately $0.20 for the full year 2011. 
Capital expenditures for the first quarter were $117 million, in line with expectations. And we continue to anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $650 million. As Mike already told you, we are working hard on effectively redesigning our cost structure in order to create a more nimble and profitable organization. To that effect and in addition to significantly reducing streamlining our SG&A expenses, we are completing the wind down of our catalog and outlet operations, which as announced in January, will deliver additional annualized savings of approximately $25 million to $30 million starting in 2012. Also we expect the restructuring of our supply-chain operations will benefit our operating income by about $25 million to $30 million in 2013 with approximately 1/2 of that benefit being achieved in 2012. 
Starting with the $3 million in the first quarter, we will incur charges for accelerated depreciation associated with the facilities we are planning to close, lease termination costs, as well as severance and outplacing services provided to the few hundred associates impacted by the restructuring. Remaining charges are currently estimated as follows: $12 million in the second quarter, $20 million in the second half of 2011 and $15 million over the course of 2012. 
Now let me share with you our few other planning assumptions for the second quarter. We anticipate 3% to 4% growth in comp store sales. The gross margin rate is expected to be relatively flat to slightly up in the second quarter. We are expecting SG&A to leverage and decrease as a percent of sales, even though we are anticipating a slight increase on our SG&A expenses largely due to expenses related to start up at the Growth Plans division. 
Real Estate and others is expected to reflect a net expense of $16 million, which includes $21 million of restructuring charges through that line item. Taking these parameters into account, for the second quarter, earnings, we expect to be in the range of $0.20 to $0.24 per share. To assist you with your modeling, our restructuring and noncomparable items are referred to on Slide 9 of our earnings presentation. For the full year, the company expects 2011 earnings to be in the range of $2.15 to $2.25 per share including the impact of our share repurchase program as well as the restructuring charges. 
In summary, we're off to a great start this year and we are pleased with the progress that we've made and the potential in front of us. Now I'll turn the call back over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I know we've covered a lot today so probably we have to turn the call over to your questions. I'd like to reiterate a few key points. The steps we have taken to improve our merchandising are paying off and have strong potential ahead. Second, based on t
componenttext:
I know we've covered a lot today so probably we have to turn the call over to your questions. I'd like to reiterate a few key points. 
The steps we have taken to improve our merchandising are paying off and have strong potential ahead. Second, based on the steps we have taken to streamline our business and essentially merge our Stores and Online businesses, we have identified areas for significant cost savings that will allow us to translate our sales gains at a much more meaningful bottom-line results. Again, we're committed to excellence in 4 key areas: first, style authority; second, customer interactions; third, digital experiences; and finally, operational effectiveness. 
Our focus on accelerating on our operational effectiveness will allow us to achieve our 2014 earnings target we set out for you last year and move closer to our goal of being a retail industry leader. Operator, please open the line for questions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Deborah Weinswig from Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Deborah Weinswig from Citi.

componenttext: I think that's the way I think about it. The .com piece was where the margin deterioration was and we think much of it was one time. There was a transition from our change in clearance strategies within the end of the quarter and back a bit. But generally, we felt very pleased with the margins we saw in the stores with prehistoric levels.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then transactions up 10%. How much of an impact do you think JCPenney rewards is having and how can you get that new customers or seeing increased transactions from existing customers?
componenttext: And then transactions up 10%. How much of an impact do you think JCPenney rewards is having and how can you get that new customers or seeing increased transactions from existing customers?

componenttextpreview: I think it's a combination of the attractions and JCP people works, I think we've found a good balance in terms of promotional effectiveness in terms of speaking to our existing customers. I think the new attractions particularly Sephora, MNG by Mango and
componenttext: I think it's a combination of the attractions and JCP people works, I think we've found a good balance in terms of promotional effectiveness in terms of speaking to our existing customers. I think the new attractions particularly Sephora, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring, as well as Liz Claiborne. They are attracting new customers and I think we are taking share there. And to the extent the rewards are getting better overtime, we think it's a very important program.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And lastly, on an environment like this, how is your sourcing organization I guess, I would say at even more of a competitive advantage?
componenttext: And lastly, on an environment like this, how is your sourcing organization I guess, I would say at even more of a competitive advantage?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we got ahead of it. We were basically working with our suppliers probably 3 or 4 months for most of our peers. I think we got a sense of what how they could it to mitigate cost increases by events, fabric placements, balancing production. And I th
componenttext: I think we got ahead of it. We were basically working with our suppliers probably 3 or 4 months for most of our peers. I think we got a sense of what how they could it to mitigate cost increases by events, fabric placements, balancing production. And I think we also got on top of price testing very, very, very early in terms of determining price elasticity. We've messaged on this before, but we found the customers were very focused on making sure we didn't change our opening price point offers on key items. But they were open to on the better and best price points, we had no difficulty passing on cost increases that to style and quality warranted. And frankly, some brands increased their prices more aggressively than we did, the gap between their offer and our private brand offers has actually increased, which made ours more attractive.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

componenttextpreview: About $10 million is in the first quarter and we'll obviously get more traction as we get into some of the process improvements. A piece of it was marketing optimization, which will continue quarter-by-quarter. Obviously, there's a balancing act between m
componenttext: About $10 million is in the first quarter and we'll obviously get more traction as we get into some of the process improvements. A piece of it was marketing optimization, which will continue quarter-by-quarter. Obviously, there's a balancing act between making sure that the optimization is taken in such a way that we don't undermine our ability to drive the top line. But frankly, with the discontinuation of the Legacy Catalog business we've been able to rationalize the way we look at all the marketing for the media. So it's a bit of a compass, it's a bit of arithmetic for the next couple of quarters to work our way through the noncomparable aspect of print media.

componenttext: And then on the gross margin, it's sounds as if there was some sort of one time, perhaps give us a sense of how much of the impact is you'll now be lapping when we sort of think about the free shipping. How much of that will continue with us through the remainder of the year versus how much have you lapped and should some of the degradation should alleviate as we progress through the year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me talk first about the lapping the or the discontinuation of Big Book catalogs. I think that is pretty much finished at this point. The first quarter, the last Big Book actually is quite profitable from a rate point of view. But we obviously felt tha
componenttext: Let me talk first about the lapping the or the discontinuation of Big Book catalogs. I think that is pretty much finished at this point. The first quarter, the last Big Book actually is quite profitable from a rate point of view. But we obviously felt that if we continue, it was not going to be profitable so that is a one-time situation. I think that free shipping is a matter of learning what is the best way to manage the top line versus the expense of shipping offers. I think as we transition the merchandise online to meet our store assortments, that will allow us to get better margins. A lot of our inventory online was conservative and traditional merchandise for the catalog shoppers and it's taken us a while to learn exactly how much we're going to be able to liquidate that portion of the demand and replace it with people to shopping in our stores. So it actually progressed quite well in terms of margins throughout the quarter or so we are in a good place and going forward. But I think the shipping issue is really a competitive issue and you got to be out there to be able to deal with what the peers are offering at different points in time.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

componenttextpreview: I think it's fair to say it's a mixed bag based on what the content is obviously and some of the cost impact is much higher than it is in apparel. But we feel very comfortable that costs are up modestly, that by the various merchandising approaches that w
componenttext: I think it's fair to say it's a mixed bag based on what the content is obviously and some of the cost impact is much higher than it is in apparel. But we feel very comfortable that costs are up modestly, that by the various merchandising approaches that we're going to be able to achieve the average price points that we have planned, and accordingly, chose to pick units down relatively in a modest way. We also have backed up and the number of various contingency plans to be able to bring in more units if we find that we've underplanned the units.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great and then in your restructuring of the supply chain operations. What exactly are you working on there? Is it changing the country of origin? Is it changing the way that you plan your inventory? Can you give us a little bit more detail about your plan
componenttext: Great and then in your restructuring of the supply chain operations. What exactly are you working on there? Is it changing the country of origin? Is it changing the way that you plan your inventory? Can you give us a little bit more detail about your plans there?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say we have some Legacy supply-chain facilities to support our catalog and Internet operations together. So we rarely we have 4 complete warehouses that were mirrored in terms of the number of SKUs and the assortments to support those 2 businesses
componenttext: I would say we have some Legacy supply-chain facilities to support our catalog and Internet operations together. So we rarely we have 4 complete warehouses that were mirrored in terms of the number of SKUs and the assortments to support those 2 businesses. As we've gone now to a JCP.com stores, inventory alignment, we've been able to repurpose one of the distribution centers to be no longer as focused on the Direct business so we went down to 3, and we think that will help our inventory turns. It's not necessary to support the business the way we're running it going forward. We're also are able to liquidate some of our .COM clearance back to the stores as opposed to our outlet stores. So it's a sense of taking a fresh look at what our strategy going forward.  For example, right now, we would have to support .com with shoes in all 3 new warehouses and repurposed facilities. And going forward, we now have the systems capability to put all of the category in one warehouse or in 2 warehouse instead of 3. So that will have the effect of more in-stock in a single place to take care of customers but also increase our turn by carrying an average of less inventory overall.

componenttext: And then finally in the slide package, it talks about further SG&A initiatives to drive additional savings. Any idea on the timing or magnitude or I guess, which line items you'd be looking at going forward?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've been very successful at looking at changing the way that we do business as a way of getting out costs. So jTime, which matched our staffing to their customer traffic patterns like time segment, actually, reduced cost substantially across the biggest
componenttext: We've been very successful at looking at changing the way that we do business as a way of getting out costs. So jTime, which matched our staffing to their customer traffic patterns like time segment, actually, reduced cost substantially across the biggest, single expense we have, which is store selling, that our customer service core has actually went up as a result. Another example is Door to Floor, which was to how to get the goods on the selling floor faster and less in the stock room and actually get better visibility when it's coming to the store. So we are looking in a number of areas like that where we believe we'll have the opportunity to improve our performance, at the same time, have lower SG&A. Probably the single biggest opportunities in marketing as I mentioned, we think that we'll get a chunk of that this year, but we'll actually start to accelerate that improvement as we go forward. We have an ongoing lean process going on at the home office to look at ways to better run our business. So it's across a number of categories, no single category will be as big as the marketing category. And our stores selling, as I said has been dramatically improved by jTime, but we'll take another look are there other better ways to organize the way we staff our stores going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

componenttext: Yes I just have a couple questions related to the out cash flow and the outlook I guess in the 2010 2014. But at least, in the near term, Michael, can you -- the payable to inventory ratio dropped that 300 basis points. Can you tell me why, what do you expect that to be for by the end of the year?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think right now, we're in a transition. One, we are building inventory as we migrate from Liz Claiborne, which is a significant brand. We build our inventory there in effect because of the sourcing that's probably one of the biggest drivers. Additi
componenttext: Yes, I think right now, we're in a transition. One, we are building inventory as we migrate from Liz Claiborne, which is a significant brand. We build our inventory there in effect because of the sourcing that's probably one of the biggest drivers. Additionally, it's a private brand as a percent of total growth. We can own that earlier so it's probably the 2 biggest drivers in that. I would suspect by the end of the year we'll have stabilized.

componenttext: I think it's going to be in line with sales.

componenttext: And then maybe you said this and I just missed it, the charges that you expect to occur in '11, how much are cash versus noncash?

componenttextpreview: I would say it's probably 50% to 65% of it is going to be noncash. A lot like, for example, of the $50 million roughly that we are doing in the supply chain over the next 2 years, 2/3 of that is noncash with accelerated depreciation on previously invested
componenttext: I would say it's probably 50% to 65% of it is going to be noncash. A lot like, for example, of the $50 million roughly that we are doing in the supply chain over the next 2 years, 2/3 of that is noncash with accelerated depreciation on previously invested fixed asset.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And my last question, you guys have talked about in the previous plan between 2010 and 2014 about opening 75 stores over that period, most of which would occur in the last couple of years. I'm just wondering, can you and light up the changes that you're g
componenttext: And my last question, you guys have talked about in the previous plan between 2010 and 2014 about opening 75 stores over that period, most of which would occur in the last couple of years. I'm just wondering, can you and light up the changes that you're going through here, can you update us what you think that looks in those outyears and what the CapEx looks in those outyears as well?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you make a good point. Part of our motivation for accelerating our SG&A improvement is the recognition that the Commercial Real Estate market is not as robust as we have planned a year ago. And therefore, we don't think there are as many outmall 1
componenttext: I think you make a good point. Part of our motivation for accelerating our SG&A improvement is the recognition that the Commercial Real Estate market is not as robust as we have planned a year ago. And therefore, we don't think there are as many outmall 100,000 square-foot opportunities in the plan period. I wanted to make sure we make our commitment of $5 a share. We more or less have repurposed our efforts not to get out of new stores but to obviously, try to we forecast the number of with this available to, us including our Books Brands division and taking the necessary actions to improve our expense performance to make up the difference. But I think it's anybody's guess how quickly the Commercial Real Estate business will return. I will say that we are very strongly anchored in the best region regional malls in the country one can certainly argue the regional malls that exist will get stronger because there won't be a lot of new regional malls built. And fortunately, the vast majorities of our stores in these malls have developers that are well-capitalized and are spending money in those malls to improve the atmosphere, the attraction and working with us to make sure that we both have a much stronger offer going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: So would you just for all of our purposes, would you see your CapEx number as you look at the out years would stay at sub$1 billion or about $1 billion or how should we think about that?
componenttext: So would you just for all of our purposes, would you see your CapEx number as you look at the out years would stay at sub$1 billion or about $1 billion or how should we think about that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: We haven't given guidance on CapEx going forward but we are at 650 this year. So that's a mixture of investing in store renovations, investing in new merchandising initiatives, investing in technology and obviously, routine maintenance. Those factors will
componenttext: We haven't given guidance on CapEx going forward but we are at 650 this year. So that's a mixture of investing in store renovations, investing in new merchandising initiatives, investing in technology and obviously, routine maintenance. Those factors will continue going forward. My guess would be that if you have new stores in the mix and possibly a little bit less CapEx in the 5-year plan, we probably envisioned initially. But we have the resources and the, to react should we find opportunities that exceed our growth.

Number 2, can you talk about your expectations for further share repurchase and how does that factor into your $5 earning estimates for 14?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the first one, the second one first. We have not factored in, yes, when we gave you this morning any future share buybacks. Obviously, future share buybacks would actually improve the EPS estimate going forward so it only encompasses the $900
componenttext: I'll answer the first one, the second one first. We have not factored in, yes, when we gave you this morning any future share buybacks. Obviously, future share buybacks would actually improve the EPS estimate going forward so it only encompasses the $900 million which we completed. To your other comment about the amount of marketing expense and its effect on the top line, we consider that relatively competitive information. Clearly, we think that we have an opportunity vis-√†-vis our competitors in terms of the rate that we're spending versus what they're spending, we would like to get more in line with their rate. And essentially, the dollar amounts will fall out there accordingly. We've taken some risk in the first quarter in terms changes in our marketing. And we've learned from those opportunities and we'll continue to learn going forward. I think we will be much smarter after the first year of these optimization actions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

componenttext: In terms of your 2011 EPS outlook, if we back out the one-time charges and if we back out the newly announced $50 million in incremental expense saves, we got the core underlying EPS falling by about $0.06 or $0.07. componenttext: I'm not sure how you got to your math. I think when you take what we previously gave as guidance, we factor in our $900 million buyback, you factor in that we didn't have $35 million for our supply chain previously in our guidance. I'm not sure why we're just how we're disconnected.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we factored all that in. And we're still getting the decline but maybe we can follow-up off-line with that?
componenttext: Yes, we factored all that in. And we're still getting the decline but maybe we can follow-up off-line with that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: To answer your first question is, yes, you're correct.
componenttext: To answer your first question is, yes, you're correct.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our Apparel business was double-digit ahead for the first quarter so we feel already great about customers' response to opening price points, as well as when we took the opportunity to improve pricing on better and best merchandise. So I don't think anybo
componenttext: Our Apparel business was double-digit ahead for the first quarter so we feel already great about customers' response to opening price points, as well as when we took the opportunity to improve pricing on better and best merchandise. So I don't think anybody in their right mind would say we're comfortable with apparel pricing going forward because there's a lot of volatility. Constant comps come down about 30% to 40% over the last several weeks. I think all of us are trying to figure out where it goes from here. I think anyone would be foolish to assume it's going to go back to previous lowest levels so as far planning costs going forward.

componenttext: And on your assumptions for gross margin for the remainder of the year, I guess especially in the back half of the year, can you just talk about our confidence in the environment and your ability to sort of get the increasing gross margins in the back half of the year? Has that proven conservative? Or how does that sort of checked out?

componenttext: That has proven conservative and we still feel very good about achieving our objectives there. At the moment, we are much higher than that.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And on the inventory levels, you talked about sort of customer facing versus noncustomer facing. But clearance levels of inventory year-over-year, how are they coming out of the first quarter?
componenttext: And on the inventory levels, you talked about sort of customer facing versus noncustomer facing. But clearance levels of inventory year-over-year, how are they coming out of the first quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: They're actually quite a bit down. We went through a different clearance cadence a year ago, if you remember. We are now up against the comparable clearance cadence and our clearance is lower, which is actually reflected in lower clearance sales and highe
componenttext: They're actually quite a bit down. We went through a different clearance cadence a year ago, if you remember. We are now up against the comparable clearance cadence and our clearance is lower, which is actually reflected in lower clearance sales and higher promotional sales, which we think is the healthy place to be. Our overall AURs is down about 1% year-to-date. Our AUR and clearance is down slightly but that's a function of Liz's clearances so.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
