headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relati
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations for J. C. Penney. Thank you. Ms. Hays, you may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney's first quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of t
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney's first quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and the company's future results of operations could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also please note that no portion of this call maybe rebroadcast in any form without prior written consent of J. C. Penney. 
Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after May 16, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have 2 speakers: first, Mike Ullman, J. C. Penney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Michael Dastugue, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Now I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. We have a great deal to cover so I'll keep our remarks brief and allow time for your questions. Overall, there are few main points I'd like to make. First, our ability to deliver on our first quarter obj
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. We have a great deal to cover so I'll keep our remarks brief and allow time for your questions. 
Overall, there are few main points I'd like to make. First, our ability to deliver on our first quarter objectives, in fact, come out a little bit ahead, reflects the progress we're making in transforming our company from a traditional department store to a retail industry leader. Second, our growth initiatives are performing very well and allowing us to drive the top line in our stores and on jcp.com. 
We're continuing to build on the accomplishments we set in motion over 18 months ago, which are focused on 4 key areas. First, we're continuing to assert our style authority by delivering great style of credibility for the balance of the best private and national brands. Second, we're delivering memorable customer interactions with the highly engaged associates, who inspire discovery and build loyalty with our customers. Third, through impactful digital experiences that are personalized and tactful. And fourth, by focusing on driving profitable growth through operational effectiveness. 
Based on actions we've taken to improve in-store execution, customer service and implement technology that streamline our processes like jTime and Door to Floor, as well as get out of businesses that are no longer delivering for us, we now have the foundation in place to accelerate a series of initiatives that will maximize operational effectiveness and profitability. Executing on these, which we started in the first quarter, is allowing us to achieve significant cost savings, which will grow in magnitude over the next several years in order to allow us to achieve our 5-year earnings target of $5 per share by 2014. 
So with that, let me give you some highlights of our first quarter. We continue to make significant strides in our style transformation with the opening of 23 new Sephora inside jcpenney locations, 292 MNG by Mango locations, and 100 Call it Spring shops, which in their initial days are seeing the same level of sales productivity per square foot as our Sephora shops. These are among the key growth initiatives of J. C. Penney. that are designed to make our stores and online business more exciting and drive our top line growth. We‚Äôre definitely achieving this in our women‚Äôs business which is a clear area of strength for us this past quarter and outperformed the industry. In fact this business delivered its highest ever per-square- foot sales performance as well as gross profit performance. We‚Äôve seen a strong response to Liz Claiborne which continues to exceed our expectations and very importantly is bringing new shoppers to J. C. Penney. This is a market share we are taking away from others. Several of our private brands including Worthington and one of our billion-dollar private brands, St. Johns Bay are also delivering great performances. Additionally, the steps we‚Äôve taken to drive the productivity of our center core businesses has been very successful. Our center core businesses includes fashion accessories, fashion jewelry, hosiery, handbags, footwear, fine jewelry including Modern Bride, and sunglasses, and is anchored by Sephora inside jcpenney. We see substantial upside to increasing our focus on these businesses to continue increasing the sales per square foot in our stores, as well as further reinforcing J. C. Penney as a style destination. 
At the same time, men's continues to drive -- deliver strong results. Building on the momentum we've seen since last Father's Day, as our customers are responding well to our new updated, modern merchandising offerings led by Claiborne and J. Ferrar. 
Children's is also a standout business. As moms love the styles and prices we offer on brands such as Carter's and our own billion-dollar brand, Arizona. 
And in home, despite the ongoing softness in the housing market, which continues to impact our furniture business, we are seeing very good performance in our soft home businesses. As we continue to make our stores more exciting and fun to shop, we remain as dedicated as ever to superior customer service. In addition to great associates, we will also this year put our leading-edge technology to work with our new markdown and size-optimization tools and the introduction of RFID across the number of stores, which will help us stay in stock on these key high SKU merchandise categories that our customers are shopping in our stores. 
I also want to quickly mention our new Growth Brands Division. A few weeks ago, we have soft-opened the first 10 Foundry Big & Tall Supply Co. stores, our first businesses under this new division. The Foundry website launched in April. And at the beginning of May, we opened 6 stores in Dallas-Fort Worth area and 4 stores in Kansas City. They carry a broad range of higher-end great brands and offer a unique shopping experience designed for just the big & tall customer. The initial response has been terrific. 
Our other 2 Growth Brands businesses that will launch in the coming months, CLAD in August and Gifting Grace in September. These digital businesses will allow us to make use of the tremendous merchandising expertise we have at our company and to pursue a significant long-term revenue streams. We are also proud to be partnering with the Hearst Corporation on these 2 new ventures. 
During the quarter, customers discovered the great style and price of our private brands typically offered at good and better price points. This resulted in AUR being down just 1% for the quarter, which was in line with our expectations. At the same time, transactions were up 10% as our compelling offer to have more customers with J. C. Penney. 
The areas of sales through Internet seeing in our stores are being mirrored online at jcp.com up 6.6% of the quarter, with the strongest performances coming from men's and children's apparel and women's accessories. jcp.com's profitability was impacted by free shipping offers, which impacted the site‚Äôs conversion rate in sales. All that aside, the Internet business is gaining momentum and we're confident in our ability to deliver an incremental $1 billion of sales by 2014. 
I should mention our sourcing relationships continue to allow us to purchase and manufacture inventory as price-effectively as possible. While protecting our margins, we were able to offer customers many pricing options. National brands as they now entrusted better and best price points, as well as our well-known private brands that offer tremendous style and quality at our good and better price points. We have not found any price adversity from our customers to these merchandise areas as we've raised prices. 
We feel very good about our ability to maintain our smart pricing strategy in the back half of this year. Accordingly, we planned down our units [ph] only 3% to 4% for the season. For 2012, there's still quite a bit of price volatility in the raw materials so it's a little too soon to determine the impact. 
As we work to drive the top line, our focus on significantly improving our expense structure and commitment to operational effectiveness was also very clear in the first quarter, and it will only accelerate. A key element to this is tight inventory control, which we were able to execute during -- with essential systems that underlie our business. 
We ended the quarter with total inventory up 6%. However, only 3.5% is customer pacing at this time. Remaining inventories are underwater [ph], mostly consisting of Liz Claiborne product and basics is not comparable. We feel very comfortable with our inventory levels as this will allow us to support our growth initiatives as well as improve inventory turn. 
Now turning to how we plan to accelerate operational effectiveness. As mentioned in our press release, we are currently in the second year of executing our 2010-2014 Long Range Plan for growth. And with that, we see opportunity to continue to grow sales by improving sales productivity in our stores and on jcp.com through the continued success of our growth initiatives and exclusive attractions like Liz Claiborne, Sephora inside jcpenney, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring, while also increasing profitability at an accelerated rate by optimizing our expense structure. 
So with this, we are implementing across the company initiatives that will maximize our operational effectiveness. We began this process about 18 months ago with initiatives like jTime for staffing models in our stores, Door to Floor, the discontinuation of our Catalog and Outlet businesses and moving to enterprise-wide inventory, tools like markdown optimization, RFID, implementation of our new digital platform and many, many more. 
The initial steps we can take include reducing our SG&A expense. This is to re-plan to reduce our SG&A expense an additional of $50 million, a portion of which is already been realized in the first quarter, and we expect much more to come as we continue to re-engineer our business in order to maximize our growth opportunities in the next couple of years. We'll inform you more about these actions, which include reducing our gross marketing expenses, streamlining our operations and carrying out further process improvements in our stores and home office when we announce the second quarter results. There is great potential ahead on these fronts. 
Additionally, we started the restructuring of our supply-chain operations, which we can do based on now having an enterprise-wide visibility and availability of inventory, and these 2 will deliver significant annualized cost savings coming on top of those already announced to you in January, with the wind down of our Catalog business and operations related to that. With that, let me now turn the call over to Michael Dastugue to provide the numbers around our business during the quarter.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. On today's call, I will summarize the key components of our performance in the quarter and then talk about our outlook for the second quarter and the remainder of the year. We're feeling confident in our long-te
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. On today's call, I will summarize the key components of our performance in the quarter and then talk about our outlook for the second quarter and the remainder of the year. 
We're feeling confident in our long-term strategies and our execution is better than ever before as the combination of our top line growth initiatives, expense-minded culture and operational initiatives are beginning to deliver measurable results. We told you back in February that the first quarter of 2011 will be our smallest in terms of EPS growth. And while we exceeded our initial guidance and delivered solid results, I'm looking forward to outlining our expectation for the second quarter and beyond. 
The key takeaways for the first quarter were that we reported $0.28 in EPS exceeding our guidance, merchandising initiatives continue to deliver sales growth, our gross margins were in line with expectations, we effectively managed expenses and launched a number of cost-saving restructuring initiatives, we completed a $900 million share buyback program in May and maintained a strong liquidity position. 
Now let's start with our top line. Driven by the continued success of our growth initiatives, the company's comparable store sales grew 3.8%, an increase for the fifth consecutive quarter and right at the midpoint of our guidance. Total sales for the quarter increased to $3.94 billion. As a percent of sales, gross margins came in line with expectations, decreasing approximately 90 basis points to 40.5% of sales. 
It's worth noting that gross margins generated for merchandise sales in our stores were ahead of plan as our growth initiatives delivered profitable sales as expected. But just as we told you, however, overall gross margins in the first quarter were negatively impacted because we cycled against the profitable tail of our last Big Book that was still active in the first quarter of 2010. 
We also had free shipping promotions on jcp.com that negatively impacted margins year-over-year. I would like to reiterate that our growth initiatives are not only driving top line growth but are also generating healthy gross profit, which will be more apparent going forward. 
SG&A for the quarter was better than expected at $1.28 billion or 32.5% of sales. Lower SG&A was primarily driven by our marketing optimization and home office expense-savings initiatives, which offset moderate expense increases related to the expansions of Sephora inside jcpenney, as well as start-up costs associated with our Growth Brands Division. 
As Mike said in his remarks, our expense savings initiatives are expected to reduce our SG&A run rate by over $50 million this year. A portion of these savings was realized in the first quarter with significantly more savings expected over the balance of this year and the next several years. 
Turning back to first quarter results. We reported lower-than-expected interest expense of $58 million in the first quarter. Contrary to our prior expectations, we do not write off the $9 million of capitalized costs related to the $750 million bank line of credit. Given that the facility was increased and all the banks in the old facility are in the new facility, the accounting rules require that we continue amortizing these fees over the 5-year term of the new facility. 
To cover a few balance sheet items, we ended the first quarter with approximately $1.8 billion of cash and short-term investments. And earlier this month, we completed our $900 million share repurchase program. Since March, we repurchased 24.4 million shares at an average price of $36.96. We estimate that the shares repurchased in the first quarter added about $0.01 to the first quarter earnings per share. Our fully completed repurchase will have accumulative impact of an estimated $0.02 per share in the second quarter and approximately $0.20 for the full year 2011. 
Capital expenditures for the first quarter were $117 million, in line with expectations. And we continue to anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $650 million. As Mike already told you, we are working hard on effectively redesigning our cost structure in order to create a more nimble and profitable organization. To that effect and in addition to significantly reducing and streamlining our SG&A expenses, we are completing the wind down of our catalog and outlet operations, which was announced in January, will deliver additional annualized savings of approximately $25 million to $30 million starting in 2012. Also, we expect the restructuring of our supply-chain operations will benefit our operating income by about $25 million to $30 million in 2013, with approximately 1/2 of that benefit being achieved in 2012. 
Starting with the $3 million in the first quarter, we will incur charges for accelerated depreciation associated with the facilities we are planning to close, lease termination costs, as well as severance and outplacement services provided to the few hundred associates impacted by the restructuring. Remaining charges are currently estimated as follows: $12 million in the second quarter; $20 million in the second half of 2011; and $15 million over the course of 2012. 
Now let me share with you a few other planning assumptions for the second quarter. We anticipate 3% to 4% growth in comp store sales. The gross margin rate is expected to be relatively flat to slightly up in the second quarter. We are expecting SG&A to leverage and decrease as a percent of sales, even though we're anticipating a slight increase on our SG&A expenses largely due to expenses related to the start up of the Growth Brands Division. 
Real Estate and others is expected to reflect a net expense of $16 million, which includes $21 million of restructuring charges going through that line item. Taking these parameters into account to the second quarter earnings, we expect to be in the range of $0.20 to $0.24 per share. To assist you with your modeling, our restructuring and non-comparable items are referred to on Slide 9 of our earnings presentation. 
For the full year, the company expects 2011 earnings to be in the range of $2.15 to $2.25 per share including the impact of our share repurchase program as well as the restructuring charges. 
In summary, we are off to a great start this year and we are pleased with the progress that we've made and the potential in front of us. Now I'll turn the call back over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I know we've covered a lot today so before we turn the call over to your questions, I'd like to reiterate a few key points. The steps we've taken to improve our merchandising are paying off and there‚Äôs strong potential ahead. Second, based on the action
componenttext:
I know we've covered a lot today so before we turn the call over to your questions, I'd like to reiterate a few key points. The steps we've taken to improve our merchandising are paying off and there‚Äôs strong potential ahead. Second, based on the actions we've taken to streamline our business and essentially merge our Stores and Online businesses, we have identified areas for significant cost savings that will allow us to translate our sales gains at a much more meaningful bottom line results. Again, we're committed to excellence in 4 key areas: First, style authority; second, customer interactions; third, digital experiences; and finally, operational effectiveness. 
Our focus on accelerating our operational effectiveness will allow us to achieve our 2014 earnings target we set out for you last year and move closer to our goal of being a retail industry leader. Operator, please open the line for questions.

componenttext: I think it's a combination of the attractions and JCP people works, I think we've found a good balance in terms of promotional effectiveness in terms of speaking to our existing customers. I think the new attractions, particularly Sephora, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring, as well as Liz Claiborne, they are attracting new customers and I think we're taking share there. And to the extent that Rewards going and getting better overtime, we think it's a very important program.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we got ahead of it. We were basically working with our suppliers, probably 3 or 4 monthly from most of our peers. I think we got a sense of what they felt to update to do to mitigate cost increases by advanced fabric placements, balancing producti
componenttext: I think we got ahead of it. We were basically working with our suppliers, probably 3 or 4 monthly from most of our peers. I think we got a sense of what they felt to update to do to mitigate cost increases by advanced fabric placements, balancing production. And I think we also got on top of price testing very, very early in terms of determining the price elasticity. We've messaged this before, but we found that customers were very focused on making sure we didn't change our opening price point offers on key items. But they were open to, on the better and best price points, we had no difficulty passing on cost increases that felt with the style and quality warranted. And frankly, as some brands increased their prices more aggressively than we did, the gap between their offer and our private brand offers actually increased, which made our items more attractive.

componenttext: About $10 million is in the first quarter and it will obviously hit more traction as we get into some of the process improvements. A piece of it was marketing optimization, which will continue quarter-by-quarter. Obviously, there's a balancing act between making sure that the optimization is taken in such a way that we don't undermine our ability to drive the top line. But frankly, with the discontinuation of the Legacy Catalog business, we've been able to rationalize the way we look at all the marketing printed media. So it's a bit of a calculus instead of arithmetic for the next couple of quarters to work our way through the non-comparable aspect of print media.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me talk first about the lapping the or the discontinuation of Big Book catalogs. I think that is pretty much finished at this point, the first quarter. The last Big Book actually was quite profitable from a rate point of view, but we obviously felt th
componenttext: Let me talk first about the lapping the or the discontinuation of Big Book catalogs. I think that is pretty much finished at this point, the first quarter. The last Big Book actually was quite profitable from a rate point of view, but we obviously felt that if we continue, it was not going to be profitable so that is a one-time situation. I think that free shipping is a matter of learning what is the best way to manage the top line versus the expense of shipping offers. I think as we transition the merchandise online to be our store assortments, that will allow us to get better margins. A lot of our inventory online was conservative and traditional merchandise for the catalog shopper and it's taken us a while to learn exactly how much we're going to be able to liquidate that portion of the demand and replace it with people who shop at our stores. So it actually progressed quite well in terms of margins throughout the quarter. So we're in a good place going forward. But I think the shipping issue is really a competitive issue and you got to be out there to be able to deal with what the peers are offering at particular points in time.

componenttext: I think it's fair to say it's a mixed bag based on what the cotton content is obviously and some of the soft [ph] as the cost impact is much higher than these in apparel. But we feel very comfortable that costs, well which are up modestly, that by the various merchandising approaches that we're going to be able to achieve the average price points that we have planned, and accordingly, chose to take the units down relatively modestly. But, we also have backed up number of various contingency plans to be able to bring in more units if we find that we've under-planned the units.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say we have some Legacy supply-chain facilities that support our Catalog and Internet operations together. So we literally had 4 complete warehouses that were mirrored in terms of the number of SKUs and the assortments to support these 2 businesse
componenttext:
I would say we have some Legacy supply-chain facilities that support our Catalog and Internet operations together. So we literally had 4 complete warehouses that were mirrored in terms of the number of SKUs and the assortments to support these 2 businesses. As we've gotten now to a
jcp.com/stores, inventory alignment, we've been able to re-purposed one of its distribution centers to be no longer as focused on the Direct business so we went down to 3, and we think that will help our inventory turns. It's not necessary to support the business the way we're running it going forward. It also, we are able to liquidate some of our .com clearance back to the stores as opposed to our outlet stores. So it's a sense of taking a fresh look at what is our store [ph] strategy going forward. For example, right now, we could support -- we would have to support .com with shoes in all 3 new warehouses or at the re-purposed facilities. And going forward, we now have the systems capability to put all of the category in 1 warehouse or in 2 warehouses instead of 3. So that now will have the effect of being more in-stock in a single place to take care of customers but also increase our turn by carrying an average of less inventory overall.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then finally, in the slide pack, it talks about further SG&A initiatives to drive additional savings. Any idea on the timing or magnitude or I guess, which line items you'd be looking at going forward?
componenttext: Great. And then finally, in the slide pack, it talks about further SG&A initiatives to drive additional savings. Any idea on the timing or magnitude or I guess, which line items you'd be looking at going forward?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've been very successful at looking at changing the way we do business, as a way of getting up costs. So jTime, which matched our staffing to their customer traffic patterns like time segment, actually, reduced costs substantially across the biggest sin
componenttext: We've been very successful at looking at changing the way we do business, as a way of getting up costs. So jTime, which matched our staffing to their customer traffic patterns like time segment, actually, reduced costs substantially across the biggest single expense we have which is store selling, that our customer service core has actually went up as a result. Another example is Door to Floor, which was to how to get the goods onto the selling floor faster and less in the stock room and actually get better visibility while it's coming to the store. So looking at a number of areas like that where we believe we'll have the opportunity to improve our performance, at the same time, have lower SG&A. Probably the single biggest opportunity is in marketing, as I mentioned, we think that we'll get a chunk of that this year, but we'll actually start to accelerate that improvement as we go forward. We have an ongoing lean process going on to the home office to look at ways to better run our business. So it's across the number of categories, no single category would be as big as the marketing category. And our stores selling, as I've said, has been dramatically improved by jTime, but we'll take another look at are there better ways to organize the way we staff our stores going forward.

componenttext: Okay. I'm just wondering, can you, in light up the changes that you're going through here, can you update us what you think that looks in those out-years and what the CapEx looks in those out-years as well?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you made a good point. Part of our motivation for accelerating our SG&A improvement was recognition that commercial real estate market is probably not as robust as we had planned a year ago. And therefore, we don't think there are as many off-mall
componenttext: I think you made a good point. Part of our motivation for accelerating our SG&A improvement was recognition that commercial real estate market is probably not as robust as we had planned a year ago. And therefore, we don't think there are as many off-mall, 100,000 square-foot opportunities in the plan period. I wanted to make sure we made our commitment of $5 a share. We, more or less, re-purposed our efforts not to get out of new stores but to obviously, try to re-forecast the numbers that will be available to us including our Growth Brands Division and our taking the necessary actions to improve our expense performance to make up the difference. But I think it's anybody's guess how quickly the commercial real estate business will return. I will say that since we're very strongly anchored in the best regional malls in the country, one can certainly argue at that regional malls that exist will get stronger because there won't be a larger regional malls built. And fortunately, the vast majority of our stores in these malls who get developers that are well-capitalized and are spending money in those malls to improve the atmosphere, the attraction and working with us to make sure that we both have a much stronger offer going forward.

componenttext: We haven't given guidance on CapEx going forward but it‚Äôs $650 million this year. So that's a mixture of investing in store renovations, investing in new merchandising initiatives, investing in technology and obviously, routine maintenance. Those factors will continue going forward. My guess would be there would be fewer new stores in the mix and possibly a little bit less CapEx in the 5-year plan than we probably envisioned initially. But we have the resources and the where with all to react should we find opportunities that exceed our growth.

Clearly, we think that we have an opportunity vis-√†-vis our competitors in terms of the rate that we're spending versus what they're spending, we would like to get more in line with their rate. And essentially, the dollar amounts will fall out better accordingly. We've taken some risk in the first quarter in terms changes in some of our marketing. And we've learned from those opportunities and we'll continue to learn going forward. I think we'll be much smarter after the first year of these optimization actions.

componenttextpreview: Our Apparel business was double-digit ahead for the first quarter so we felt really great about customers' response to opening price points, as well as when we took the opportunity to improve pricing on better and best merchandise. So we're at -- I don't
componenttext: Our Apparel business was double-digit ahead for the first quarter so we felt really great about customers' response to opening price points, as well as when we took the opportunity to improve pricing on better and best merchandise. So we're at -- I don't think anybody in their right mind would say we're comfortable with apparel pricing going forward because there's a lot of volatility. Cost of cotton has come down about 30% to 40% in the last several weeks. I think all of us are trying to figure out where it goes from here. I think anyone would be foolish to assume it's going to go back to previous lowest levels, so all of us are planning cautiously going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: They're actually quite a bit down. We went through a different clearance cadence a year ago, if you remember. We are now up against the comparable clearance cadence and our clearance is lower, which is actually reflected on lower clearance sales and highe
componenttext: They're actually quite a bit down. We went through a different clearance cadence a year ago, if you remember. We are now up against the comparable clearance cadence and our clearance is lower, which is actually reflected on lower clearance sales and higher promotional sales, which we think is the healthy place to be. Our overall AUR is down about 1% year-to-date. Our AUR and clearance is down slightly but that's a function of less clearance to sell [ph].

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about why do you still anticipate a direct from the Catalog business on the sales line now that you've cycled in and don't expect a detriment from the gross margin perspective?
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about why do you still anticipate a direct from the Catalog business on the sales line now that you've cycled in and don't expect a detriment from the gross margin perspective?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it gets a little complicated but essentially, a good portion of our Catalog business was from older customers buying conservative and traditional merchandise that shows instead of calling in their orders to the call center or sending in a written
componenttext:
Okay. So it gets a little complicated but essentially, a good portion of our Catalog business was from older customers buying conservative and traditional merchandise that shows instead of calling in their orders to the call center or sending in a written form they‚Äôve chosen to enter their order online, that has been reflected in the past in our .com business. It was also reflected in our direct inventory in the warehouse. As we've transitioned the inventory facing the customer to the same inventory that's in the stores by the best amount, there are some specialized businesses online like real goods for children's, cribs and so forth. The vast majority is the same inventory now that's in our stores. So we are up against some non-comparability in the first quarter of inventory levels that essentially had more of a catalog-feel to them than they did stores. But that's gone and that should not be a
non-comparable issue going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And can you talk about your Digital business for the quarter, where that was relative to your expectations? And do you still feel comfortable with your guidance for double-digit growth this year?
componenttext: Great. And can you talk about your Digital business for the quarter, where that was relative to your expectations? And do you still feel comfortable with your guidance for double-digit growth this year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're very encouraged by our Soft Home business which was actually quite good online, which is the biggest portion of our Direct business has been in home, so that was encouraging. And we feel that will continue to contribute going forward. I think t
componenttext: Yes, we're very encouraged by our Soft Home business which was actually quite good online, which is the biggest portion of our Direct business has been in home, so that was encouraging. And we feel that will continue to contribute going forward. I think the area that's been most difficult has been Apparel because it was the one that was the most distorted by the conservative traditional inventory transition. We're now starting to see double-digit increases across all Apparel categories since Apparel is the biggest piece of our business in the stores, and we have about 27 million people that shop in our stores that were not yet shopping online with us because the inventory didn't match what they saw in the stores. We feel confident that we will be back on a growth trajectory. As we've gone through a massive transformation of what .com was when it was with essentially a different customer base. We've said this before but ironically, our oldest customers was our online customer. Our youngest customer was our store customer. So we believe that the customer profiles started to match the store customer as we've transitioned the inventory and as we've updated the functionality on the site.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And could you talk at all about the trends you're seeing in May?
componenttext: Great. And could you talk at all about the trends you're seeing in May?

componenttext: It's a bit early to talk about May. Obviously, Mother's Day and Easter were only 2 weeks apart plus there'd been a number of factors that everybody that‚Äôs selling apparels in facing in terms of the unusual and unseasonable weather that's coming out of first quarter. So it's only the middle of this -- the beginning of the second week of the period so it's probably too early to discuss it.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the marketing, can you just talk about how you're getting smarter in connecting with the customer and still able to deliver the same level of sales with some of the new brands you have coming on? And then also along those lines, is there any c
componenttext: In terms of the marketing, can you just talk about how you're getting smarter in connecting with the customer and still able to deliver the same level of sales with some of the new brands you have coming on? And then also along those lines, is there any changes in the promotional calendar that we should expect in the second quarter? And then lastly, anything in terms of the monthly comp cadence relative to your quarterly expectations for Q2?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. First of all, the customer is always changing in terms of the way they view media and how they are impacted by our offers. So for example, the traditional preprint, that same sort of newspapers 3 or 4 years ago, was by far the vast majority of our sp
componenttext: Yes. First of all, the customer is always changing in terms of the way they view media and how they are impacted by our offers. So for example, the traditional preprint, that same sort of newspapers 3 or 4 years ago, was by far the vast majority of our spend as well as the impact that the customers saw as we trend it's like good piece of our marketing into digital marketing obviously, we sorted exactly how we're using media. So I'd say the biggest single transition has been from preprints, their new insert newspapers although it's still a large part of our program. And the biggest single increase has been in digital media. In terms of the changes in cadence from month-to-month, we wouldn't necessarily message that except to say that we're up against the same calendars a year ago in terms of Father's Day and back-to-school, so I don't see major shifts. I do would say for the last week of July last year was a difficult week for us because we're up against a very large non-comparable clearance event, so my guess is we have a better July than we did a year ago. I would say in terms of -- from a competitive point of view, we intend to continue to be very promotional because that's the nature of our business and that's what the customer expects.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just, I guess lastly, in terms of new brands or new recognizable brands that you've may be bringing into the portfolio, is there anything that you have on the radar that you're looking at over the next 12 to 24 months? And are you looking t
componenttext: And then maybe just, I guess lastly, in terms of new brands or new recognizable brands that you've may be bringing into the portfolio, is there anything that you have on the radar that you're looking at over the next 12 to 24 months? And are you looking to increase the percentage within that private/exclusive label in the store?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: We remain committed to having attractions that bring the modern 18- to 35-year-old customer because we know we're under indexed in that category. And our modern businesses are the fastest-growing businesses we have in the stores. So yes we have other idea
componenttext: We remain committed to having attractions that bring the modern 18- to 35-year-old customer because we know we're under indexed in that category. And our modern businesses are the fastest-growing businesses we have in the stores. So yes we have other ideas and we'll continue to innovate. That's what the customers come to expect. Our scores that we seek from the consumer in terms of that's called the Net Promoter Score in terms of the admirers versus detractors who have gone up double-digit, which says that New Look, New Day, Who Knew messaging is working because when they come to the store, they're finding what they're looking for. People's style wants has helped us a great deal in terms giving style credibility to our assortments. So this is a key strategy, it‚Äôs the #1 item that I mentioned in terms of style authority. So that's where our focus is on new attractions.

componenttext: Okay. So I think, I think I'm there. And then just in terms of the $5 per share goal, I guess when you originally delivered that goal, did you envision this amount of share repurchase? Did you envision sort of these restructuring items? How has the plan sort of evolved? And do you still need a kind of mid-single-digit comps over the planning period to get to that $5?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Probably, the easiest way to think about it is if we assume we haven't changed our comp store growth objective and you assume we've trimmed our expectations out of new store, new footprint, as part of the plan and so we didn't include any share repur
componenttext: Yes. Probably, the easiest way to think about it is if we assume we haven't changed our comp store growth objective and you assume we've trimmed our expectations out of new store, new footprint, as part of the plan and so we didn't include any share repurchase in the EPS estimate, you can assume that we've engineered a process improvement cost take-out to allow us to make $5 a share. Another way of looking at it is we take the 2011 estimate that we have that we'd like to double that in terms of EPS by 2013. So we're not -- this is not something that's all back-end loaded. We expect to get improvement by accelerating our cost focus and our lean and other simplification initiatives.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then my final question. This is something that came up along with Claiborne's call, that was sort of surprising to me, someone asked would they consider selling the brand to you. Would you consider buying the brand out right? Would that b
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then my final question. This is something that came up along with Claiborne's call, that was sort of surprising to me, someone asked would they consider selling the brand to you. Would you consider buying the brand out right? Would that be something that would make sense?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, just to clarify our agreement. Our agreement allows us to acquire the brand after year 5. And once again, have the option to acquire the brand in year 10. And the pricing of that, more or less option, is related to the license income that would be a
componenttext: Well, just to clarify our agreement. Our agreement allows us to acquire the brand after year 5. And once again, have the option to acquire the brand in year 10. And the pricing of that, more or less option, is related to the license income that would be accruing to the Claiborne Corporation for our work together. Out of that license income page was the design element that they provide and we do the rest. So while we have the right to do it at year 5 and year 10, we do not have the absolute right to acquire at other periods of time.

componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then secondly just a little more color on some of the progress you're making in Home? Obviously, your team has been in place for a little over a year now. And last year, you were talking about improvements on how you present merchandise. Obviously in updating the assortments, I'm just wondering if you could give us your sense of what the drivers are in the improvement and then when we might start to see some improvement in the Hard Home areas?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great question. I think in Home and Soft Home, particularly, the real strengths in bedding and bath, as well as the house wares, small electrics and gadgets categories. Our luggage has also been on a great trend. So the core businesses that are attr
componenttext: Okay. Great question. I think in Home and Soft Home, particularly, the real strengths in bedding and bath, as well as the house wares, small electrics and gadgets categories. Our luggage has also been on a great trend. So the core businesses that are attracting the customer on a day-to-day basis are starting to respond. I think there's been a real focus on upgrading the taste levels as well as any more modern cast to the department in terms of the assortments and that's been well-received by customers. I think the real drag at the moment has been on the Hard Home business, particularly Furniture. We're obviously, taking a hard look at the housing industry and trying to figure out how to improve our Furniture business in this environment. There have been some shifts in sales promotions as well as we look at the profitability of these various businesses but we're still quite confident that homes can be a major contributor and the feedback we've gotten from our customer surveys on the assortments, the quality, the offer have all been improving, so we feel like we're on the right track. John Tighe and his team are very focused on building a long-term sustainable profitable business.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our last question today will be coming from the line of Bernard Sosnick with Gilford Securities.
componenttext: Our last question today will be coming from the line of Bernard Sosnick with Gilford Securities.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: With regard to the 2014 sales line, you said that there would probably be fewer new stores contributing to it. But I don't think that you originally included Growth Brands in your forecast, so I'm wondering what that might prove to be as an element of sal
componenttext: With regard to the 2014 sales line, you said that there would probably be fewer new stores contributing to it. But I don't think that you originally included Growth Brands in your forecast, so I'm wondering what that might prove to be as an element of sales growth and what the sales number that you were looking for from the stores might be in 2014? You assumed $1 billion increase from Internet, we know that. Could you clarify the forecast, please?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think -- fair quick question, I think as we look to 70 new large stores in 2014, as I mentioned earlier, our conclusion was given the current commercial real estate market that, that was unlikely. At the time, we have not yet announced our Growth
componenttext: Sure. I think -- fair quick question, I think as we look to 70 new large stores in 2014, as I mentioned earlier, our conclusion was given the current commercial real estate market that, that was unlikely. At the time, we have not yet announced our Growth Brands Division. So one thing to conclude that the Growth Brands Division in 2014 would not be as big as the drop we see in our forecast for large stores. So the difference will be a lower sales expectation in 2014 but maintaining the bottom line EPS forecast, which obviously improves and increase the quality of earnings because sales would not be at the level we have forecasted. We did not change the comp for the 5-year period. So all we're doing is calling out the fact that a year later, we're smarter as to what the current environment is for our new store growth. We have an appetite for new stores when they meet our hurdle rate and when they have sufficient Penney's customers in the market. And in the meantime, we're going to re-invest a lot of our CapEx into merchandise improvements in our stores attractions and renovations, and it will take a while for the Growth Brands group to start to build the kind of sales momentum to be the size of 70 new large stores would be.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: When you compare the Growth Brands to 70 large stores, right now, you don't have the CapEx plan in mind, but would you be thinking that the number of stores would be 1/2 the amount you originally planned or less?
componenttext: When you compare the Growth Brands to 70 large stores, right now, you don't have the CapEx plan in mind, but would you be thinking that the number of stores would be 1/2 the amount you originally planned or less?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bernard, first of all, it's an estimate so I really haven't changed the estimate except to say that we  don't feel comfortable we can find 70 that would hit our hurdle rate. Those new communities there and where all the new housing was being developed in
componenttext: Bernard, first of all, it's an estimate so I really haven't changed the estimate except to say that we  don't feel comfortable we can find 70 that would hit our hurdle rate. Those new communities there and where all the new housing was being developed in '06, '07, and early '08, those communities are not building houses in those communities today and we've taken a look at other formats. But at this point, we think the prudent thing to do is to streamline our cost structure so we can achieve the same bottom line without having to reach into less profitable opportunities on the CapEx side. So you're quite correct that we don't have a CapEx budget for 2014 at this point except to say by have -- building fewer large new stores, we'll have more resources to allocate to other ways of growing the business.

componenttext: I don't have difficulty getting to your EPS number. I was just wondering how to model the top line.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relati
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations for J. C. Penney. Thank you. Ms. Hays, you may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney's first quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of t
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney's first quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and the company's future results of operations could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also please note that no portion of this call may be rebroadcast in any form without prior written consent of J. C. Penney. 
Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after May 16, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have 2 speakers: first, Mike Ullman, J. C. Penney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Michael Dastugue, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Now I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. We have a great deal to cover so I'll keep our remarks brief and allow time for your questions. Overall, there are a few main points I'd like to make. First, our ability to deliver on our first quarter o
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. We have a great deal to cover so I'll keep our remarks brief and allow time for your questions. 
Overall, there are a few main points I'd like to make. First, our ability to deliver on our first quarter objectives, in fact, come out a little bit ahead, reflects the progress we're making in transforming our company from a traditional department store to a retail industry leader. Second, our growth initiatives are performing very well and allowing us to drive the top line in our stores and on jcp.com. 
We're continuing to build on the accomplishments we set in motion over 18 months ago, which are focused on 4 key areas: First, we're continuing to assert our style authority by delivering great style of credibility for the balance of the best private and national brands; second, we're delivering memorable customer interactions with the highly engaged associates, who inspire discovery and build loyalty with our customers; third, through impactful digital experiences that are personalized and impactful; and fourth, by focusing on driving profitable growth through operational effectiveness. 
Based on actions we've taken to improve in-store execution, customer service and implement technology that streamline our processes like jTime and Door to Floor, as well as get out of businesses that are no longer delivering for us, we now have the foundation in place to accelerate a series of initiatives that will maximize operational effectiveness and profitability. Executing on these, which we started in the first quarter, is allowing us to achieve significant cost savings, which will grow in magnitude over the next several years in order to allow us to achieve our 5-year earnings target of $5 a share by 2014. 
So with that, let me give you some highlights of our first quarter. We continue to make significant strides in our style transformation with the opening of 23 new Sephora inside jcpenney locations, 292 MNG by Mango locations, and 100 Call it Spring shops, which in their initial days are seeing the same level of sales productivity per square foot as our Sephora shops. These are among the key growth initiatives of J. C. Penney. that are designed to make our stores and online business more exciting and drive our top line growth. We‚Äôre definitely achieving this in our women‚Äôs business which is a clear area of strength for us this past quarter and outperformed the industry. In fact this business delivered its highest ever first quarter store sales performance as well as gross profit performance. We‚Äôve seen a strong response to Liz Claiborne which continues to exceed our expectations and very importantly is bringing new shoppers to J. C. Penney. This is a market share we are taking away from others. Several of our private brands including Worthington and one of our billion-dollar private brands, St. Johns Bay are also delivering great performances. Additionally, the steps we‚Äôve taken to drive the productivity of our center core businesses has been very successful. Our center core businesses include fashion accessories, fashion jewelry, hosiery, handbags, footwear, fine jewelry including Modern Bride, and sunglasses, and is anchored by Sephora inside jcpenney. We see substantial upside to increasing our focus on these businesses to continue increasing the sales per square foot in our stores, as well as further reinforcing J. C. Penney as a style destination. 
At the same time, men's continues to drive -- deliver strong results. Building on the momentum we've seen since last Father's Day, as our customers are responding well to our new updated, modern merchandising offerings led by Claiborne and J. Ferrar. 
Children's is also a standout business. As moms love the styles and prices we offer on brands such as Carter's and our own billion-dollar brand, Arizona. 
And in home, despite the ongoing softness in the housing market, which continues to impact our furniture business, we are seeing very good performance in our soft home businesses. As we continue to make our stores more exciting and fun to shop, we remain as dedicated as ever to superior customer service. In addition to great associates, we will also this year put our leading-edge technology to work with our new markdown and size-optimization tools and the introduction of RFID across a number of stores, which will help us stay in stock on these key high SKU merchandise categories that our customers are shopping in our stores. 
I also want to quickly mention our new Growth Brands Division. A few weeks ago, we soft-opened the first 10 Foundry Big & Tall Supply Co. stores, our first businesses under this new division. The Foundry website launched in April. And at the beginning of May, we opened 6 stores in Dallas-Fort Worth area and 4 stores in Kansas City. They carry a broad range of higher-end great brands and offer a unique shopping experience designed for just the big & tall customer. The initial response has been terrific. 
Our other 2 Growth Brands businesses will launch in the coming months, CLAD in August and Gifting Grace in September. These digital businesses will allow us to make use of the tremendous merchandising expertise we have at our company and to pursue significant long-term revenue streams. We are also proud to be partnering with the Hearst Corporation on these 2 new ventures. 
During the quarter, customers discovered the great style and price of our private brands typically offered at our good and better price points. This resulted in AUR being down just 1% for the quarter, which was in line with our expectations. At the same time, transactions were up 10% as our compelling offer drove more customers to J. C. Penney. 
The areas of success that we're seeing in our stores are being mirrored online at jcp.com, up 6.6% for the quarter, with the strongest performances coming from men's and children's apparel and women's accessories. jcp.com's profitability was impacted by free shipping offers, which impacted the site‚Äôs conversion rate in sales. All that aside, our Internet business is gaining momentum and we're confident in our ability to deliver an incremental $1 billion of sales by 2014. 
I should mention our sourcing relationships continue to allow us to purchase and manufacture inventory as price-effectively as possible. While protecting our margins, we were able to offer customers many pricing options; national brands that they know and trust at better and best price points, as well as our well-known private brands that offer tremendous style and quality at our good and better price points. We have not found any price adversity from our customers to these merchandise areas as we've raised prices. 
We feel very good about our ability to maintain our smart pricing strategy in the back half of this year. Accordingly, we planned down our units only 3% to 4% for the season. For 2012, there's still quite a bit of price volatility in the raw materials so it's a little too soon to determine the impact. 
As we work to drive the top line, our focus on significantly improving our expense structure and commitment to operational effectiveness was also very clear in the first quarter, and it will only accelerate. A key element to this is tight inventory control, which we were able to execute during -- with essential systems that underlie our business. 
We ended the quarter with total inventory up 6%. However, only 3.5% of it is customer pacing at this time. The remaining inventory is on the water, mostly consisting of Liz Claiborne product and basics, that is not comparable. We feel very comfortable with our inventory levels as this will allow us to support our growth initiatives as well as improve inventory turn. 
Now turning to how we plan to accelerate our operational effectiveness. As mentioned in our press release, we are currently in the second year of executing our 2010-2014 Long Range Plan for growth. And with that, we see opportunity to continue to grow sales by improving sales productivity in our stores and on jcp.com through the continued success of our growth initiatives and exclusive attractions like Liz Claiborne, Sephora inside jcpenney, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring, while also increasing profitability at an accelerated rate by optimizing our expense structure. 
So with this, we are implementing across the company initiatives that will maximize our operational effectiveness. We began this process about 18 months ago with initiatives like jTime for staffing models in our stores, Door to Floor, the discontinuation of our Catalog and Outlet businesses and moving to enterprise-wide inventory, tools like markdown optimization, RFID, implementation of our new digital platform and many, many more. 
The initial steps we'll take include reducing our SG&A expense. This year we plan to reduce our SG&A expense an additional $50 million, a portion of which has already been realized in the first quarter, and we expect much more to come as we continue to re-engineer our business in order to maximize our growth opportunities in the next several years. We'll inform you more about these actions, which include reducing our gross marketing expenses, streamlining our operations and carrying out further process improvements in our stores and home office when we announce the second quarter results. There is great potential ahead on these fronts. 
Additionally, we started the restructuring of our supply-chain operations, which we can do based on now having an enterprise-wide visibility and availability of inventory, and this, too, will deliver significant annualized cost savings coming on top of those already announced to you in January, with the wind down of our Catalog business and operations related to that. With that, let me now turn the call over to Michael Dastugue to provide the numbers around our business during the quarter.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. On today's call, I will summarize the key components of our performance in the quarter and then talk about our outlook for the second quarter and the remainder of the year. We're feeling confident in our long-te
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. On today's call, I will summarize the key components of our performance in the quarter and then talk about our outlook for the second quarter and the remainder of the year. 
We're feeling confident in our long-term strategies and our execution is better than ever before as the combination of our top line growth initiatives, expense-minded culture and operational initiatives are beginning to deliver measurable results. We told you back in February that the first quarter of 2011 will be our smallest in terms of EPS growth. And while we exceeded our initial guidance and delivered solid results, I'm looking forward to outlining our expectation for the second quarter and beyond. 
The key takeaways for the first quarter were that we reported $0.28 in EPS exceeding our guidance, merchandising initiatives continued to deliver sales growth, our gross margins were in line with expectations, we effectively managed expenses and launched a number of cost-saving restructuring initiatives, we completed a $900 million share buyback program in May and maintained a strong liquidity position. 
Now let's start with our top line. Driven by the continued success of our growth initiatives, the company's comparable store sales grew 3.8%, an increase for the fifth consecutive quarter and right in the midpoint of our guidance. Total sales for the quarter increased to $3.94 billion. As a percent of sales, gross margins came in line with expectations, decreasing approximately 90 basis points to 40.5% of sales. 
It's worth noting that gross margins generated for merchandise sales in our stores were ahead of plan as our growth initiatives delivered profitable sales as expected. But just as we told you, however, overall gross margins in the first quarter were negatively impacted because we cycled against the profitable tail of our last Big Book that was still active in the first quarter of 2010. 
We also had free shipping promotions on jcp.com that negatively impacted margins year-over-year. I would like to reiterate that our growth initiatives are not only driving top line growth but are also generating healthy gross profit, which will be more apparent going forward. 
SG&A for the quarter was better than expected at $1.28 billion or 32.5% of sales. Lower SG&A was primarily driven by our marketing optimization and home office expense-savings initiatives, which offset moderate expense increases related to the expansion of Sephora inside jcpenney, as well as start-up costs associated with our Growth Brands Division. 
As Mike said in his remarks, our expense savings initiatives are expected to reduce our SG&A run rate by over $50 million this year. A portion of these savings was realized in the first quarter with significantly more savings expected over the balance of this year and the next several years. 
Turning back to first quarter results. We reported lower-than-expected interest expense of $58 million in the first quarter. Contrary to our prior expectations, we did not write off the $9 million of capitalized costs related to the $750 million bank line of credit. Given that the facility was increased and all the banks in the old facility are in the new facility, the accounting rules require that we continue amortizing these fees over the 5-year term of the new facility. 
To cover a few balance sheet items, we ended the first quarter with approximately $1.8 billion in cash and short-term investments. And earlier this month, we completed our $900 million share repurchase program. Since March, we repurchased 24.4 million shares at an average price of $36.96. We estimate that the shares repurchased in the first quarter added about $0.01 to the first quarter earnings per share. Our fully completed repurchase will have a cumulative impact of an estimated $0.02 per share in the second quarter and approximately $0.20 for the full year 2011. 
Capital expenditures for the first quarter were $117 million, in line with expectations. And we continue to anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $650 million. As Mike already told you, we are working hard on effectively redesigning our cost structure in order to create a more nimble and profitable organization. To that effect and in addition to significantly reducing and streamlining our SG&A expenses, we are completing the wind down of our catalog and outlet operations, which as announced in January, will deliver additional annualized savings of approximately $25 million to $30 million starting in 2012. Also, we expect the restructuring of our supply-chain operations will benefit our operating income by about $25 million to $30 million in 2013, with approximately half of that benefit being achieved in 2012. 
Starting with the $3 million in the first quarter, we will incur charges for accelerated depreciation associated with the facilities we are planning to close, lease termination cost, as well as severance and outplacement services provided to the few hundred associates impacted by the restructuring. Remaining charges are currently estimated as follows: $12 million in the second quarter; $20 million in the second half of 2011; and $15 million over the course of 2012. 
Now let me share with you a few other planning assumptions for the second quarter. We anticipate 3% to 4% growth in comp store sales. The gross margin rate is expected to be relatively flat to slightly up in the second quarter. We are expecting SG&A to leverage and decrease as a percent of sales, even though we're anticipating a slight increase in our SG&A expenses largely due to expenses related to the startup of the Growth Brands Division. 
Real Estate and Other is expected to reflect a net expense of $16 million, which includes $21 million of restructuring charges going through that line item. Taking these parameters into account for the second quarter earnings, we expect to be in the range of $0.20 to $0.24 per share. To assist you with your modeling, our restructuring and non-comparable items are referred to on Slide 9 of our earnings presentation. 
For the full year, the company expects 2011 earnings to be in the range of $2.15 to $2.25 per share including the impact of our share repurchase program as well as the restructuring charges. 
In summary, we are off to a great start this year and we are pleased with the progress that we've made and the potential in front of us. Now I'll turn the call back over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: We know we've covered a lot today so before we turn the call over for your questions, I'd like to reiterate a few key points. The steps we've taken to improve our merchandising are paying off and there‚Äôs strong potential ahead. Second, based on the acti
componenttext:
We know we've covered a lot today so before we turn the call over for your questions, I'd like to reiterate a few key points. The steps we've taken to improve our merchandising are paying off and there‚Äôs strong potential ahead. Second, based on the actions we've taken to streamline our business and essentially merge our Stores and Online businesses, we have identified areas for significant cost savings that will allow us to translate our sales gains into much more meaningful bottom line results. Again, we're committed to excellence in 4 key areas: First, style authority; second, customer interactions; third, digital experiences; and finally, operational effectiveness. 
Our focus on accelerating our operational effectiveness will allow us to achieve our 2014 earnings target we set out for you last year and move closer to our goal of being a retail industry leader. Operator, please open the line for questions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Deborah Weinswig of Citi. [Citigroup Inc.]
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Deborah Weinswig of Citi. [Citigroup Inc.]

componenttextpreview: I think that's the way I think about it. The dotcom piece was where the margin deterioration was and we think much of it was one time. There was a transition from our change in clearance strategies which is at the beginning of the quarter which impacted a
componenttext: I think that's the way I think about it. The dotcom piece was where the margin deterioration was and we think much of it was one time. There was a transition from our change in clearance strategies which is at the beginning of the quarter which impacted a bit. But generally, we felt very pleased with the margins in the stores which were at historic levels.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then transactions up 10%. How much of an impact do you think JCPenney Rewards is having and do you think that, that's new customers or seeing increased transactions from existing customers?
componenttext: Okay. And then transactions up 10%. How much of an impact do you think JCPenney Rewards is having and do you think that, that's new customers or seeing increased transactions from existing customers?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's a combination of the attractions and JCP Rewards, I think we've found a good balance in terms of promotional effectiveness in terms of speaking to our existing customers. But I think the new attractions, particularly Sephora, MNG by Mango and
componenttext: I think it's a combination of the attractions and JCP Rewards, I think we've found a good balance in terms of promotional effectiveness in terms of speaking to our existing customers. But I think the new attractions, particularly Sephora, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring, as well as Liz Claiborne, they are attracting new customers and I think we're taking share there. And to the extent that Rewards will only get better over time, we think it's a very important program.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, in an environment like this, how is your sourcing organization, I guess I would say, even more of a competitive advantage?
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, in an environment like this, how is your sourcing organization, I guess I would say, even more of a competitive advantage?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we got ahead of it. We were basically working with our suppliers, probably 3 or 4 months before most of our peers. I think we got a sense of what they felt they could do to mitigate cost increases by advanced fabric placements, balancing productio
componenttext: I think we got ahead of it. We were basically working with our suppliers, probably 3 or 4 months before most of our peers. I think we got a sense of what they felt they could do to mitigate cost increases by advanced fabric placements, balancing production. And I think we also got on top of price testing very, very early in terms of determining the price elasticity. We've messaged this before, but we found that customers were very focused on making sure we didn't change our opening price point offers on key items. But they were open to, on the better and best price points, we had no difficulty passing on cost increases they felt that the style and quality warranted. And frankly, as some brands increased their prices more aggressively than we did, the gap between their offer and our private brand offers actually increased, which made our items more attractive.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

componenttext: Mike, could you just help us on the $50 million on expense savings you called out a portion was recognized in Q1. Could you be a little bit more specific in terms of how much was recognized in Q1 and perhaps help us think through the cadence through the remainder of the year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: About $10 million was in the first quarter and it will obviously get more traction as we get into some of the process improvements. A piece of it was marketing optimization, which will continue quarter-by-quarter. Obviously, there's a balancing act betwee
componenttext: About $10 million was in the first quarter and it will obviously get more traction as we get into some of the process improvements. A piece of it was marketing optimization, which will continue quarter-by-quarter. Obviously, there's a balancing act between making sure that the optimization is taken in such a way that we don't undermine our ability to drive the top line. But frankly, with the discontinuation of the Legacy Catalog business, we've been able to rationalize the way we look at all the marketing printed media. So it's a bit of calculus instead of arithmetic for the next couple quarters to work our way through the non-comparable aspect of print media.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it sounds that it's still more back-end loaded in terms of the benefits, the remainder?
componenttext: Okay. So it sounds that it's still more back-end loaded in terms of the benefits, the remainder?
