componenttext: I think our benefits will increase over time, not just this year but throughout the next 3 years.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the gross margin, it sounds as if there was some sort of one-time -- perhaps give us a sense of how much of the impact is -- you'll now be lapping and so when we think about the free shipping, how much of that will continue with us as fo
componenttext: Okay. And then on the gross margin, it sounds as if there was some sort of one-time -- perhaps give us a sense of how much of the impact is -- you'll now be lapping and so when we think about the free shipping, how much of that will continue with us as for the remainder of the year versus how much have you lapped and should -- some of the degradation should alleviate as we progress through the year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me talk first about the lapping the -- or the discontinuation of Big Book catalogs. I think that is pretty much finished at this point, the first quarter. The last Big Book actually was quite profitable from a rate point of view, but we obviously felt
componenttext: Let me talk first about the lapping the -- or the discontinuation of Big Book catalogs. I think that is pretty much finished at this point, the first quarter. The last Big Book actually was quite profitable from a rate point of view, but we obviously felt that if we continued, it was not going to be profitable so that is a one-time situation. I think that free shipping is a matter of learning what is the best way to manage the top line versus the expense of shipping offers. I think that as we transition the merchandise online to be our store assortments, that will allow us to get better margins. A lot of our inventory online was conservative and traditional merchandise for the catalog shopper and it's taken us a while to learn exactly how much we're going to be able to liquidate that portion of the demand and replace it with people that are shopping at our stores. So it actually progressed quite well in terms of margins throughout the quarter. So we feel we're in a good place going forward. Because I think the shipping issue is really a competitive issue and you've got to be out there to be able to deal with what the peers are offering at particular points in time.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just my final 2 questions, obviously, very aggressive buyback in the first quarter. Any updates in terms of future plans for the remainder of the year?
componenttext: Okay. And then just my final 2 questions, obviously, very aggressive buyback in the first quarter. Any updates in terms of future plans for the remainder of the year?

componenttext: No, that's something the board obviously deals with on a case-by-case basis. The good news is we have very strong financial position and have important choices that we can make.

Are we thinking about that correctly that the upward revision doesn't fully capture the $50 million in cost savings yet?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Adrianne, this is Michael. I think you got to remember, you're correct, it does include the stock buyback. But it also includes $35 million that wasn't in the original guidance related to our supply chain restructuring. So those one-time costs are al
componenttext: Yes. Adrianne, this is Michael. I think you got to remember, you're correct, it does include the stock buyback. But it also includes $35 million that wasn't in the original guidance related to our supply chain restructuring. So those one-time costs are also factored in the new guidance.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike, you discussed buying units down 3% to 4% in the back half. What are you seeing on the costing front for your back half unit purchases?
componenttext: Mike, you discussed buying units down 3% to 4% in the back half. What are you seeing on the costing front for your back half unit purchases?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's fair to say it's a mixed bag based on what the cotton content is. Obviously, in some of the soft home areas, the cost impact is much higher than it is in apparel. But we feel very comfortable that while costs are up modestly, that by th
componenttext: Well, I think it's fair to say it's a mixed bag based on what the cotton content is. Obviously, in some of the soft home areas, the cost impact is much higher than it is in apparel. But we feel very comfortable that while costs are up modestly, that by the various merchandising approaches that we're going to be able to achieve the average price points that we have planned, and accordingly, chose to take the units down relatively modestly. But we also have backed up, in a number of areas have contingency plans to be able to bring in more units if we find that we've under-planned the units.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then your restructuring of the supply chain operations. What exactly are you working on there? Is it changing the country of origin? Is it changing the way that you plan your inventory? Can you give us a little bit more detail about your plans
componenttext: Great. And then your restructuring of the supply chain operations. What exactly are you working on there? Is it changing the country of origin? Is it changing the way that you plan your inventory? Can you give us a little bit more detail about your plans there?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say we have some Legacy supply-chain facilities that support our Catalog and Internet operations together. So we literally had 4 complete warehouses that were mirrored in terms of the number of SKUs and the assortments to support those 2 businesse
componenttext: I would say we have some Legacy supply-chain facilities that support our Catalog and Internet operations together. So we literally had 4 complete warehouses that were mirrored in terms of the number of SKUs and the assortments to support those 2 businesses. As we've gone now to a jcp.com/stores inventory alignment, we've been able to re-purpose one of the distribution centers to be no longer as focused on the Direct business so we went down to 3, and we think that will help our inventory turns. It's not necessary to support the business the way we're running it going forward. It also, we are able to liquidate some of our .com clearance back through the stores as opposed to our outlet stores. So it's a sense of taking a fresh look at what is our strategy going forward. For example, right now, we could support -- we would have to support .com with shoes in all 3 new warehouses or at the re-purposed facilities. And going forward, we now have the systems capability to put all of a category in 1 warehouse or in 2 warehouses instead of 3. So that now will have the effect of being more in-stock in a single place to take care of customers but also increase our turn by carrying an average of less inventory overall.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then finally, in the slide pack, it talks about further SG&A initiatives to drive additional savings. Any idea on the timing or magnitude or I guess, which line items you'd be looking at going forward?
componenttext: Great. And then finally, in the slide pack, it talks about further SG&A initiatives to drive additional savings. Any idea on the timing or magnitude or I guess, which line items you'd be looking at going forward?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've been very successful at looking at changing the way we do business, as a way of getting out costs. So jTime, which matched our staffing to their customer traffic patterns by time segment, actually reduced costs substantially across the biggest singl
componenttext: We've been very successful at looking at changing the way we do business, as a way of getting out costs. So jTime, which matched our staffing to their customer traffic patterns by time segment, actually reduced costs substantially across the biggest single expense we have which is store selling, that our customer service scores actually went up as a result. Another example is Door to Floor, which was to how to get the goods onto the selling floor faster and less in the stock room and actually get better visibility of what was coming to the store. So we're looking at a number of areas like that where we believe we'll have the opportunity to improve our performance, at the same time, have lower SG&A. Probably the single biggest opportunity is in marketing, as I mentioned. We think that we'll get a chunk of that this year, but we'll actually start to accelerate that improvement as we go forward. We have an ongoing lean process going on at the home office to look at ways to better run our business. So it's across the number of categories, no single category would be as big as the marketing category. And our store selling, as I said, has been dramatically improved by jTime, but we'll take another look at are there better ways to organize the way we staff our stores going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think right now, you're -- we're in transition. One, we were building inventory as we migrate from Liz Claiborne, which is a significant brand. We build our inventory there in effect because of the sourcing, that's probably one of the biggest drive
componenttext: Yes. I think right now, you're -- we're in transition. One, we were building inventory as we migrate from Liz Claiborne, which is a significant brand. We build our inventory there in effect because of the sourcing, that's probably one of the biggest drivers. Additionally, as our private brand as a percent of total grow, we tend to own that earlier. And so those are probably the 2 biggest drivers of that. I would suspect by the end of the year, we'll kind of stabilize.

componenttext: I think it's going to be in line with sales.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe, you said this and I just missed it, the charges that you expect to occur in '11, how much are cash versus non-cash?
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe, you said this and I just missed it, the charges that you expect to occur in '11, how much are cash versus non-cash?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say, it's probably 50% to 65% of it is going to be non-cash. A lot like, for example, of the $50 million roughly that we're doing in supply chain over the next 2 years, 2/3 of that is non-cash; it's accelerating depreciation on previous fixed asse
componenttext: I would say, it's probably 50% to 65% of it is going to be non-cash. A lot like, for example, of the $50 million roughly that we're doing in supply chain over the next 2 years, 2/3 of that is non-cash; it's accelerating depreciation on previous fixed assets -- previously invested fixed assets.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my last question, you guys have talked about in the previous plan between 2010 and 2014 about opening 75 stores over that period, most of which would occur in the last couple of years. I'm just wondering, can you, in light of the changes that yo
componenttext: Okay. And my last question, you guys have talked about in the previous plan between 2010 and 2014 about opening 75 stores over that period, most of which would occur in the last couple of years. I'm just wondering, can you, in light of the changes that you're going through here, can you update us what you think that looks in those out-years and what the CapEx looks in those out-years as well?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you make a good point. Part of our motivation for accelerating our SG&A improvement was the recognition that the commercial real estate market is probably not as robust as we had planned a year ago. And therefore, we don't think there are as
componenttext: Yes, I think you make a good point. Part of our motivation for accelerating our SG&A improvement was the recognition that the commercial real estate market is probably not as robust as we had planned a year ago. And therefore, we don't think there are as many off-mall, 100,000 square-foot opportunities in the plan period. Wanting to make sure we made our commitment of $5 a share. We, more or less, re-purposed our efforts not to get out of new stores but to obviously, try to re-forecast the numbers that will be available to us including our Growth Brands Division and our taking the necessary actions to improve our expense performance to make up the difference. But I think it's anybody's guess how quickly the commercial real estate business will return. I will say that since we're very strongly anchored in the best regional malls in the country, one can certainly argue that the regional malls that exist will get stronger because there won't be a lot of new regional malls built. And fortunately, the vast majority of our stores in those malls are with developers that are well-capitalized and are spending money in those malls to improve the atmosphere, the attraction and working with us to make sure that we both have a much stronger offer going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: So would you -- just for all of our purposes, would you see your CapEx number as you look in the out-years would stay sub-$1 billion or about $1 billion or how should we think about that?
componenttext: So would you -- just for all of our purposes, would you see your CapEx number as you look in the out-years would stay sub-$1 billion or about $1 billion or how should we think about that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: We haven't given guidance on CapEx going forward but we're at $650 million this year. So that's a mixture of investing in store renovations, investing in new merchandising initiatives, investing in technology and obviously, routine maintenance. Those fact
componenttext: We haven't given guidance on CapEx going forward but we're at $650 million this year. So that's a mixture of investing in store renovations, investing in new merchandising initiatives, investing in technology and obviously, routine maintenance. Those factors will continue going forward. My guess would be there would be fewer new stores in the mix and possibly a little bit less CapEx in the 5-year plan than we probably envisioned initially. But we have the resources and the wherewithal to react should we find opportunities that exceed our growth.

componenttext: Can you be a little bit more specific about how much advertising expense you expect to eliminate over the next couple years and what you think the offset is for the top line? Number 2, can you talk about your expectations for further share repurchase and how does that factor into your $5 earning estimate for '14?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll answer the first one -- the second one first. We have not factored in, in the estimate we gave you this morning any future share buybacks. Obviously, future share buybacks would actually improve the EPS estimate going forward so it only encompas
componenttext: Yes. I'll answer the first one -- the second one first. We have not factored in, in the estimate we gave you this morning any future share buybacks. Obviously, future share buybacks would actually improve the EPS estimate going forward so it only encompasses the $900 million we just completed. To your other comment about the amount of marketing expenses and its effect on the top line, we consider that relatively competitive information. Clearly, we think that we have an opportunity vis-√†-vis our competitors in terms of the rate that we're spending versus what they're spending; we would like to get more in line with their rate. And essentially, the dollar amounts will fall out accordingly. We've taken some risk in the first quarter in terms changing some of our marketing, and we've learned from those opportunities and we'll continue to learn going forward. I think we'll be much smarter after the first year of these optimization actions.

componenttext: I don't -- I'm not sure how you got to your math. headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our Apparel business was double-digit ahead for the first quarter so we felt really great about customers' response to opening price points, as well as when we took the opportunity to improve pricing on better and best merchandise. So we're not -- I don't
componenttext: Our Apparel business was double-digit ahead for the first quarter so we felt really great about customers' response to opening price points, as well as when we took the opportunity to improve pricing on better and best merchandise. So we're not -- I don't think anybody in their right mind would say we're comfortable with apparel pricing going forward because there's a lot of volatility. Cost of cotton has come down about 30% to 40% in the last several weeks. I think all of us are trying to figure out where it goes from here. I think anyone would be foolish to assume it's going to go back to previous lowest levels, so all of us are planning cautiously going forward.

componenttext: We don't typically announce that. It's been in the range of in terms of 250 to 300 basis points over time, or even higher at times. The bigger margin difference is obviously in GP.

componenttext: Got it. headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. And on the inventory levels, you talked about sort of customer facing versus non-customer facing. But are clearance levels of inventory year-over-year, how are they coming out of the first quarter?
componenttext: Got it. And on the inventory levels, you talked about sort of customer facing versus non-customer facing. But are clearance levels of inventory year-over-year, how are they coming out of the first quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: They're actually quite a bit down. We went through a different clearance cadence a year ago, you remember. We are now up against a comparable clearance cadence and our clearance is lower, which is actually reflected in lower clearance sales and higher pro
componenttext: They're actually quite a bit down. We went through a different clearance cadence a year ago, you remember. We are now up against a comparable clearance cadence and our clearance is lower, which is actually reflected in lower clearance sales and higher promotional sales, which we think is a healthy place to be. Our overall AUR is down about 1% year-to-date. Our AUR in clearance is down slightly but that's a function of less clearance to sell.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Erika Maschmeyer of Robert W. Baird.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about why you still anticipate a drag from the Catalog business on the sales line now that you've cycled in and don't expect a detriment from the gross margin perspective?
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about why you still anticipate a drag from the Catalog business on the sales line now that you've cycled in and don't expect a detriment from the gross margin perspective?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it gets a little complicated but essentially, a good portion of our Catalog business was from older customers buying conservative and traditional merchandise that chose, instead of calling in their orders to the call center or sending in a writte
componenttext: Okay. So it gets a little complicated but essentially, a good portion of our Catalog business was from older customers buying conservative and traditional merchandise that chose, instead of calling in their orders to the call center or sending in a written form, had chosen to enter their order online. That has been reflected in the past in our .com business. It was also reflected in our direct inventory in the warehouse. As we've transitioned the inventory facing the customer to be the same inventory that's in the stores by a vast amount, there are some specialized businesses online like wheeled goods for children's, cribs and so forth. The vast majority is the same inventory now that's in our stores. So we are up against some non-comparability in the first quarter of inventory levels that essentially had more of a catalog-feel to them than they did stores. But that's gone and that should not be a non-comparable issue going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And can you talk about your Digital business for the quarter, where that was relative to your expectations? And do you still feel comfortable with your guidance for double-digit growth this year?
componenttext: Great. And can you talk about your Digital business for the quarter, where that was relative to your expectations? And do you still feel comfortable with your guidance for double-digit growth this year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're very encouraged by our Soft Home business; it was actually quite good online, which is the biggest portion of our Direct business has been in home, so that was encouraging. And we feel that will continue to contribute going forward. I think the
componenttext: Yes, we're very encouraged by our Soft Home business; it was actually quite good online, which is the biggest portion of our Direct business has been in home, so that was encouraging. And we feel that will continue to contribute going forward. I think the area that's been most difficult has been Apparel because it was the one that was the most distorted by the conservative traditional inventory transition. We're now starting to see double-digit increases across all Apparel categories since Apparel is the biggest piece of our business in the stores, and we have about 27 million people that shop in our stores that were not yet shopping online with us because the inventory didn't match what they saw in the stores. We feel confident that we will be back on a growth trajectory. So we've gone through a massive transformation of what .com was when it was with essentially a different customer base. We've said this before but ironically, our oldest customer was our online customer. Our youngest customer was our store customer. So we believe that the customer profile will start to match the store customer as we've transitioned the inventory and as we've updated the functionality on the site.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And could you talk at all about the trends you're seeing in May?
componenttext: Great. And could you talk at all about the trends you're seeing in May?

componenttextpreview: It's a bit early to talk about May. Obviously, Mother's Day and Easter were only 2 weeks apart plus there'd been a number of factors that everybody that‚Äôs selling apparel has been facing in terms of the unusual and unseasonable weather coming out of fir
componenttext: It's a bit early to talk about May. Obviously, Mother's Day and Easter were only 2 weeks apart plus there'd been a number of factors that everybody that‚Äôs selling apparel has been facing in terms of the unusual and unseasonable weather coming out of first quarter. So it's only the middle of this -- the beginning of the second week of the period so it's probably too early to discuss it.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Sean Naughton of Piper Jaffray.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the marketing, can you just talk about how you're getting smarter in connecting with the customer and still able to deliver the same level of sales with some of the new brands you have coming on? And then also along those lines, is there any c
componenttext: In terms of the marketing, can you just talk about how you're getting smarter in connecting with the customer and still able to deliver the same level of sales with some of the new brands you have coming on? And then also along those lines, is there any changes in the promotional calendar that we should expect in the second quarter? And then lastly, anything in terms of the monthly comp cadence relative to your quarterly expectations for Q2?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. First of all, the customer is always changing in terms of the way they view media and how they are impacted by our offers. So for example, the traditional preprint, that same sort of newspapers 3 or 4 years ago, was by far the vast majority of our sp
componenttext: Yes. First of all, the customer is always changing in terms of the way they view media and how they are impacted by our offers. So for example, the traditional preprint, that same sort of newspapers 3 or 4 years ago, was by far the vast majority of our spend as well as the impact that the customer saw. As we've transitioned a good piece of our marketing into digital marketing obviously, we sorted exactly how we're using media. So I'd say the biggest single transition has been from preprint, their insert into newspapers, although still a large part of our program, the biggest single increase has been in digital media. In terms of the changes in cadence from month-to-month, we wouldn't necessarily message that except to say that we're up against the same calendar as a year ago in terms of Father's Day and back-to-school, so I don't see major shifts. I do--  would say that the last week of July last year was a difficult week for us because we were up against a very large non-comparable clearance event, so my guess is we'll have a better July than we did a year ago. I would say in terms of -- from a competitive point of view, we intend to continue to be very promotional because that's the nature of our business and that's what the customer expects.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I just, I guess lastly, in terms of new brands or new recognizable brands that you may be bringing into the portfolio, is there anything that you have on the radar that you're looking at over the next 12 to 24 months? And are you looking to
componenttext: Okay. And then I just, I guess lastly, in terms of new brands or new recognizable brands that you may be bringing into the portfolio, is there anything that you have on the radar that you're looking at over the next 12 to 24 months? And are you looking to increase the percentage within that private/exclusive label in the store?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: We remain committed to having attractions that bring the modern 18- to 35-year-old customer because we know we're under indexed in that category. And our modern businesses are the fastest-growing businesses that we have in the stores. So yes, we have othe
componenttext: We remain committed to having attractions that bring the modern 18- to 35-year-old customer because we know we're under indexed in that category. And our modern businesses are the fastest-growing businesses that we have in the stores. So yes, we have other ideas and we'll continue to innovate. That's what the customer has come to expect. Our scores that we seek from the consumer in terms of what's called the Net Promoter Score, in terms of admirers versus detractors have gone up double-digit, which says that New Look, New Day, Who Knew messaging is working because when they come to the store, they're finding what they're looking for. People's Style Watch has helped us a great deal in terms giving style credibility to our assortments. So this is a key strategy, it‚Äôs the #1 item that I mentioned in terms of style authority. So that's where our focus is on new attractions.

componenttext: I guess, just to clarify I think as a follow-up to Michelle's question. componenttextpreview: Okay. So I think I'm there. And then just in terms of the $5 per share goal, I guess when you originally delivered that goal, did you envision this amount of share repurchase? Did you envision sort of these restructuring items? How has the plan sort of ev
componenttext: Okay. So I think I'm there. And then just in terms of the $5 per share goal, I guess when you originally delivered that goal, did you envision this amount of share repurchase? Did you envision sort of these restructuring items? How has the plan sort of evolved? And do you still need a kind of mid-single-digit comps over the planning period to get to that $5?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So probably, the easiest way to think about it, if you assume we haven't changed our comp store growth objective and you assume we've trimmed our expectations out of new store, new footprint, as part of the plan and assume we didn't include any shar
componenttext: Okay. So probably, the easiest way to think about it, if you assume we haven't changed our comp store growth objective and you assume we've trimmed our expectations out of new store, new footprint, as part of the plan and assume we didn't include any share repurchase in the EPS estimate, you can assume that we've engineered a process improvement cost take-out to allow us to make $5 a share. Another way of looking at it is if you take the 2011 estimate that we have that we'd like to double that in terms of EPS by 2013. So we're not -- this is not something that's all back-end loaded. We expect to get improvement by accelerating our cost focus and our lean and other simplification initiatives.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then my final question. This is something that came up on the Liz Claiborne call that was sort of surprising to me, someone asked would they consider selling the brand to you. Would you consider buying the brand outright? Would that be so
componenttext: Okay, great. And then my final question. This is something that came up on the Liz Claiborne call that was sort of surprising to me, someone asked would they consider selling the brand to you. Would you consider buying the brand outright? Would that be something that would make sense?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, just to clarify our agreement. Our agreement allows us to acquire the brand after year 5. And once again, have the option to acquire the brand in year 10. And the pricing of that, more or less option, is related to the license income that would be a
componenttext: Well, just to clarify our agreement. Our agreement allows us to acquire the brand after year 5. And once again, have the option to acquire the brand in year 10. And the pricing of that, more or less option, is related to the license income that would be accruing to the Claiborne Corporation for our work together. That license income phase for the design element that they provide and we do the rest. So while we have the right to do it at year 5 and year 10, we do not have the absolute right to acquire it at other periods of time.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So that would be a negotiation if it were to happen outside of or before that time period?
componenttext: Okay. So that would be a negotiation if it were to happen outside of or before that time period?

componenttext: That's correct.

componenttext: Mike, just one clarification and then a follow-up question. I think you just said that your plan is to double EPS in 2011 by 2013. I wasn't sure if you meant '13 or '14.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then secondly just a little more color on some of the progress you're making in Home? Obviously, your team has been in place for a little over a year now. And last year, you were talking about improvements in how you present merchandise.
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then secondly just a little more color on some of the progress you're making in Home? Obviously, your team has been in place for a little over a year now. And last year, you were talking about improvements in how you present merchandise. Obviously in updating the assortments, and just wondered if you could give us your sense of what the drivers are in the improvement and then when we might start to see some improvement in the Hard Home areas?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great question. I think in Home and Soft Home, particularly, the real strengths have been bedding and bath, as well as the housewares, small electrics and gadgets categories. Luggage has also been on a great trend. So the core businesses that are at
componenttext: Okay. Great question. I think in Home and Soft Home, particularly, the real strengths have been bedding and bath, as well as the housewares, small electrics and gadgets categories. Luggage has also been on a great trend. So the core businesses that are attracting the customer on a day-to-day basis are starting to respond. I think there's been a real focus on upgrading the taste level as well as a more modern cast to the department in terms of the assortments and that's been well-received by customers. I think the real drag at the moment has been on the Hard Home business, particularly Furniture. We're obviously, taking a hard look at the housing industry and trying to figure out how to improve our Furniture business in this environment. There have been some shifts in sales promotions as well as we look at the profitability of these various businesses but we're still quite confident that Home's going to be a major contributor and the feedback we've gotten from our customer surveys on the assortments, the quality, the offer have all been improving, so we feel like we're on the right track. John Tighe and his team are very focused on building a long-term sustainable profitable business.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011

componenttext: Our last question today will be coming from the line of Bernard Sosnick with Gilford Securities.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: With regard to the 2014 sales line, you said that there would probably be fewer new stores contributing to it. But I don't think that you originally included Growth Brands in your forecast, so I'm wondering what that might prove to be as an element of sal
componenttext: With regard to the 2014 sales line, you said that there would probably be fewer new stores contributing to it. But I don't think that you originally included Growth Brands in your forecast, so I'm wondering what that might prove to be as an element of sales growth and what the sales number that you were looking for from the stores might be in 2014? You assumed $1 billion increase from Internet, we know that. Could you clarify the forecast, please?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think -- fair question. I think as we looked at 70 new large stores in 2014, as I mentioned earlier, our conclusion was given the current commercial real estate market that, that was unlikely. At the time, we had not yet announced our Growth Brand
componenttext: Sure. I think -- fair question. I think as we looked at 70 new large stores in 2014, as I mentioned earlier, our conclusion was given the current commercial real estate market that, that was unlikely. At the time, we had not yet announced our Growth Brands Division. So one can conclude that the Growth Brands Division in 2014 would not be as big as the drop we see in our forecast for large stores. So the difference would be a lower sales expectation in 2014 but maintaining the bottom line EPS forecast, which obviously improves an increase in the quality of earnings because sales would not be at the level that we had forecasted. We did not change the comp for the 5-year period. So all we're doing is calling out the fact that a year later, we're smarter as to what the current environment is for new store growth. We have an appetite for new stores when they meet our hurdle rate and when they have sufficient Penney's customers in the market. And in the meantime, we're going to re-invest a lot of our CapEx into merchandise improvements in our stores, attractions and renovations, and it will take a while for the Growth Brands group to start to build the kind of sales momentum to be the size that 70 new large stores would be.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: When you compare the Growth Brands to 70 large stores, right now, you don't have the CapEx plan in mind, but would you be thinking that the number of stores would be half the amount you originally planned or less?
componenttext: When you compare the Growth Brands to 70 large stores, right now, you don't have the CapEx plan in mind, but would you be thinking that the number of stores would be half the amount you originally planned or less?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, it's an estimate so I really haven't changed the estimate except to say that we  don't feel comfortable we can find 70 that would hit our hurdle rate. Those new communities where all the new housing was being developed in '06, '07 and
componenttext: Well, first of all, it's an estimate so I really haven't changed the estimate except to say that we  don't feel comfortable we can find 70 that would hit our hurdle rate. Those new communities where all the new housing was being developed in '06, '07 and early '08, those communities are not building houses in those communities today and we've taken a look at other formats. But at this point, we think the prudent thing to do is to streamline our cost structure so we can achieve the same bottom line without having to reach into less profitable opportunities on the CapEx side. So you're quite correct that we don't have a CapEx budget for 2014 at this point except to say by building fewer large new stores, we'll have more resources to allocate to other ways of growing the business.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you for joining jcpenney's  second quarter earnings this morning. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you for joining jcpenney's  second quarter earnings this morning. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plans, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties end of the companies future results of operations could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on of these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also please note that no portion of this call may be rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of JCPenney. Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after August 12, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have 2 speakers: first, Mike Ullman, JCPenney Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mike Dastugue, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Now I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Mike and I are going to keep our comments brief with this morning's so we'll have more time for your questions. Overall, there a few main points I'd like to make. First of all, while the topline system versus we
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Mike and I are going to keep our comments brief with this morning's so we'll have more time for your questions. Overall, there a few main points I'd like to make. First of all, while the topline system versus were softer than initially planned, we effectively managed expenses, maintain our strong liquidity position and continued to transition our pricing and brands to excite existing customers and attract new customers. Second, our focus on building attractions to becoming a destination, which is where style is taking hold. Our identified growth initiatives, Liz Claiborne, support inside JCPenney, our tops business, modern shoes and handbags, fast fashion, modern bright fine jewelry, housewares and Center Core performing double-digit ahead of last year. With transactions being up 6.4% and our AUR essentially flat during the quarter, we're not trading down on our business, trading down on our quality or trading down our price but rather, we are trading up our attractions. 
We see opportunity growth sales by improving the productivity in our existing stores in jcp.com with the continued success of our growth initiatives and exclusive attractions like Liz Claiborne, Sephora  inside JCPenney, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring by ALDO. 
In the second quarter, we opened 22 Sephora inside jcpenney locations and another 21 had a grand opening today, bringing our total locations to 297. Additionally, in the next few weeks, we'll have a total of 405 Call it Spring locations and 487 MNG by Mango locations, reinforcing JCPenney as a style destination. 
As part of our $650 million 2011 capital expenditures just program, we also completed approximately 500 store upgrades and 30 major renovations during the quarter, including the large renovation in our company's history at the JCPenney Roosevelt Field store in Long Island. Our ongoing renovation program, which is being rolled out across our fleet of stores is a key component of our transformation plan designed to make our stores more exciting and to continue improve our sales per square foot productivity. 
Turning now to our operational effectiveness initiatives. During the quarter, we accelerated the actions we are taking to significantly improve our expense structure. This is part of a multiyear operational effectiveness program that we put in place almost 2 years ago to reengineer our business, which will allow us to achieve our 5-year earnings target by 2014. 
As we stated in our first quarter press release, we expect to realize $50 million expense savings in fiscal 2011. $10 million was realized in the first quarter with $7 million saved in the second quarter. The remaining $33 million in savings were incurred in the back half, primarily in the fourth quarter. Year-to-date we've gotten out of the Catalog business, announced the closure of our clearance outlets, reorganized our supply chain and custom decorating operations, we're ensuring our marketing spend is productive and effective, we're rolling out in new process improvement technology like RFID, mark down and price optimization and we launched the new digital platform. Additionally, we're looking at the design and structure of the entire organization to ensure we have the right people in the right roles to reflect our future growth opportunities. In some situations, primarily to home office, we will staff organizations differently to meet the changing needs of our business. 
Part of the organizational redesign includes a voluntary early retirement program for select associates who will spend at least 20 years in the company are active participants in our pension fund and are 55 years of age or above. This voluntary program is not designed by all participants, enhance retirement benefit in exchange for voluntarily separating from the company. By making these changes, we will great opportunities to improve our processes and do things better, faster and more efficiently. With that, let me turn the call over to Michael, who will provide the numbers relating to our during the second quarter. Michael?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported $0.07 of earnings per share, in line with our most recent guidance. Starting with our top line. Once again, our growth initiatives in sales for our private and exclusive brands drove th
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported $0.07 of earnings per share, in line with our most recent guidance. Starting with our top line. 
Once again, our growth initiatives in sales for our private and exclusive brands drove the business as the company's comparable store sales grew 1.5% in the second quarter. Year-to-date, comp store sales are up 2.7% over last year. 
Total sales for the quarter declined slightly to $3.9 billion, largely reflecting the elimination of our Catalog business last year. Gross margin in the second quarter was negatively impacted by the softer-than-expected selling environment in May and June, which resulted in more promotional activity and more markdowns in the quarter. Compared to last year's historical peak, gross margin decreased approximately 110 basis points to 38.3% of sales. 
SG&A for the quarter came in better than guidance, increasing $32 million year-over-year to $1.24 billion or 31.8% of sales. Lower-than-planned SG&A was primarily driven by effective management of our store labor hours and various home office savings initiatives. These items offset moderate expense increases related to the expansion of Sephora inside jcpenney as well as startup costs associated with our growth plans division. 
Also our effective tax rate, 41.7% was slightly higher than expected, largely due to the changes in certain state tax laws that took effect this year. We ended the second quarter with approximately $1.6 billion in cash and short-term investments and our free cash flow has improved approximately $90 million year-over-year. 
Capital expenditures for the second quarter were $295 million, in line with our expectations and we continue to anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $650 million. We ended the quarter with our inventory of 2.3%, in line with our projected sales trend for the upcoming quarter. 
Now let me share with you our planning assumptions for the third quarter. We expect comp store sales to grow 2% to 3% in the third quarter. On a monthly basis, we expect August sales will be below this range as back-to-school selling season starting later again this year with customers continuing their pattern of shopping closer to need. 
September should be roughly in line with our quarterly guidance while October is expected to be a bit better. The gross margin rate is expected to be down slightly in the third quarter. Reflecting our focus on expense management, we are expecting SG&A to be flat to slightly lower year-over-year even with the additional expenses we expect to incur related to the expansions of Sephora  inside JCPenney, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring. 
The real estate and other line is expected to reflect that expense of about $11 million with $19 million of restructuring charges flowing through that line item. Taking all of these assumptions into account for the third quarter earnings, we expect to be in the range of $0.15 to $0.20 per share including previously disclosed charges of approximately $0.05 per share. 
Also as Mike mentioned in our ongoing effort to reduce expenses and streamline operations, we have begun a voluntary early retirement program or so-called burp. Eligible associates will have between September 1 and October 15 to decide if they want to participate in the program. We will release the number of associates who have elected to participate in the program as well as the operational efficiencies resulting from this program later in the year, likely with our third quarter earnings release. Our current Q3 earnings guidance does not include any impact from the burp but we will update you on the earnings impact later in the quarter as appropriate. 
Additionally, we may also incur additional one-time charges in the third quarter arising from the possible sale of the company's clearance outlet stores to a third party but that impact has not been included in our current guidance. As you'll recall earlier this year, we announced the plan to close the 19 outlet stores over the course of this year and next year. However, we are currently in negotiations to sell these outlet stores to a third party which may result in acceleration of some of their previously announced charges and will be incurred in the third quarter. We will keep you updated as appropriate on the impact of this potential sale. 
So the be clear we currently expect Q3 earnings to be in the range of $0.15 to $0.20 per share, including the previously disclosed restructuring charges of approximately $0.05. And this guidance does not include the impact of the burp or the sale of the outlets stores. 
As to the full year guidance, because the full year earnings impact resulting from a voluntary early retirement program, the ongoing restructuring initiatives and other home office initiatives including the changes in leadership, it is yet to be determined and because we expect the consumer environment remain uncertain, we believe it's prudent to provide guidance for the fourth quarter and full when with visibility into these matters has improved. As such, we're not providing full-year outlook at this time. And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Mike

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Consumer climate is clearly uncertain and tumultuous in the last 10 days or so hasn't given core customer and middle income family any reason to be more confident. Due to our compelling value proposition now more than ever, our abili
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Consumer climate is clearly uncertain and tumultuous in the last 10 days or so hasn't given core customer and middle income family any reason to be more confident. 
Due to our compelling value proposition now more than ever, our ability to offer great style and quality, compelling prices is sustainable, competitive advantage. Encouraging to us is our recent customer scorecard for the second quarter. That a significant improvement in price perception and value to the consumer. We also scored the largest increase in store for me, styles I like, new styles every time I visit and overall update and style for the store. Therefore, we remain cautiously optimistic about the back half of the year, especially as we head into the height of the back-to-school selling season as well as fall holiday. 
For the high penetration of private brands that continue to grow faster than the rest of the store in our high margin businesses. We have the unique ability to offer our customers quality merchandise at very sharp prices while protecting our margins. 
We are continuing to build on the accomplishments we set in motion almost 2 years ago, which were focused on 4 key areas. First, we continue to assert our style authority by delivering great style credibility with the balance of the best private and national brands. Second, we're giving a memorable customer interactions with the help of our highly engaged associates to inspire discovery and build loyalty with our customers. Third, we are increasing our reach through digital experiences that are personalized and impactful. And fourth, we're taking a significant strips to drive profitable growth with a focus on improving our operational effectiveness. 
Our focus on reengineering our business will allow us to achieve the 2014 earnings target we set out last year and move us closer to our goal of a being a retail estimate leader. 
Before I open up the call for questions, I'd like to give you an update on Ron Johnson. As planned, Ron joined our Board of Directors on August 1. And Ron and I visited stores and we took a trip with me to Asia to a Supplier Summit and individual needs of suppliers. Our time together has been and will continue to be very productive and we're looking forward to getting Ron a full time CEO in November 1. With that, operator, we'll take your questions.

componenttext: Can you give us additional color on the gross margin guidance? What levels of promotional activities is baked into that guidance and how important is the new optimization technology to that guidance?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Part of our margin story in the first half has been the difficult conversion away from the catalog business and its effect on .com. So part of our caution is we still feel we are in the middle of that transformation. Over half of our .com business today i
componenttext: Part of our margin story in the first half has been the difficult conversion away from the catalog business and its effect on .com. So part of our caution is we still feel we are in the middle of that transformation. Over half of our .com business today is the home business and the home is the most troubled of our businesses. So while we are getting good sell through on fresh merchandise, as a matter of fact, we continue to see very sharp price points being bestsellers, as well as the newness and fashion and Sephora  actually is the highest trending business in store. So we're optimistic about our ability to maintain margins but we still have the drag a bit of our .com business. So I would say in the first half and particularly in the second quarter, half of our decline in margin to last year was the effect of .com.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And can you talk about your pricing philosophy in this environment and what are your experience with regard to pricing elasticity?
componenttext: And can you talk about your pricing philosophy in this environment and what are your experience with regard to pricing elasticity?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said earlier, we believe we got ahead of this by our strength in sourcing and our ability to test over a year ago. Our view is that customer expects the sharp price points. In this economic environment, we've been able to maintain those. I'm s
componenttext: Well, as we said earlier, we believe we got ahead of this by our strength in sourcing and our ability to test over a year ago. Our view is that customer expects the sharp price points. In this economic environment, we've been able to maintain those. I'm sure that's had some impact on customer score card in terms of perception and price. At the same time, we think we can get modest price improvement in the middle of our assortments, where fashion is driving the business and where the customer sees the value of something that's relevant with what they are wanting at this timeframe. So we'll continue to look at somewhat less unit selling in the fall season but at higher average unit in retail. But I think our June retail will be a competitive advantage in this environment.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, based on your same-store sales on your SG&A leverage, can you assess some of your ongoing SG&A initiatives outside the $50 million of expense savings you're expressing in the quarter and that we will see in the third quarter as well?
componenttext: And then lastly, based on your same-store sales on your SG&A leverage, can you assess some of your ongoing SG&A initiatives outside the $50 million of expense savings you're expressing in the quarter and that we will see in the third quarter as well?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we have 9 different initiatives that are attacking SG&A and some long-term program that will be played out over the next several years. Our view is that marketing effectiveness is one of our key initiatives and part of that again, is as we transitio
componenttext: Well, we have 9 different initiatives that are attacking SG&A and some long-term program that will be played out over the next several years. Our view is that marketing effectiveness is one of our key initiatives and part of that again, is as we transition away from the traditional catalog business into more print media is directed across stores as well as .com. As mentioned about our voluntary retirement program that has a positive effect on SG&A that we are looking forward to. We won't know the full impact of that until people voluntarily step forward and say they want to participate. We continue to look at ways to improve our processes in the store as well as in home office by redesigning work. We're looking at our non-merchandise procurement where we can save in terms of purchasing paper, print and other commodity items. So it's a comprehensive program, we believe given the impact of the recession on virtually every business, the pace of the consumer, we think we're going to get our structure in line to be able to leverage to get improved bottom line results and that's in our 5-year plan.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: What's been driving the business all year in our comp improvement in the first half has been driven by our growth initiatives. And as mentioned, those includes the Sephora, the tux business, the modern assortments, the intimate apparel business, those bus
componenttext: What's been driving the business all year in our comp improvement in the first half has been driven by our growth initiatives. And as mentioned, those includes the Sephora, the tux business, the modern assortments, the intimate apparel business, those businesses have been quite encouraging. There's over 12% comp in the aggregate of those initiatives in the first half. We expect those to continue in Liz Claiborne is being through me successful well beyond our projection. We see no reason why these would slowdown in the back half. Our opening price points assortments are selling through very much at or above plan. The toughest businesses frankly, have been the middle of the basics assortments. I think customers in this economic environment just decided to slowdown on kind of the routine purchasing and they're focused on fashion and price points that meet their family budget in this economic environment.

componenttextpreview: And then the better gross margin guidance for 3Q versus 2Q, can you just talk about the factors that will drive that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: We thought that we had a particularly difficult May. I think part of the most everybody experienced unchangeable weather early in the quarter and that we encourage as we got into the latter part of June and July. And since the weather now is quite warm pa
componenttext: We thought that we had a particularly difficult May. I think part of the most everybody experienced unchangeable weather early in the quarter and that we encourage as we got into the latter part of June and July. And since the weather now is quite warm particularly, rare now and seasonal goods are selling well we think one of our strengths as back-to-school. And most back-to-school is in front of us and in the third quarter, so we feel good about back-to-school and we feel good about holiday. I think if there's any caution is what's facing the American family, whether it's the continuation of employment that is not growing as fast in the new entrants or housing and volatility prolonged by the legal process and other factors.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Klinefelter with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Klinefelter with Piper Jaffray.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions about the supply chain. In terms of coming back from her suppliers somewhat recently, can you share any perspective on what you were seeing out of the import community in terms of costs, labor trends, raw material trends et cete
componenttext: Just a couple of questions about the supply chain. In terms of coming back from her suppliers somewhat recently, can you share any perspective on what you were seeing out of the import community in terms of costs, labor trends, raw material trends et cetera? And then also what sort of inventory flexibility do you have for the second half of the year both up and down at this point given the low visibility for comp trends for the industry at this point?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we as you know, we believe it will strengthen our partnership with our international suppliers. I think we benefited from having virtually no cost increases in the first half. And I would argue that our cost impact on the second half of the year is
componenttext: Well, we as you know, we believe it will strengthen our partnership with our international suppliers. I think we benefited from having virtually no cost increases in the first half. And I would argue that our cost impact on the second half of the year is probably more muted than most. We got ahead of it. I think we benefited from suppliers helping us with managing production and earning on down periods. But there's no question that the cost of cotton impact everyone particularly in categories like home or the portion of the good is much higher than cotton. Cotton prices are coming down or have come down. So we're a bit more optimistic in the second half of the spring that we'll get back to a more normalized cost structure. We believe that our suppliers have worked very hard with us to optimize what we will buy in terms of what portion of assortment and which price points. And in terms of the visibility to what we have in the back half we feel we have the right goods in route. There's not much flexibility of changing quantity so this close to the end of the year but we're buying the middle of spring at this point and we feel good about the work of our suppliers to continue our competitive advantage in terms of sourcing as well as private brand. Private brand sales improvement continues to exceed national brand selling and our GP and private brand continues to exceed national brand GP.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011

componenttext: One other question. You mentioned that the later back-to-school season is leading you to forecast a slightly lower August comp versus your quarterly guidance. And you can you just share a little bit on what the analytics are going to that estimate? Are you seeing anything in terms of early back-to-school seasons that give you confidence that you will see an acceleration toward the end of the month or how are you formulating that thesis?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Last several years, it's really been almost 2 or 3 days a year average shift to the center of back-to-school. Last year, it was quite strong around Labor Day and actually after Labor Day. We think part of this is buying closer to the needs so maybe the mo
componenttext: Last several years, it's really been almost 2 or 3 days a year average shift to the center of back-to-school. Last year, it was quite strong around Labor Day and actually after Labor Day. We think part of this is buying closer to the needs so maybe the moms ends up by the coat after Labor Day when she feels like the pricing is better. It's really assess what she bought versus what the child needs for back-to-school. So we're just reflecting what our experience has been over the last several years. And of course, the tax-free shopping is has shifted much of this year. So that's not a big factor. It's pretty comparable to last year.

componenttext: Yes, the clunky part of our transitional catalog is affecting us more in .com than we anticipated because apparently the catalog customers spent a lot of time entering their orders online. And we've been slow to be able to talk to them in a direct-mail way. But the big pluses in home and in luggage, in housewares and the soft part of home, bedding and bath, we believe that our print media going forward is going to be more targeted to not only the existing store customer but also to pick up those customers that would shop from us in catalog. They are very willing to shop with us online so those are the main things. We have some new leadership in the furniture business that we're excited about the prospects there but there's no doubt that American families are having difficulties in wanting to invest in big-ticket home in this economic situation.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let's start with the Foundry. The Foundry has 10 stores opened at this point. We've seen excellent sell-through, several stores are hitting the 3 to 5-year productivity in the first couple of months. We think the mall stores seem to be performing at
componenttext: Well, let's start with the Foundry. The Foundry has 10 stores opened at this point. We've seen excellent sell-through, several stores are hitting the 3 to 5-year productivity in the first couple of months. We think the mall stores seem to be performing at a much better rate than the 3 mall stores we opened. But I would say the customer reaction or customer service reaction or the customer scores are in the eighties, which is highly satisfied. So we feel like we have a very responsive customer to what we're doing. We'll be evaluating that over the next several months in terms of the rate of the stores. Our other growth initiatives, we have 2 stores opening this year and one is already opened in Maryland. We have a store opening in, in Central Dallas here in about 6 or 7 weeks. Our growth initiatives again as mentioned, we believe will get double-digit improvements in selling and the growth initiatives in the back half as we've experienced Liz Claiborne's, Sephora, Mango, Call it Spring, Modern Bride. Those are the things that are driving the growth.

componenttext: Bernie, just a correct this record that we've been out  of the 3 big books for a year now that we had 75 other books. And frankly, the separate home books that were fairly effective had a bigger impact on .com than we had planned. There were about $400 million sales lost this year from catalog business is not comparable and that we'll be out of it completely by the end of the year. We started I think we went dark on catalog completing toward the fourth quarter of last year. So while it's not helpful in terms of our visibility and transforming this area of our business, we do believe going forward, it's the right thing to do. It is still quite profitable at very high margins but the problem was it was dropping like a rock. So question one, do you want to take the hit and move on with the way the customer wants to shop going forward. And it's quite good, the customers are really shopping online and use the catalog for our view book but the catalog postage and print and producing pages of print was not the most productive way to go forward.

componenttext: Well, transitioning out of clearance mode, which is to be clear in outlet stores to lining our assortments so we can clear catalog, what formerly catalog mix it was now online merchandise clearance through our regular store. So there's some noncomparability in that process. We'll be through that by the end of the fall as well. So these are transformational issues that you're clunky but not necessary.

componenttext: There's a little bit of that would be related to the print media but the majority of the savings was in salary effectiveness as well as marketing optimization. And those areas, we plan to make improvements as well as home office expense. So I think it was well managed and we actually had lower dollars than a year ago by I think $35 million, which is given all the renovations initiatives and things that we did including all of our comp adjustments is a good record.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the encouraging thing, Bernie, is that we have 27 million people that shop our stores for fashion. They didn't shop online because they didn't not have the same merchandise online. So we now have now aligned our assortments and we're getting
componenttext: Well, I think the encouraging thing, Bernie, is that we have 27 million people that shop our stores for fashion. They didn't shop online because they didn't not have the same merchandise online. So we now have now aligned our assortments and we're getting I think something in the range of 12% to 20% increase on the apparel categories online now. That is yet as you point out, that is the young customer. So we don't think there's any inhibition to shop with us online. They're actually buying our goods in the store but shop somebody else online. So we still have a very robust .com business. It's just not growing overall because 51% of it is home. And as the home furnishings has softened take hold and we get better print media to this formerly catalog customers, we feel that we'll get to double-digit .com overall.

componenttext: Well, as I said earlier we're up double digit in luggage, housewares, bedding, bath, holler, very strong positive comps. The only 2 areas in home which were down are frankly, the furniture. Furniture was down 20% so those are the things were driving down the overall home business.

componenttext: We are not ashamed of having big ticket. It's just in this environment, if you don't a fill a lot of new homes, we don't get as many window coverings. And people can defer a purchase of changing their window covering so we think it's an ongoing strength overall. But at the moment, it's not helpful.

componenttext: Well, there have been a number over the last couple of years. I'll just focus on the ones that have been in the last year. Claiborne is our biggest and are well over our early expectations and frankly, keep increasing our future commitments. We think that is resonating not only in the categories we were in before we went to the apparently the Liz Claiborne. brand that but we're also expanded categories that's very well. I think the MNG by Mango is 77 stores last year. And as I mentioned in my remarks, we have 500 stores by fall. It's getting great registration with the customer. The pricing is very sharp compared to other fast fashion concepts, we're the only department store that has true  fast fashion in the store and is attracting the 18- to 35-year-old customer segment that we're focused on. Call it Spring again, very much modern shoe assortment that's attracting younger demographic. We're way ahead of our expectations there across women's handbags and men's. Our support continues to be double-digit comps and leading brand launch. Our Modern Bride has been a pleasant surprise in terms of our engagement jewelry business, up over 20% comp as we rolled that out. American Living continues to be one of the top 10 brands. It's obviously more classic and traditional than some of the other that are focused more in the other customer. So we feel very good. As I said, we only had growth initiatives would be up double-digit comps. So the other part of the business obviously is the more of the basic business that during the difficult, economic climate customers can defer.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that main learning was the customer did not have much elasticity desire at the opening price points. The share book and price points, we report to them. And that's continue to be the case and they responded very well particularly in Father's Day a
componenttext: I think that main learning was the customer did not have much elasticity desire at the opening price points. The share book and price points, we report to them. And that's continue to be the case and they responded very well particularly in Father's Day and early back-to-school. I think there has been some willingness to pay a bit more for something that wasn't fashionable and new and that's encouraging to us. I think the good news is our costs of goods is such that we don't have to go up as much as some of our key competitors meet our objectives. So while we plan units down modestly, that means we don't have to put as much and it to meet our overall objectives but time will tell. This is a difficult unprecedented period of time, rising apparel inflation in 20 years so we expect in this environment there'll be a lot of learning for each of our competitors and us.

componenttext: We think our ongoing expense program will continue to be a impact on the P&L. And I would say our mall discretionary traffic is pretty much the same, 200 basis points decline in discretionary mall traffic so as we look at the back half, I think that anybody that looks at it carefully will say, it's almost better to be cautious about what we don't think we're going back  into a recession customer has reason to be concerned about the ability to spend more than they have planned. And that's our caution on comp sales forecasting as well as GP.
