headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays. Thank you. Ms. Hays, you may
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays. Thank you. Ms. Hays, you may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney second quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Pri
componenttext:
Thank you. And thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney second quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and the company's future results of operations could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also please note that no portion of this call may be rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of  J. C. Penney. Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after August 12, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated, and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have 2 speakers: first, Mike Ullman, J. C. Penney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Michael Dastugue, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Michael and I are going to keep our comments brief this morning's, so we'll have more time for your questions. Overall, there a few main points I'd like to make. First of all, while the top line sales number w
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Michael and I are going to keep our comments brief this morning's, so we'll have more time for your questions. Overall, there a few main points I'd like to make. 
First of all, while the top line sales number were softer than initially planned, we effectively managed expenses, maintained our strong liquidity position and continued to transition our storefront of products and brands to excite existing customers and attract new customers. Second, our focus on building attractions to becoming a destination for discovering great style is taking hold. 
Our identified growth initiatives, Liz Claiborne, Sephora inside jcpenney, our tops business, modern shoes and handbags, fast fashion, Modern Bride fine jewelry, housewares and center core are performing double-digit ahead of last year. With transactions being up 6.4% and our AUR essentially flat during the quarter, we're not trading down our business, trading down our quality or trading down our price but rather, we're trading up our attractions. 
We see opportunity to grow sales by improving the productivity in our existing stores and jcp.com, with the continued success of our growth initiatives and exclusive attractions like Liz Claiborne, Sephora inside jcpenney, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring by ALDO. 
In the second quarter, we opened 22 Sephora inside jcpenney locations and another 21 had a grand opening today, bringing our total locations to 297. Additionally, in the next few weeks, we'll have a total of 405 Call it Spring locations and 487 MNG by Mango locations, reinforcing  jcpenney as a style destination. 
As part of our $650 million 2011 capital expenditures program, we also completed approximately 500 store updates and 20 major renovations during the quarter, including the largest renovation in our company's history at the jcpenney Roosevelt Field store in Long Island. Our ongoing renovation program, which is being rolled out across our fleet of stores is a key component of our transformation plan designed to make our stores more exciting and to continue to improve our sales per square foot productivity. 
Turning now to our operational effectiveness  initiatives. During the quarter, we accelerated the actions we are taking to significantly improve our expense structure. This is part of a multiyear operational effectiveness program that we put in place almost 2 years ago to reengineer our business, which will allow us to achieve our 5-year earnings target by 2014. 
As we stated in our first quarter press release, we expect to realize $50 million expense savings in fiscal 2011. $10 million was realized in the first quarter, with $7 million saved in the second quarter. The remaining $33 million in savings will occur in the back half, primarily in the fourth quarter. Year-to-date, we've gotten out of the Catalog business, announced the closure of our clearance outlets, reorganized our supply chain and custom decorating operations, we're ensuring our marketing spend is productive, competitive and effective, we're rolling out a new process improvement technologies like RFID, mark down and price optimization and we launched the new digital platform. Additionally, we're looking at the design and structure of our entire organization to ensure we have the right people in the right roles to reflect our future growth opportunities. In some situations, primarily at the home office, we will staff organizations differently to meet the changing needs of our business. 
Part of the organizational redesign includes a voluntary early retirement program for select associates, who have spent at least 20 years in the company, are active participants in our pension fund and are 55 years of age or above. This voluntary program is designed to provide eligible participants enhance retirement benefit in exchange for voluntarily separating from the company. By making these change, we will create opportunities to improve our processes and do things better, faster and more efficiently. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Michael, who will provide the numbers related to our business during the second quarter. Michael?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported $0.07 in earnings per share, in line with our most recent guidance. Starting with our top line. Once again, our growth initiatives and sales of our private and exclusive brands drove th
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported $0.07 in earnings per share, in line with our most recent guidance. Starting with our top line. 
Once again, our growth initiatives and sales of our private and exclusive brands drove the business as the company's comparable store sales grew 1.5% in the second quarter. Year-to-date, comp store sales are up 2.7% over last year. 
Total sales for the quarter declined slightly to $3.9 billion, largely reflecting the elimination of our Catalog business last year. Gross margin in the second quarter was negatively impacted by the softer-than-expected selling environment in May and June, which resulted in more promotional activity and more markdowns in the quarter. Compared to last year's historical peak, gross margin decreased approximately 110 basis points to 38.3% of sales. 
SG&A for the quarter came in better than guidance, decreasing $32 million year-over-year to $1.24 billion or 31.8% of sales. Lower-than-planned SG&A was primarily driven by effective management of our store labor hours and various home office savings initiatives. These items offset moderate expense increases related to the expansion of Sephora inside jcpenney, as well as startup costs associated with our growth brands division. 
Also our effective tax rate, 41.7% was slightly higher than expected, largely due to the changes in certain state tax laws that took effect this year. We ended the second quarter with approximately $1.6 billion in cash and short-term investments and our free cash flow has improved approximately $90 million year-over-year. 
Capital expenditures through the second quarter were $295 million, in line with our expectations and we continue to anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $650 million. We ended the quarter with our inventory up 2.3%, in line with our projected sales trend for the upcoming quarter. 
Now let me share with you our planning assumptions for the third quarter. We expect comp store sales will grow 2% to 3% in the third quarter. On a monthly basis, we expect August sales will be below this range as back-to-school selling season is starting later again this year, with customers continuing their pattern of shopping closer to need. 
September should be roughly in line with our quarterly guidance, while October is expected to be a bit better. The gross margin rate is expected to be down slightly in the third quarter. Reflecting our focus on expense management, we are expecting SG&A to be flat to slightly lower year-over-year even with the additional expenses we expect to incur related to the expansions of Sephora inside jcpenney, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring. 
The real estate and other line is expected to reflect the net expense of about $11 million with $19 million of restructuring charges flowing through that line item. Taking all of these assumptions into account for the third quarter earnings, we expect to be in the range of $0.15 to $0.20 per share including previously disclosed charges of approximately $0.05 per share. 
Also as Mike mentioned, in our ongoing effort to reduce expenses and streamline operations, we have begun a Voluntary Early Retirement Program or so-called VERP. Eligible associates will have between September 1 and October 15 to decide if they want to participate in the program. We will release the number of associates who have elected to participate in the program, as well as the operational efficiencies resulting from this program later in the year, likely with our third quarter earnings release. Our current Q3 earnings guidance does not include any impact from the VERP but we will update you on the earnings impact later in the quarter as appropriate. 
Additionally, we may also incur additional onetime charges in the third quarter arising from the possible sale of the company's clearance outlet stores to a third party but that impact has not been included in our current guidance. As you recall, earlier this year, we announced the plan to close the 19 outlet stores over the course of this year and next year. However, we are currently in negotiations to sell these outlet stores to a third party, which may result in acceleration of some of the previously announced charges and would be incurred in the third quarter. We will keep you updated as appropriate on the impact of this potential sale. 
So to be clear, we currently expect Q3 earnings to be in the range of $0.15 to $0.20 per share, including the previously disclosed restructuring charges of approximately $0.05. And this guidance does not include the impact of the VERP or the sale of the outlet stores. 
As to the full year guidance, because the full year earnings impact resulting from our Voluntary Early Retirement Program, the ongoing restructuring initiatives and other home office initiatives including the changes in leadership, it is yet to be determined and because we expect the consumer environment to remain uncertain, we believe it is prudent to provide guidance for the fourth quarter and full year, when visibility into these matters has improved. As such, we are not providing full year outlook at this time. 
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Mike

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Consumer climate is clearly uncertain and the tumultuous last 10 days or so hasn't given our core customer, the middle income family any reason to be more confident. Due to our compelling value proposition now more than ever, our abi
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Consumer climate is clearly uncertain and the tumultuous last 10 days or so hasn't given our core customer, the middle income family any reason to be more confident. 
Due to our compelling value proposition now more than ever, our ability to offer great style and quality at compelling prices is sustainable, competitive advantage. Encouraging to us is our recent customer scorecard for the second quarter. We've had a significant improvement in price perception and value delivered to the consumer. We also scored the largest increase in store for me, styles I like, new styles every time I visit and overall update and style for the store. Therefore, we remain cautiously optimistic about the back half of the year, especially as we head into the height of the back-to-school selling season, as well as fall and holiday. 
With our high penetration of private brands that continue to grow faster than the rest of the store and our high margin businesses, we have a unique ability to offer our customers quality merchandise at very sharp prices, while protecting our margins. 
We are continuing to build on the accomplishments we set in motion almost 2 years ago, which were focused on 4 key areas: First, we're continuing to assert our style authority by delivering great style credibility, with a balance of the best private and national brands. Second, we're delivering on memorable customer interactions with the help of our highly-engaged associates, who inspire discovery and build loyalty with our customers. Third, we're increasing our reach through digital experiences that are personalized and impactful. And fourth, we're taking significant steps to drive profitable growth with a focus on improving our operational effectiveness. 
Our focus on reengineering our business will allow us to achieve the 2014 earnings target we set out last year, and move us closer toward our goal of being a retail industry leader. 
Before I open the call for questions, I'd like to give you an update on Ron Johnson. As planned, Ron joined our Board of Directors on August 1. And Ron and I have been visiting stores and he took a trip with me to Asia for our supplier summit and individual meetings with key suppliers. Our time together has been and will continue to be very productive, and we're all looking forward to getting Ron here full time as CEO in November 1. 
With that, operator, we'll take your questions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you provide us additional color on the gross margin guidance? What levels of promotional activities is baked into that guidance, and how important is the new optimization technology to the guidance?
componenttext: Can you provide us additional color on the gross margin guidance? What levels of promotional activities is baked into that guidance, and how important is the new optimization technology to the guidance?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Part of our margin story in the first half has been the difficult conversion away from the catalog business and its effect on dot-com. So part of our caution is we still feel we're in the middle of that transformation. Over half of our dot-com business to
componenttext: Part of our margin story in the first half has been the difficult conversion away from the catalog business and its effect on dot-com. So part of our caution is we still feel we're in the middle of that transformation. Over half of our dot-com business today is the home business and big-ticket home is the most troubled of our businesses. So while we're getting good sell-through on fresh merchandise, as a matter of fact, we continue to see very sharp price points being bestsellers, as well as the newness and fashion and Sephora actually is the highest trending business in the store. So we're optimistic about our ability to maintain margins but we still have the drag a bit of our dot-com business. So I would say in the first half and particularly in the second quarter, half of our decline in margin to last year was the effect of dot-com.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, can you talk about your pricing philosophy in this environment, and what are your experiencing with regard to pricing elasticity?
componenttext: And then, can you talk about your pricing philosophy in this environment, and what are your experiencing with regard to pricing elasticity?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we've messaged earlier, we believe we got ahead of this by our strength in sourcing and our ability to test over a year ago. Our view is that the customer expects the sharp price points. In this economic environment, we've been able to maintain t
componenttext: Well, as we've messaged earlier, we believe we got ahead of this by our strength in sourcing and our ability to test over a year ago. Our view is that the customer expects the sharp price points. In this economic environment, we've been able to maintain those. I'm sure that had some impact on the customer scorecard in terms of perception of price. At the same time, we think we can get modest price improvement in the middle of our assortments, where fashion is driving the business and where the customer sees the value of something that's relevant to what they are wanting at this time frame. So we will continue to look at somewhat less unit selling in the fall season but at higher average unit at retail. So I think our average unit at retail will be a competitive advantage in this environment.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, based on your same-store sales, I was very impressed with your SG&A leverage. Can you assess some of your ongoing SG&A initiatives outside the $50 million in expense savings you experience in the quarter and that we will see in the
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, based on your same-store sales, I was very impressed with your SG&A leverage. Can you assess some of your ongoing SG&A initiatives outside the $50 million in expense savings you experience in the quarter and that we will see in the third quarter as well?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we have 9 different initiatives that are attacking SG&A and some long-term program that will be played out over the next several years. Our view is that marketing effectiveness is one of our key initiatives and part of that is again, is the transiti
componenttext: Well, we have 9 different initiatives that are attacking SG&A and some long-term program that will be played out over the next several years. Our view is that marketing effectiveness is one of our key initiatives and part of that is again, is the transition away from the traditional catalog business into more print media, that's directed across stores, as well as dot-com. As mentioned about our voluntary early retirement program, that has a positive effect on SG&A that we are looking forward to. We won't know the full impact of that until people voluntarily step forward and say, they want to participate. We continue to look at ways to improve our processes in the store, as well as in home office by redesigning work. We are looking at our non-merchandise procurement, where we can save in terms of purchasing paper, print and other commodity items. So it's a comprehensive program, we believe, given the impact of the recession on virtually every business that faces the consumer, that we need to get our cost structure in line to be able to leverage, to get improved bottom line results and that's integral to our 5-year plan.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: You discussed how challenging and uncertain the consumer environment is. Can you talk about what you expect the comp drivers to be in the back half to cause the acceleration from the second quarter and then also the acceleration within the third quarter?
componenttext: You discussed how challenging and uncertain the consumer environment is. Can you talk about what you expect the comp drivers to be in the back half to cause the acceleration from the second quarter and then also the acceleration within the third quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: What's been driving the business all year and our comp improvement in the first half has been driven by our growth initiatives. And as mentioned, those includes the Sephora, the tops business, the modern assortments, the intimate apparel business, those a
componenttext: What's been driving the business all year and our comp improvement in the first half has been driven by our growth initiatives. And as mentioned, those includes the Sephora, the tops business, the modern assortments, the intimate apparel business, those are the young businesses, those businesses have been quite encouraging. There's over 12% comp in the aggregate of those initiatives in the first half, we expect those to continue. Liz Claiborne has been extremely successful, well beyond our projection. We see no reason why these would slow down in the back half. Our opening price points assortments are selling through very much at or above plan. The toughest businesses frankly have been in the middle of the basics assortments. I think customers in this economic environment have just decided to slow down on kind of the routine purchasing, and they're focused on fashion and price points that meet their family budget in this economic environment.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the better gross margin guidance for 3Q versus 2Q, can you just talk about the factors that will drive that?
componenttext: And then the better gross margin guidance for 3Q versus 2Q, can you just talk about the factors that will drive that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we felt that we had a particularly difficult May. I think part of it was everybody experienced unseasonable weather early in the quarter, and we're more encouraged as we got into the latter part of June and July. And since weather now is quite warm
componenttext: Well, we felt that we had a particularly difficult May. I think part of it was everybody experienced unseasonable weather early in the quarter, and we're more encouraged as we got into the latter part of June and July. And since weather now is quite warm particularly, rare now and seasonal goods are selling well. We think one of our strengths is back-to-school. And most of back-to-school is in front of us and in the third quarter, so we feel good about back-to-school and feel good about holiday. I think if there's any caution, it's what's facing the American family, whether it's the continuation of employment that is not growing as fast as the new entrants or housing and volatility brought on by the political process and other factors.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Klinefelter with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Klinefelter with Piper Jaffray.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions about the supply chain, Mike. In terms of coming back from your supplier summit recently, could you share any perspective on what you're seeing out of the import community in terms of costs, labor trends, raw material trends, et
componenttext: Just a couple of questions about the supply chain, Mike. In terms of coming back from your supplier summit recently, could you share any perspective on what you're seeing out of the import community in terms of costs, labor trends, raw material trends, et cetera? And then also, what sort of inventory flexibility do you have for the second half of the year both up and down at this point, given the low visibility for comp trends for the industry at this point?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we as you know, we believe we have a real strength in our partnership with our international suppliers. I think we benefited from having virtually no cost increases in the first half. And I would argue that our cost impact on the second half of the
componenttext: Well, we as you know, we believe we have a real strength in our partnership with our international suppliers. I think we benefited from having virtually no cost increases in the first half. And I would argue that our cost impact on the second half of the year is probably more muted than most. We got ahead of it. I think we benefited from suppliers helping us with managing production during down periods. But there's no question the cost of cotton impacted everyone particularly in categories like home or the portion of the good is much higher in cotton. Cotton prices are coming down or have come down. So we're a bit more optimistic in the second half of spring, that we'll get back to a more normalized cost structure. We believe that our suppliers have worked very hard with us to optimize the way we buy, in terms of what portion of the assortment, at which price points. And in terms of the visibility to what we have in the back half, we feel we have the right goods en route. There's not much flexibility of changing quantity, this close to the end of the year. But we're buying in the middle of spring at this point, and we feel good about our ability to work with suppliers to continue our competitive advantage in terms of sourcing, as well as private brand. Private brand sales improvement continues to exceed national brand selling and our GP and private brand continues to exceed national brand GP.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. One other question. You mentioned that the later back-to-school season is leading you to forecast a slightly lower August comp versus your quarterly guidance. And can you just share a little bit on what the analytics are going into that estimate? Ar
componenttext: Okay. One other question. You mentioned that the later back-to-school season is leading you to forecast a slightly lower August comp versus your quarterly guidance. And can you just share a little bit on what the analytics are going into that estimate? Are you seeing anything in terms of the early back-to-school seasons that give you confidence that you will see an acceleration toward the end of the month or how are you formulating that thesis?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: For the last several years, it's really been almost 2 or 3 days a year average shift to the center of back-to-school. Last year, it was quite strong around Labor Day and actually after Labor Day. We think part of this is buying closer to the needs, so may
componenttext: For the last several years, it's really been almost 2 or 3 days a year average shift to the center of back-to-school. Last year, it was quite strong around Labor Day and actually after Labor Day. We think part of this is buying closer to the needs, so maybe the mom ends up buying the coat after Labor Day, when she feels like the pricing is better. It's really, assess what she bought versus what the child needs for back-to-school. So we're just reflecting what our experience has been last several years. And of course, the tax-free shopping has not shifted much this year. So that's not a big factor. It's pretty comparable to last year.

componenttext: Well, in terms of the balance? In the second quarter, our transactions were up. Unit sales were up. As I mentioned, we said, we had a modest decrease in AUR. Our units per transaction is down modestly and dollars per transaction down modestly. So that's pretty much the arithmetic.

componenttextpreview: Well, we were down slightly in Q2 as well. So I would say some of the same factors apply, meaning the transition we're taking through the catalog out, which had a negative impact on margins. I would say also, just overall the mix of business and dot-com b
componenttext: Well, we were down slightly in Q2 as well. So I would say some of the same factors apply, meaning the transition we're taking through the catalog out, which had a negative impact on margins. I would say also, just overall the mix of business and dot-com being so heavily skewed toward big-ticket home. I think our optimism on GP as the sell-through of  fresh merchandise and the flow of goods. So I think that we're cautiously optimistic, it will be slightly better than the second quarter.

componenttext: Yes. The levels of inventory is quite satisfactory. We're about 2% over last year, which is well in line with our forward guidance on sales.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, can you talk about a bit about the home department and some maybe new thoughts around marketing there, maybe thoughts on trying to do something to offset some of the losses from discontinuing the catalog?
componenttext: And then, can you talk about a bit about the home department and some maybe new thoughts around marketing there, maybe thoughts on trying to do something to offset some of the losses from discontinuing the catalog?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the clunky part of our transitional catalog is affecting us more in dot-com than we anticipated because apparently the catalog customers spent a lot of time entering their orders online, and we've been slow to be able to talk to them in a direct-mail
componenttext: Yes, the clunky part of our transitional catalog is affecting us more in dot-com than we anticipated because apparently the catalog customers spent a lot of time entering their orders online, and we've been slow to be able to talk to them in a direct-mail way. But the big pluses in home have been in luggage, in housewares and the soft part of home, bedding and bath. We believe that our print media going forward is going to be more targeted to not only the existing store customer but also to pick up those home customers that used to shop us in catalog. They are very willing to shop with us online. So those are the main things. And we have some new leadership in the furniture business, that we're excited about the prospects there. But there's no doubt that the American families are having difficulties in wanting to invest in big-ticket home during this economic situation.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dana Telsey with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dana Telsey with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little bit of an update on more color on any of the growth brands, and also in particular the Foundry. How is it doing relative to plan and growth initiatives store openings?
componenttext: Can you give us a little bit of an update on more color on any of the growth brands, and also in particular the Foundry. How is it doing relative to plan and growth initiatives store openings?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let's start with the Foundry. The Foundry has 10 stores opened at this point. We've seen excellent sell-through, several stores are hitting the 3- to 5-year productivity in the first couple of months. We think the mall stores seemed to be performing
componenttext: Well, let's start with the Foundry. The Foundry has 10 stores opened at this point. We've seen excellent sell-through, several stores are hitting the 3- to 5-year productivity in the first couple of months. We think the mall stores seemed to be performing at a much better rate than the 3 mall stores we opened. But I would say the customer reaction, our customer service scores are in the 80s, which is -- we're highly satisfied. So we feel like we have a very responsive customer to what we're doing. We'll be evaluating that over the next several months in terms of the rate of opening new stores. Our other growth initiatives, we have 2 stores opening this year and one is already opened in Maryland. We have a store opening in Skillman, in Central Dallas here in about 6 or 7 weeks. Our growth initiatives again, as mentioned, we believe we'll get double-digit improvements in selling and the growth initiatives in the back half as we've experienced, Liz Claiborne, Sephora, Mango, Call it Spring, Modern Bride. Those are the things that are driving the growth.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Bernard Sosnick with Gilford Securities.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Bernard Sosnick with Gilford Securities.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a timeline to clarify catalog? You've been out of catalog a year now. And could you give us a timeline in terms of the impact on sales by half, and when you expect the impact to more or less disappear?
componenttext: Could you give us a timeline to clarify catalog? You've been out of catalog a year now. And could you give us a timeline in terms of the impact on sales by half, and when you expect the impact to more or less disappear?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bernie, just to correct the record, that we've been out  of the 3 Big Books for a year now, we had 75 other books. And frankly, the separate home books that were fairly effective had a bigger impact on dot-com than we had planned. We have about a $400 mil
componenttext: Bernie, just to correct the record, that we've been out  of the 3 Big Books for a year now, we had 75 other books. And frankly, the separate home books that were fairly effective had a bigger impact on dot-com than we had planned. We have about a $400 million sales lost this year from catalog business is non-comparable and we'll be out of it completely by the end of the year. We started, I think, we went dark on catalog completely toward the fourth quarter of last year. So while it's not helpful in terms of our visibility and transforming this area of our business, but we do believe going forward, it's the right thing to do. It was still quite profitable at a very high margins but the problem was it was dropping like a rock. So question one, do you want to take the hit and move on to a way the customer wants to shop going forward. And it's quite clear, that was not. The customers are really shopping online and use the catalog for a view book, but the catalog postage and print and producing billions of pages of print was not the most productive way to go forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: You also mentioned that there's still an ongoing impact on gross margin from the catalog decision. And that it might impact third quarter. Why is that ongoing, and when might that moderate?
componenttext: You also mentioned that there's still an ongoing impact on gross margin from the catalog decision. And that it might impact third quarter. Why is that ongoing, and when might that moderate?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, transitioning out of a clearance mode, which used to be cleared outlet stores to lining our assortments, so we can clear catalog -- formerly was catalog merch, it was now online merchandise clearing it through our regular stores. So there's some non
componenttext: Well, transitioning out of a clearance mode, which used to be cleared outlet stores to lining our assortments, so we can clear catalog -- formerly was catalog merch, it was now online merchandise clearing it through our regular stores. So there's some noncomparability in that process. We'll be through that by the end of the fall as well. So these are transformational issues that are clunky but necessary.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the reduction in expenses in the second quarter, let's call it, the first half of '11. How much of that might have been attributable to the elimination of Big Books, if any?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's a little bit of that would be related to the print media but the majority of the savings was in salary effectiveness, as well as marketing optimization. And those areas, we plan to make improvements, as well as home office expense. So I think it w
componenttext: There's a little bit of that would be related to the print media but the majority of the savings was in salary effectiveness, as well as marketing optimization. And those areas, we plan to make improvements, as well as home office expense. So I think it was well-managed and we actually had lower dollars than a year ago by I think, $35 million, which is given all the renovations initiatives and things that we did, including all of our comp adjustments is a good record.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And finally, since so much of your Internet business was coming through catalog and catalog customers on average are older than typical Internet customers, what programs do you have to bring on new younger customers and how effective has that been?
componenttext: And finally, since so much of your Internet business was coming through catalog and catalog customers on average are older than typical Internet customers, what programs do you have to bring on new younger customers and how effective has that been?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the encouraging thing, Bernie, is that we have 27 million people that shop our stores for fashion that didn't shop online because we didn't have the same merchandise online. So we now have aligned our assortments and we're getting, I think,
componenttext: Well, I think the encouraging thing, Bernie, is that we have 27 million people that shop our stores for fashion that didn't shop online because we didn't have the same merchandise online. So we now have aligned our assortments and we're getting, I think, something in the range of 12% to 20% increases on the apparel categories online now. That is yet, as you point out, that is a younger customer. So we don't think there's any inhibition to shopping with us online. They're actually were buying our goods in the store but shop somebody else online. So we still have a very robust dot-com business. It's just not growing overall because the 51% of it is home. And as the home furnishings and soft home, take hold and we get better print media directed to this former catalog customers, we feel that we'll get to double-digit  dot-com overall.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Some other retailers have reported positive sales in home, soft goods, small appliances. What has been your experience both in the stores and catalog?
componenttext: Some other retailers have reported positive sales in home, soft goods, small appliances. What has been your experience both in the stores and catalog?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said earlier, we're up double digit in luggage, housewares, bedding, bath, all are very strong positive comps. The only 2 areas in home which are down are frankly, the window covering at furniture. Furniture is down 20%. So those are the things
componenttext: Well, as I said earlier, we're up double digit in luggage, housewares, bedding, bath, all are very strong positive comps. The only 2 areas in home which are down are frankly, the window covering at furniture. Furniture is down 20%. So those are the things that are dragging down the overall home business.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: So your greater exposure to the big-ticket items...
componenttext: So your greater exposure to the big-ticket items...

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're not ashamed of having big ticket. It's just in this environment, if you don't build a lot of new homes, you don't need as many window coverings. And people can defer a purchase of changing their window covering. So we think it's an ongoing strength
componenttext: We're not ashamed of having big ticket. It's just in this environment, if you don't build a lot of new homes, you don't need as many window coverings. And people can defer a purchase of changing their window covering. So we think it's an ongoing strength overall. But at the moment, it's not helpful.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011

componenttext: Our next question is from Charles Grom with Deutsche Bank.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just -- can you give us a little bit of update on some of the more recent brand launches over the past few year, it's been a while since we've heard from you guys on American Living, and if you could also touch on Mango and how that's doing in stores?
componenttext: Just -- can you give us a little bit of update on some of the more recent brand launches over the past few year, it's been a while since we've heard from you guys on American Living, and if you could also touch on Mango and how that's doing in stores?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there have been a number over the last couple of years. I'll just focus on the ones that have been in the last year. Claiborne is our biggest. We're well over our early expectations and frankly, keep increasing our future commitments. We think that
componenttext: Well, there have been a number over the last couple of years. I'll just focus on the ones that have been in the last year. Claiborne is our biggest. We're well over our early expectations and frankly, keep increasing our future commitments. We think that is resonating not only in the categories we were in before we went to the parent Liz Claiborne brand but we're also expanding categories, that's gone very well. I think the MNG by Mango is 77 stores last year. And as I mentioned in my remarks, we'll be up to 500 stores by fall. It's getting great registration with the customer. The pricing is very sharp compared to other fast fashion concepts, we're the only department store that has true fast fashion in the store and is attracting the 18- to 35-year-old customer segment that we are focused on. Call it Spring, again, very much modern shoe assortment that's attracting a younger demographic. We're way ahead of our expectations there across women's handbags and men's. Sephora continues to be double-digit comps and a leading brand launch. Our Modern Bride has been a pleasant surprise in terms of our engagement jewelry business, up over 20% comp, as we rolled that out. American Living continues to be one of the top 10 brands. It's obviously more classic and traditional than some of the other that are focused more in the younger customer. So we feel very good. As I said, we only had growth initiatives, we'd be up double-digit comps. So the other part of the business obviously is the -- more of the basic business that during a difficult economic climate, customers can defer.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, looking ahead given the upcoming transition to Ron. How is the merchandising team work in that environment? Does it stall any new brand launches as you look ahead over the next 12 months? Or are the chief merchants still looking to bring
componenttext: Great. And then, looking ahead given the upcoming transition to Ron. How is the merchandising team work in that environment? Does it stall any new brand launches as you look ahead over the next 12 months? Or are the chief merchants still looking to bring in some new brands in spring and into next fall?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have a full agenda of initiatives going forward, as you can imagine. And Ron is very well aware of what's in progress and he'll obviously have his own point of view. But we're all very excited about his leadership. We've been working on several years t
componenttext: We have a full agenda of initiatives going forward, as you can imagine. And Ron is very well aware of what's in progress and he'll obviously have his own point of view. But we're all very excited about his leadership. We've been working on several years to attract Ron.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then one question near term, both Kohl's and Macy's kind of share with us their elasticity assumptions here over the next quarter or 2. And I was wondering, if you could as well. And then also share with us any results from any of the tests tha
componenttext: Great. And then one question near term, both Kohl's and Macy's kind of share with us their elasticity assumptions here over the next quarter or 2. And I was wondering, if you could as well. And then also share with us any results from any of the tests that you guys may have done in the spring in terms of changes in price.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that main learning was that the customer did not have much elasticity desire at the opening price points. The sharp opening price points were important to them. And that's continue to be the case and they responded very well particularly in Father
componenttext: I think that main learning was that the customer did not have much elasticity desire at the opening price points. The sharp opening price points were important to them. And that's continue to be the case and they responded very well particularly in Father's Day and early back-to-school. I think there has been some willingness to pay a bit more for something that was fashionable and new and that's encouraging to us. I think the good news is our costs of goods is such that I don't think we have to go up as much as some of our key competitors to meet our objectives. So while we plan units down modestly, that means we don't have to go quite as much up in price to meet our overall objectives, but time will tell. This is a difficult unprecedented period of time, there hasn't been apparel inflation in 20 years. So we expect in this environment, there'll be a lot of learning by each of our competitors and us.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And your last question comes from Michelle Clark with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And your last question comes from Michelle Clark with Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: Well,  I said there were 77 catalogs, only 3 of them were Big Books. So I would say that 2010 and 2009, was the historic high gross profit for the company. componenttext: Okay. And then last question is, if sales do slow in the back half year and come in below plan, how much room do you have to pull back on expenses, particularly given that you had cut expenses aggressively in the back half of 2010?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: We think our ongoing expense program will continue to be a favorable impact on the P&L. I think it's fair to say that, I mean, if you look at the GDP numbers, personal consumption in the first quarter was up 210 basis points and the second quarter was fla
componenttext: We think our ongoing expense program will continue to be a favorable impact on the P&L. I think it's fair to say that, I mean, if you look at the GDP numbers, personal consumption in the first quarter was up 210 basis points and the second quarter was flat. And I would say our mall discretionary traffic is pretty much the same, 200 basis points decline in discretionary mall traffic. So as we look at the back half, I think anybody that looks at it carefully will say, it's almost better to be cautious about. While we don't think we're going back into a recession, we believe the customer has reason to be concerned about the ability to spend more than they have planned. And that's our caution on comp sales forecasting, as well as GP.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays. Thank you. Ms. Hays, you may
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays. Thank you. Ms. Hays, you may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney's second quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the P
componenttext:
Thank you. And thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney's second quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and the company's future results of operations could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also please note that no portion of this call may be rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of J. C. Penney. Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after August 12, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have 2 speakers: first, Mike Ullman, J. C. Penney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Michael Dastugue, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Michael and I are going to keep our comments brief this morning so we'll have more time for your questions. Overall, there a few main points I'd like to make. First of all, while the top line sales number was
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Michael and I are going to keep our comments brief this morning so we'll have more time for your questions. Overall, there a few main points I'd like to make. 
First of all, while the top line sales number was softer than initially planned, we effectively managed expenses, maintained our strong liquidity position and continued to transition our storefront of products and brands to excite existing customers and attract new customers. Second, our focus on building attractions to becoming a destination for discovering great style is taking hold. 
Our identified growth initiatives, Liz Claiborne, Sephora inside jcpenney, our tops business, modern shoes and handbags, fast fashion, Modern Bride fine jewelry, housewares and center core are performing double-digit ahead of last year. With transactions being up 6.4% and our AUR essentially flat during the quarter, we're not trading down our business, trading down our quality or trading down our price but rather, we're trading up our attractions. 
We see opportunity to grow sales by improving the productivity in our existing stores and jcp.com, with the continued success of our growth initiatives and exclusive attractions like Liz Claiborne, Sephora inside jcpenney, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring by ALDO. 
In the second quarter, we opened 22 Sephora inside jcpenney locations and another 21 had a grand opening today, bringing our total locations to 297. Additionally, in the next few weeks, we'll have a total of 405 Call it Spring locations and 487 MNG by Mango locations, reinforcing jcpenney as a style destination. 
As part of our $650 million 2011 capital expenditures program, we also completed approximately 500 store updates and 20 major renovations during the quarter, including the largest renovation in our company's history at the jcpenney Roosevelt Field store in Long Island. Our ongoing renovation program, which is being rolled out across our fleet of stores, is a key component of our transformation plan designed to make our stores more exciting and to continue to improve our sales per square foot productivity. 
Turning now to our operational effectiveness initiatives. During the quarter, we accelerated the actions we are taking to significantly improve our expense structure. This is part of a multiyear operational effectiveness program that we put in place almost 2 years ago to reengineer our business, which will allow us to achieve our 5-year earnings target by 2014. 
As we stated in our first quarter press release, we expect to realize $50 million expense savings in fiscal 2011. $10 million was realized in the first quarter, with $7 million saved in the second quarter. The remaining $33 million in savings will occur in the back half, primarily in the fourth quarter. Year-to-date, we've gotten out of the Catalog business, announced the closure of our clearance outlets, reorganized our supply chain and custom decorating operations, we're ensuring our marketing spend is productive, competitive and effective, we're rolling out new process improvement technologies like RFID, mark down and price optimization and we launched the new digital platform. Additionally, we're looking at the design and structure of our entire organization to ensure we have the right people in the right roles to reflect our future growth opportunities. In some situations, primarily at the home office, we will staff organizations differently to meet the changing needs of our business. 
Part of the organizational redesign includes a voluntary early retirement program for select associates who have spent at least 20 years in the company, are active participants in our pension fund and are 55 years of age or above. This voluntary program is designed to provide eligible participants enhanced retirement benefits in exchange for voluntarily separating from the company. By making these changes, we will create opportunities to improve our processes and do things better, faster and more efficiently. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Michael, who will provide the numbers related to our business during the second quarter. Michael?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported $0.07 in earnings per share, in line with our most recent guidance. Starting with our top line. Once again, our growth initiatives and sales of our private and exclusive brands drove th
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported $0.07 in earnings per share, in line with our most recent guidance. 
Starting with our top line. Once again, our growth initiatives and sales of our private and exclusive brands drove the business as the company's comparable store sales grew 1.5% in the second quarter. Year-to-date, comp store sales are up 2.7% over last year. 
Total sales for the quarter declined slightly to $3.9 billion, largely reflecting the elimination of our Catalog business last year. Gross margin in the second quarter was negatively impacted by the softer-than-expected selling environment in May and June, which resulted in more promotional activity and more markdowns in the quarter. Compared to last year's historical peak, gross margin decreased approximately 110 basis points to 38.3% of sales. 
SG&A for the quarter came in better than guidance, decreasing $32 million year-over-year to $1.24 billion or 31.8% of sales. Lower-than-planned SG&A was primarily driven by effective management of our store labor hours and various home office savings initiatives. These items offset moderate expense increases related to the expansion of Sephora inside jcpenney, as well as startup costs associated with our growth brands division. 
Also our effective tax rate, 41.7%, was slightly higher than expected, largely due to the changes in certain state tax laws that took effect this year. We ended the second quarter with approximately $1.6 billion in cash and short-term investments and our free cash flow has improved approximately $90 million year-over-year. 
Capital expenditures through the second quarter were $295 million, in line with our expectations, and we continue to anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $650 million. We ended the quarter with our inventory up 2.3%, in line with our projected sales trend for the upcoming quarter. 
Now let me share with you our planning assumptions for the third quarter. We expect comp store sales will grow 2% to 3% in the third quarter. On a monthly basis, we expect August sales will be below this range as back-to-school selling season is starting later again this year, with customers continuing their pattern of shopping closer to need. 
September should be roughly in line with our quarterly guidance, while October is expected to be a bit better. The gross margin rate is expected to be down slightly in the third quarter. Reflecting our focus on expense management, we are expecting SG&A to be flat to slightly lower year-over-year, even with the additional expenses we expect to incur related to the expansions of Sephora inside jcpenney, MNG by Mango and Call it Spring. 
The real estate and other line is expected to reflect the net expense of about $11 million with $19 million of restructuring charges flowing through that line item. Taking all of these assumptions into account for the third quarter earnings, we expect to be in the range of $0.15 to $0.20 per share including previously disclosed charges of approximately $0.05 per share. 
Also as Mike mentioned, in our ongoing effort to reduce expenses and streamline operations, we have begun a Voluntary Early Retirement Program, or so-called VERP. Eligible associates will have between September 1 and October 15 to decide if they want to participate in the program. We will release the number of associates who have elected to participate in the program, as well as the operational efficiencies resulting from this program later in the year, likely with our third quarter earnings release. Our current Q3 earnings guidance does not include any impact from the VERP, but we will update you on the earnings impact later in the quarter as appropriate. 
Additionally, we may also incur additional onetime charges in the third quarter arising from the possible sale of the company's clearance outlet stores to a third party but that impact has not been included in our current guidance. As you recall, earlier this year we announced the plan to close the 19 outlet stores over the course of this year and next year. However, we are currently in negotiations to sell these outlet stores to a third party, which may result in acceleration of some of the previously announced charges and would be incurred in the third quarter. We will keep you updated as appropriate on the impact of this potential sale. 
So to be clear, we currently expect Q3 earnings to be in the range of $0.15 to $0.20 per share, including the previously disclosed restructuring charges of approximately $0.05. And this guidance does not include the impact of the VERP or the sale of the outlet stores. 
As to the full year guidance, because the full year earnings impact resulting from our Voluntary Early Retirement Program, the ongoing restructuring initiatives and other home office initiatives including the changes in leadership, it is yet to be determined and because we expect the consumer environment to remain uncertain, we believe it is prudent to provide guidance for the fourth quarter and full year, when visibility into these matters has improved. As such, we are not providing full year outlook at this time. 
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Consumer climate is clearly uncertain and the tumultuous last 10 days or so hasn't given our core customer, the middle-income family, any reason to be more confident. Due to our compelling value proposition now more than ever, our ab
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Consumer climate is clearly uncertain and the tumultuous last 10 days or so hasn't given our core customer, the middle-income family, any reason to be more confident. 
Due to our compelling value proposition now more than ever, our ability to offer great style and quality at compelling prices is sustainable, competitive advantage. Encouraging to us is our recent customer scorecard for the second quarter. We've had a significant improvement in price perception and value delivered to the consumer. We also scored the largest increase in store for me, styles I like, new styles every time I visit and overall update and style for the store. Therefore, we remain cautiously optimistic about the back half of the year, especially as we head into the height of the back-to-school selling season, as well as fall and holiday. 
With our high penetration of private brands that continue to grow faster than the rest of the store and our high margin businesses, we have a unique ability to offer our customers quality merchandise at very sharp prices, while protecting our margins. 
We are continuing to build on the accomplishments we set in motion almost 2 years ago, which were focused on 4 key areas: First, we're continuing to assert our style authority by delivering great style credibility, with a balance of the best private and national brands. Second, we're delivering on memorable customer interactions with the help of our highly engaged associates, who inspire discovery and build loyalty with our customers. Third, we're increasing our reach through digital experiences that are personalized and impactful. And fourth, we're taking significant steps to drive profitable growth with a focus on improving our operational effectiveness. 
Our focus on reengineering our business will allow us to achieve the 2014 earnings target we set out last year, and move us closer toward our goal of being a retail industry leader. 
Before I open the call for questions, I'd like to give you an update on Ron Johnson. As planned, Ron joined our Board of Directors on August 1. And Ron and I have been visiting stores and he took a trip with me to Asia for our supplier summit and individual meetings with key suppliers. Our time together has been and will continue to be very productive, and we're all looking forward to getting Ron here full time as CEO on November 1. 
With that, operator, we'll take your questions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Deborah Weinswig with Citi.
