componenttext: Can you provide us additional color on the gross margin guidance? What levels of promotional activities is baked into that guidance, and how important is the new optimization technology to the guidance?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Part of our margin story in the first half has been the difficult conversion away from the catalog business and its effect on dot-com. So part of our caution is we still feel we're in the middle of that transformation. Over half of our dot-com business to
componenttext: Part of our margin story in the first half has been the difficult conversion away from the catalog business and its effect on dot-com. So part of our caution is we still feel we're in the middle of that transformation. Over half of our dot-com business today is the home business and big-ticket home is the most troubled of our businesses. So while we're getting good sell-through on fresh merchandise, as a matter of fact, we continue to see very sharp price points being bestsellers, as well as the newness and fashion and Sephora actually is the highest trending business in the store. So we're optimistic about our ability to maintain margins, but we still have the drag a bit of our dot-com business. So I would say in the first half and particularly in the second quarter, half of our decline in margin to last year was the effect of dot-com.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, can you talk about your pricing philosophy in this environment, and what are you experiencing with regard to pricing elasticity?
componenttext: And then, can you talk about your pricing philosophy in this environment, and what are you experiencing with regard to pricing elasticity?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well as we've messaged earlier, we believe we got ahead of this by our strength in sourcing and our ability to test over a year ago. Our view is that the customer expects the sharp price points. In this economic environment, we've been able to maintain th
componenttext: Well as we've messaged earlier, we believe we got ahead of this by our strength in sourcing and our ability to test over a year ago. Our view is that the customer expects the sharp price points. In this economic environment, we've been able to maintain those. I'm sure that had some impact on the customer scorecard in terms of perception of price. At the same time, we think we can get modest price improvement in the middle of our assortments, where fashion is driving the business and where the customer sees the value of something that's relevant to what they are wanting at this timeframe. So we will continue to look at somewhat less unit selling in the fall season but at higher average unit at retail. So I think our average unit at retail will be a competitive advantage in this environment.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, based on your same-store sales, I was very impressed with your SG&A leverage. Can you assess some of your ongoing SG&A initiatives outside the $50 million in expense savings you experienced in the quarter and that we will see in the
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, based on your same-store sales, I was very impressed with your SG&A leverage. Can you assess some of your ongoing SG&A initiatives outside the $50 million in expense savings you experienced in the quarter and that we will see in the third quarter as well?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we have 9 different initiatives that are attacking SG&A and some long-term program that will be played out over the next several years. Our view is that marketing effectiveness is one of our key initiatives and part of that is again, is the transiti
componenttext: Well, we have 9 different initiatives that are attacking SG&A and some long-term program that will be played out over the next several years. Our view is that marketing effectiveness is one of our key initiatives and part of that is again, is the transition away from the traditional catalog business into more print media that's directed across stores, as well as dot-com. As mentioned about our voluntary early retirement program, that has a positive effect on SG&A that we are looking forward to. We won't know the full impact of that until people voluntarily step forward and say they want to participate. We continue to look at ways to improve our processes in the store, as well as in home office by redesigning work. We are looking at our non-merchandise procurement, where we can save in terms of purchasing paper, print and other commodity items. So it's a comprehensive program, we believe, given the impact of the recession on virtually every business that faces the consumer, but we need to get our cost structure in line to be able to leverage, to get improved bottom line results and that's integral to our 5-year plan.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: You discussed how challenging and uncertain the consumer environment is. Can you talk about what you expect the comp drivers to be in the back half to cause the acceleration from the second quarter and then also the acceleration within the third quarter?
componenttext: You discussed how challenging and uncertain the consumer environment is. Can you talk about what you expect the comp drivers to be in the back half to cause the acceleration from the second quarter and then also the acceleration within the third quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: What's been driving the business all year and our comp improvement in the first half has been driven by our growth initiatives. And as mentioned, those include Sephora, the tops business, the modern assortments, the intimate apparel business. Those are th
componenttext: What's been driving the business all year and our comp improvement in the first half has been driven by our growth initiatives. And as mentioned, those include Sephora, the tops business, the modern assortments, the intimate apparel business. Those are the young businesses; those businesses have been quite encouraging. There's over 12% comp in the aggregate of those initiatives in the first half, we expect those to continue. Liz Claiborne has been extremely successful, well beyond our projection. We see no reason why these would slow down in the back half. Our opening price point assortments are selling through very much at or above plan. The toughest businesses frankly have been in the middle of the basics assortments. I think customers in this economic environment have just decided to slow down on kind of the routine purchasing, and they're focused on fashion and price points that meet their family budget in this economic environment.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the better gross margin guidance for 3Q versus 2Q, can you just talk about the factors that will drive that?
componenttext: And then the better gross margin guidance for 3Q versus 2Q, can you just talk about the factors that will drive that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we felt that we had a particularly difficult May. I think part of it was everybody experienced unseasonable weather early in the quarter, and we're more encouraged as we got into the latter part of June and July. And since weather now is quite warm,
componenttext: Well, we felt that we had a particularly difficult May. I think part of it was everybody experienced unseasonable weather early in the quarter, and we're more encouraged as we got into the latter part of June and July. And since weather now is quite warm, particularly rare now and seasonal goods are selling well, we think one of our strengths is back-to-school. And most of back-to-school is in front of us and in the third quarter, so we feel good about back-to-school and feel good about holiday. I think if there's any caution, it's what's facing the American family, whether it's the continuation of employment that is not growing as fast as the new entrants or housing and volatility brought on by the political process and other factors.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Klinefelter with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Klinefelter with Piper Jaffray.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions about the supply chain, Mike. In terms of coming back from your supplier summit recently, could you share any perspective on what you're seeing out of the import community in terms of costs, labor trends, raw material trends, et
componenttext: Just a couple of questions about the supply chain, Mike. In terms of coming back from your supplier summit recently, could you share any perspective on what you're seeing out of the import community in terms of costs, labor trends, raw material trends, et cetera? And then also, what sort of inventory flexibility do you have for the second half of the year both up and down at this point, given the low visibility for comp trends for the industry at this point?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well we, as you know, we believe we have a real strength in our partnership with our international suppliers. I think we benefited from having virtually no cost increases in the first half. And I would argue that our cost impact on the second half of the
componenttext: Well we, as you know, we believe we have a real strength in our partnership with our international suppliers. I think we benefited from having virtually no cost increases in the first half. And I would argue that our cost impact on the second half of the year is probably more muted than most. We got ahead of it. I think we benefited from suppliers helping us with managing production during down periods. But there's no question the cost of cotton impacted everyone, particularly in categories like home, where the portion of the good is much higher in cotton. Cotton prices are coming down or have come down. So we're a bit more optimistic in the second half of spring that we'll get back to a more normalized cost structure. We believe that our suppliers have worked very hard with us to optimize the way we buy, in terms of what portion of the assortment at which price points. And in terms of the visibility to what we have in the back half, we feel we have the right goods en route. There's not much flexibility of changing quantities this close to the end of the year, but we're buying in the middle of spring at this point, and we feel good about our ability to work with suppliers to continue our competitive advantage in terms of sourcing, as well as private brand. Private brand sales improvement continues to exceed national brand selling and our GP and private brand continues to exceed national brand GP.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. One other question. You mentioned that the later back-to-school season is leading you to forecast a slightly lower August comp versus your quarterly guidance. And can you just share a little bit on what the analytics are going into that estimate? Ar
componenttext: Okay. One other question. You mentioned that the later back-to-school season is leading you to forecast a slightly lower August comp versus your quarterly guidance. And can you just share a little bit on what the analytics are going into that estimate? Are you seeing anything in terms of the early back-to-school seasons that give you confidence that you will see an acceleration toward the end of the month or how are you formulating that thesis?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: For the last several years, it's really been almost 2 or 3 days a year average shift to the center of back-to-school. Last year, it was quite strong around Labor Day and actually after Labor Day. We think part of this is buying closer to the needs, so may
componenttext: For the last several years, it's really been almost 2 or 3 days a year average shift to the center of back-to-school. Last year, it was quite strong around Labor Day and actually after Labor Day. We think part of this is buying closer to the needs, so maybe the mom ends up buying the coat after Labor Day, when she feels like the pricing is better. It's reassess what she bought versus what the child needs for back-to-school. So we're just reflecting what our experience has been last several years. And of course, the tax-free shopping has not shifted much this year. So that's not a big factor. It's pretty comparable to last year.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Bob Drbul with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from Bob Drbul with Barclays Capital.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, can you help me reconcile the comp a little bit with -- I think you gave, was it AUR? I think it was up 6% -- or transaction is up 6%, AUR flat. What's the other component in there? Just trying to reconcile sort of the comps to your total sales,
componenttext: I guess, can you help me reconcile the comp a little bit with -- I think you gave, was it AUR? I think it was up 6% -- or transaction is up 6%, AUR flat. What's the other component in there? Just trying to reconcile sort of the comps to your total sales, how do you guys calculate that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of the balance? In the second quarter, our transactions were up. Unit sales were up. As I mentioned, we said we had a modest decrease in AUR. Our units per transaction is down modestly and dollars per transaction down modestly. So that's pr
componenttext: Well, in terms of the balance? In the second quarter, our transactions were up. Unit sales were up. As I mentioned, we said we had a modest decrease in AUR. Our units per transaction is down modestly and dollars per transaction down modestly. So that's pretty much the arithmetic.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think then you have to offset it with what's going on in the dot-com and then the elimination of the catalogs, which offset some of that from the total. The statistics Mike's talking to are the ones that impact our stores.
componenttext: Yes, I think then you have to offset it with what's going on in the dot-com and then the elimination of the catalogs, which offset some of that from the total. The statistics Mike's talking to are the ones that impact our stores.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Store basis.
componenttext: Store basis.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. I just have a question, you completed the buyback and you didn't really -- you hadn't announced another authorization. Can you just maybe update us on the board's thinking around the potential for another buyback or when something like that m
componenttext: Okay, great. I just have a question, you completed the buyback and you didn't really -- you hadn't announced another authorization. Can you just maybe update us on the board's thinking around the potential for another buyback or when something like that might be announced?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well typically, we have a capital structure discussion at the beginning of each fiscal year to balance a recommendation on dividend policy, capital expenditures and potential buyback. And I would anticipate that discussion will continue to be focused at t
componenttext: Well typically, we have a capital structure discussion at the beginning of each fiscal year to balance a recommendation on dividend policy, capital expenditures and potential buyback. And I would anticipate that discussion will continue to be focused at the beginning of the fiscal year.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Erika Maschmeyer with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Erika Maschmeyer with Robert W. Baird.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of your gross margin guidance for Q3 were down slightly, could you talk about the factors that are kind of different in Q3 versus Q2 and where you've got incremental confidence?
componenttext: In terms of your gross margin guidance for Q3 were down slightly, could you talk about the factors that are kind of different in Q3 versus Q2 and where you've got incremental confidence?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we were down slightly in Q2 as well, so I would say some of the same factors apply, meaning the transition we're taking through the catalog out, which had a negative impact on margins. I would say also, just overall the mix of business and dot-com b
componenttext: Well, we were down slightly in Q2 as well, so I would say some of the same factors apply, meaning the transition we're taking through the catalog out, which had a negative impact on margins. I would say also, just overall the mix of business and dot-com being so heavily skewed toward big-ticket home. I think our optimism on GP as the sell-through of fresh merchandise and the flow of goods. So I think that we're cautiously optimistic it will be slightly better than the second quarter.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. So you've cleared your inventory and you feel good about the new receipts that you have now?
componenttext: Great. So you've cleared your inventory and you feel good about the new receipts that you have now?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. The level of inventory is quite satisfactory. We're about 2% over last year, which is well in line with our forward guidance on sales.
componenttext: Yes. The level of inventory is quite satisfactory. We're about 2% over last year, which is well in line with our forward guidance on sales.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, can you talk about a bit about the home department and some maybe new thoughts around marketing there, maybe thoughts on trying to do something to offset some of the losses from discontinuing the catalog?
componenttext: And then, can you talk about a bit about the home department and some maybe new thoughts around marketing there, maybe thoughts on trying to do something to offset some of the losses from discontinuing the catalog?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the clunky part of our transitional catalog is affecting us more in dot-com than we anticipated because apparently the catalog customers spent a lot of time entering their orders online, and we've been slow to be able to talk to them in a direct-mail
componenttext: Yes, the clunky part of our transitional catalog is affecting us more in dot-com than we anticipated because apparently the catalog customers spent a lot of time entering their orders online, and we've been slow to be able to talk to them in a direct-mail way. But the big pluses in home have been in luggage, in housewares and the soft part of home, bedding and bath. We believe that our print media going forward is going to be more targeted to not only the existing store customer, but also to pick up those home customers that used to shop us in catalog. They are very willing to shop with us online. So those are the main things. And we have some new leadership in the furniture business that we're excited about the prospects there. But there's no doubt that the American families are having difficulties in wanting to invest in big-ticket home during this economic situation.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dana Telsey with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dana Telsey with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little bit of an update on more color on any of the growth brands, and also in particular the Foundry? How is it doing relative to plan and growth initiatives store openings?
componenttext: Can you give us a little bit of an update on more color on any of the growth brands, and also in particular the Foundry? How is it doing relative to plan and growth initiatives store openings?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well let's start with the Foundry. The Foundry has 10 stores opened at this point. We've seen excellent sell-through; several stores are hitting the 3- to 5-year productivity in the first couple of months. We think the mall stores seem to be performing at
componenttext: Well let's start with the Foundry. The Foundry has 10 stores opened at this point. We've seen excellent sell-through; several stores are hitting the 3- to 5-year productivity in the first couple of months. We think the mall stores seem to be performing at a much better rate than the 3 mall stores we opened. But I would say the customer reaction, our customer service scores are in the 80s, which is -- we're highly satisfied. So we feel like we have a very responsive customer to what we're doing. We'll be evaluating that over the next several months in terms of the rate of opening new stores. Our other growth initiatives, we have 2 stores opening this year and one is already opened in Maryland. We have a store opening in Skillman, in Central Dallas here in about 6 or 7 weeks. Our growth initiatives again, as mentioned, we believe we'll get double-digit improvements in selling and the growth initiatives in the back half as we've experienced; Liz Claiborne, Sephora, Mango, Call it Spring, Modern Bride. Those are the things that are driving the growth.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Bernard Sosnick with Gilford Securities.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Bernard Sosnick with Gilford Securities.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a timeline to clarify catalog? You've been out of catalog a year now. And could you give us a timeline in terms of the impact on sales by half, and when you expect the impact to more or less disappear?
componenttext: Could you give us a timeline to clarify catalog? You've been out of catalog a year now. And could you give us a timeline in terms of the impact on sales by half, and when you expect the impact to more or less disappear?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bernie, just to correct the record, we've been out of the 3 Big Books for a year now, we had 75 other books. And frankly, the separate home books that were fairly effective had a bigger impact on dot-com than we had planned. We have about a $400 million s
componenttext: Bernie, just to correct the record, we've been out of the 3 Big Books for a year now, we had 75 other books. And frankly, the separate home books that were fairly effective had a bigger impact on dot-com than we had planned. We have about a $400 million sales loss this year from catalog business is non-comparable and we'll be out of it completely by the end of the year. We started, I think we went dark on catalog completely toward the fourth quarter of last year. So while it's not helpful in terms of our visibility and transforming this area of our business, but we do believe going forward it's the right thing to do. It was still quite profitable at very high margins, but the problem was it was dropping like a rock. So question when do you want to take the hit and move on to a way the customer wants to shop going forward and it's quite clear to us now the customers are really shopping online and use the catalog for a view book, but the catalog postage and print and producing billions of pages of print was not the most productive way to go forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: You also mentioned that there's still an ongoing impact on gross margin from the catalog decision and that it might impact third quarter. Why is that ongoing, and when might that moderate?
componenttext: You also mentioned that there's still an ongoing impact on gross margin from the catalog decision and that it might impact third quarter. Why is that ongoing, and when might that moderate?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're transitioning out of a clearance mode, which used to be clearing outlet stores to lining our assortments so we can clear catalog -- formerly was catalog merch which is now online merchandise, clearing it through our regular stores. So there's
componenttext: Well, we're transitioning out of a clearance mode, which used to be clearing outlet stores to lining our assortments so we can clear catalog -- formerly was catalog merch which is now online merchandise, clearing it through our regular stores. So there's some non-comparability in that process. We'll be through that by the end of the fall as well. So these are transformational issues which are clunky, but necessary.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the reduction in expenses in the second quarter, let's call it the first half of '11. How much of that might have been attributable to the elimination of Big Books, if any?
componenttext: And the reduction in expenses in the second quarter, let's call it the first half of '11. How much of that might have been attributable to the elimination of Big Books, if any?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's a little bit of that, that would be related to the print media, but the majority of the savings was in salary effectiveness as well as marketing optimization. And those areas we plan to make improvements, as well as home office expense. So I think
componenttext: There's a little bit of that, that would be related to the print media, but the majority of the savings was in salary effectiveness as well as marketing optimization. And those areas we plan to make improvements, as well as home office expense. So I think it was well managed and we actually had lower dollars than a year ago by I think $35 million, which is given all the renovations, initiatives and things that we did, including all of our comp adjustments is a good record.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And finally, since so much of your Internet business was coming through catalog and catalog customers on average are older than typical Internet customers, what programs do you have to bring on new younger customers and how effective has that been?
componenttext: And finally, since so much of your Internet business was coming through catalog and catalog customers on average are older than typical Internet customers, what programs do you have to bring on new younger customers and how effective has that been?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well I think the encouraging thing, Bernie, is that we had 27 million people that shop our stores for fashion that didn't shop online because we didn't have the same merchandise online. So we now have aligned our assortments and we're getting, I think, so
componenttext: Well I think the encouraging thing, Bernie, is that we had 27 million people that shop our stores for fashion that didn't shop online because we didn't have the same merchandise online. So we now have aligned our assortments and we're getting, I think, something in the range of 12% to 20% increases on the apparel categories online now. That is yet, as you point out, that is a younger customer. So we don't think there's any inhibition to shopping with us online. They actually were buying our goods in the store, but shop somebody else online. So we still have a very robust dot-com business, it's just not growing overall because the 51% of it is home. And as the home furnishings and soft home take hold and we get better print media directed to those former catalog customers, we feel that we'll get to double-digit dot-com overall.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Some other retailers have reported positive sales in home, soft goods, small appliances. What has been your experience both in the stores and catalog?
componenttext: Some other retailers have reported positive sales in home, soft goods, small appliances. What has been your experience both in the stores and catalog?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said earlier, we're up double digit in luggage, housewares, bedding, bath; all are very strong positive comps. The only 2 areas in home which are down are frankly window covering and furniture. Furniture is down 20%. So those are the things tha
componenttext: Well, as I said earlier, we're up double digit in luggage, housewares, bedding, bath; all are very strong positive comps. The only 2 areas in home which are down are frankly window covering and furniture. Furniture is down 20%. So those are the things that are dragging down the overall home business.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: So your greater exposure to the big-ticket items...
componenttext: So your greater exposure to the big-ticket items...

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're not ashamed of having big ticket. It's just in this environment, if you don't build a lot of new homes, you don't need as many window coverings. And people can defer a purchase of changing their window covering. So we think it's an ongoing strength
componenttext: We're not ashamed of having big ticket. It's just in this environment, if you don't build a lot of new homes, you don't need as many window coverings. And people can defer a purchase of changing their window covering. So we think it's an ongoing strength overall. But at the moment, it's not helpful.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Charles Grom with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Charles Grom with Deutsche Bank.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just -- can you give us a little bit of update on some of the more recent brand launches over the past few years? It's been a while since we've heard from you guys on American Living, and if you could also touch on Mango and how that's doing in stores?
componenttext: Just -- can you give us a little bit of update on some of the more recent brand launches over the past few years? It's been a while since we've heard from you guys on American Living, and if you could also touch on Mango and how that's doing in stores?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there have been a number over the last couple of years. I'll just focus on the ones that have been in the last year. Claiborne is our biggest. We're well over our early expectations and frankly, keep increasing our future commitments. We think that
componenttext: Well, there have been a number over the last couple of years. I'll just focus on the ones that have been in the last year. Claiborne is our biggest. We're well over our early expectations and frankly, keep increasing our future commitments. We think that is resonating not only in the categories we were in before we went to the parent Liz Claiborne brand, but we're also expanding categories; that's gone very well. I think the MNG by Mango, we had 77 stores last year. And as I mentioned in my remarks, we'll be up to 500 stores by fall. It's getting great registration with the customer. The pricing is very sharp compared to other fast fashion concepts. We're the only department store that has true fast fashion in the store and is attracting the 18- to 35-year-old customer segment that we are focused on. Call it Spring, again, very much a modern shoe assortment that's attracting a younger demographic. We're way ahead of our expectations there across women's handbags and men's. Sephora continues to be double-digit comps and a leading brand launch. Our Modern Bride has been a pleasant surprise in terms of our engagement jewelry business, up over 20% comp, as we rolled that out. American Living continues to be one of the top 10 brands. It's obviously more classic and traditional than some of the other that are focused more in the younger customer. So we feel very good. As I said, if we only had growth initiatives, we'd be up double-digit comps. So the other part of the business obviously is the -- more of the basic business that during a difficult economic climate, customers can defer.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, looking ahead given the upcoming transition to Ron. How does the merchandising team work in that environment? Does it stall any new brand launches as you look ahead over the next 12 months? Or are the chief merchants still looking to brin
componenttext: Great. And then, looking ahead given the upcoming transition to Ron. How does the merchandising team work in that environment? Does it stall any new brand launches as you look ahead over the next 12 months? Or are the chief merchants still looking to bring in some new brands in spring and into next fall?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have a full agenda of initiatives going forward, as you can imagine. And Ron is very well aware of what's in progress and he'll obviously have his own point of view. But we're all very excited about his leadership. We've been working on several years t
componenttext: We have a full agenda of initiatives going forward, as you can imagine. And Ron is very well aware of what's in progress and he'll obviously have his own point of view. But we're all very excited about his leadership. We've been working on several years to attract Ron.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then one question near term, both Kohl's and Macy's kind of share with us their elasticity assumptions here over the next quarter or 2. And I was wondering if you could as well. And then also share with us any results from any of the tests that
componenttext: Great. And then one question near term, both Kohl's and Macy's kind of share with us their elasticity assumptions here over the next quarter or 2. And I was wondering if you could as well. And then also share with us any results from any of the tests that you guys may have done in the spring in terms of changes in price.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that main learning was that the customer did not have much elasticity desire at the opening price points. The sharp opening price points were important to them and that's continued to be the case and they responded very well, particularly in Fathe
componenttext: I think that main learning was that the customer did not have much elasticity desire at the opening price points. The sharp opening price points were important to them and that's continued to be the case and they responded very well, particularly in Father's Day and early back-to-school. I think there has been some willingness to pay a bit more for something that was fashionable and new and that's encouraging to us. I think the good news is our cost of goods is such that I don't think we have to go up as much as some of our key competitors to meet our objectives. So while we plan units down modestly, that means we don't have to go quite as much up in price to meet our overall objectives, but time will tell. This is a difficult unprecedented period of time. There hasn't been apparel inflation in 20 years. So we expect in this environment, there'll be a lot of learning by each of our competitors and us.

componenttext: We think our ongoing expense program will continue to be a favorable impact on the P&L. I think it's fair to say that, I mean if you look at the GDP numbers, personal consumption in the first quarter was up 210 basis points and the second quarter was flat. And I would say our mall discretionary traffic is pretty much the same, 200 basis points decline in discretionary mall traffic. So as we look at the back half, I think anybody that looks at it carefully will say it's almost better to be cautious about. While we don't think we're going back into a recession, we believe the customer has reason to be concerned about the ability to spend more than they have planned. And that's our caution on comp sales forecasting, as well as GP.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relati
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations for J. C. Penney. Thank you, Ms. Hays. You may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christine, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney third quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meanin
componenttext: Thank you, Christine, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review J. C. Penney third quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and the company's future results of operation could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also please note that no portion of this call may be rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of J. C. Penney. Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after November 14, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. Now I'll turn the call over to Mike Ullman.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. There are 3 of us on the call this morning, Michael Dastugue; Ron Johnson and myself. All over the call give you some color on this past quarter as well as our plans for the holiday shopping season. Michae
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. There are 3 of us on the call this morning, Michael Dastugue; Ron Johnson and myself. All over the call give you some color on this past quarter as well as our plans for the holiday shopping season. Michael will as usual give you a greater financial detail including our outlook for the balance of the year. And then Ron will say a few words now that he's officially taken the CEO helm. Let me start with our result for the quarter. 
It continues to be a difficult consumer environment and this was evident in mall traffic during the period, which was down 2.4% in all our sales performance. But our higher income customers responded very well to our attractions. Our moderate income customers delayed efforts to merchandise as they continue to shop closer to need. That said, it's too early to call a trend, we recently seen stronger sales in cold weather apparel and accessories as temperatures across the country became more seasonable. There were some bright spots during the quarter that bear noting. The Liz Claiborne brand remains a standout performer. Sephora is generating strong sales in every location, up double digits for the quarter and year-to-date. And work we've been doing to build our center core business is resonating evident in performance of our women's accessory business. 
We've also made significant progress in our organizational restructuring we began earlier this year, which is designed to reduce expenses and simplify our organization by reducing investments in areas of business that no longer contribute meaningfully to our overall financial performance. This includes the sale during the quarter at 15 outlet stores to SB the capital as well as that we took to reorganize our supply chain network and our initiatives to reduce SG&A expenses throughout the business. It also includes the work we've done to redesign jcpenney  from a people perspective to make our work at all levels of the organization more effective and nimble. As part of this work, we initiated voluntary early retirement program or VERP for associates who have been with the company for more than 20 years and were at least 55 years of age. Mike will provide more detail on the financial impact of this program in a few moments. 
I should note that even though as we focused on these import organizational changes, we have continued to make investments in the attractions to drive our business, including renovating our stores to showcase our attractions like MNG by Mango and Call it Spring by ALDO. 
During the quarter, we opened 405 new Call it Spring by ALDO shoe shops for a total of 505 locations, we opened 208 MNG by Mango shoves for a total now of over 505 stores and we opened additional 31 Sephora inside jcpenney shops for a year and total of 308 locations. 
We also accelerate our, to the Liz Claiborne family brands from Liz Claiborne Inc, so we can capture all the upside from the strong business. And at the same time, we took the opportunity to acquire the Monet fashion jewelry brand from them as well, which we'll launch in jcpenney in the fall of 2012. 
Outside our core jcpenney  brand, we continue to build our growth brand businesses, which include our 2 new additional concepts Gifting Grace and CLAD. Both websites launched last week and our strategic partnerships between JCPenney and the Hearst Corporation. 
Moving on to holiday. We feel very good about our merchandise offering and our gift assortments, which are stronger than ever. While still a tough consumer environment, we've planned our business accordingly and will be stocked at the right levels. This combined with our compelling marketing campaign and high level of consumer service we offer makes jcpenney  once again be positioned as the key holiday gift destination this Christmas season. With that I'll now turn the call over to Mike Dastugue for further information in the quarter. Michael?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings of $0.11 per share excluding restructuring and management transition charges. This was in line with our most recent guidance. A reconciliation of adjusted net income to the
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings of $0.11 per share excluding restructuring and management transition charges. This was in line with our most recent guidance. A reconciliation of adjusted net income to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is included in our release, which is available on our website. 
On a GAAP basis, our EPS this quarter is a loss of $0.67 per share and I will our go on the overall charges related to that loss in a moment. Overall, the quarter was more challenging than we planned. While our SG&A was well managed, sales and gross margins came in below our expectations. That said, we are continuing to take actions necessary to streamline restructuring organization to position us for the next phase of J. C. Penney's  transformation. 
Turning to our Q3 results. Comp store sales declined 1.6% in the third quarter. Year-to-date, comp store sales are up 1.2% over last year. SG&A for the quarter came in better than anticipated, decreasing $84 million year-over-year to $1.24 million from 31.2% of sales. This was driven primarily by our decrease in marketing spend, lower credit costs and benefits realized from our expense reduction initiatives. Gross margin, however, decreased approximately 160 basis points to 37.4% of sales. 
Our gross margin in the third quarter was impacted by the softer-than-expected selling environment which resulted in higher promotional activity and more markdowns in the quarter. We did continue to be in a strong financial position and end of the third quarter with approximately $1.1 billion in cash and short-term investments. 
Capital expenditures to the third quarter were about $469 million in line with our expectations and we continue to anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $650 million. We ended the quarter with our inventory up 2.6%. So now let me take you through some charges we recorded this quarter. 
In aggregate, we reported $265 million of restructuring and administrative transition charges in the third quarter. As you recall, we announced on our second quarter call that J. C. Penney  offered a voluntary early retirement program for approximately 8,200 associates. That program closed on October 15. Close to 4,000 J. C. Penney  associates took advantage of this opportunity to retire from the company with an enhanced financial incentive. With 80% of the cash cost associated with the program being borne by our well-funded pension plan, we recorded a pretax charge of $179 million. 
As associates retire over the next year, we estimate this program to have a favorable impact of approximately $50 million on 2012 operating expenses with a slightly higher benefit realized in 2013. 
Next we reported one-time charges of approximately $30 million related to the sale of our outlet store business to SB Capital in October. This included expenses related to the disposition of inventory and severance for associates. The remaining charges, which are detailed in our earnings release are related to the process improvements in our home office and supply chain as well as management transition expenses. 
Also please note, we have broken out the restructuring and management transition charges this quarter as a separate line item on our P&L. At the same time, we reclassified  2 previous quarters of restructuring charges to conform with the current presentation. As a result, these charges no longer flow in real estate numbers 
Now let me share with you a few of our assumptions for the fourth quarter. We expect comparable store sales to be flat to up slightly in the fourth quarter and gross margins to be down modestly. Our SG&A is expected to be well-managed and slightly below last year's levels. As we continue with our restructuring efforts and transitions in leadership, we expect to incur additional charges in the fourth quarter of approximately $104 million. A portion of these charges will have an impact on our effective tax rate, in other words, they are not tax-deductible in the fourth quarter, which is and therefore, the tax rate will -- and is expected to be approximately 48%. As a result, on approximately $220 million average shares outstanding, we expect fourth quarter earnings before restructuring and management transition charges to be in the range of $1.05 to $1.15 per share. 
On a GAAP basis, including all of the restructuring and management transition charges, earnings for the fourth quarter are now expected to be in a range of $0.64 to $0.74 per share. Additionally, as we stated in our release this morning, we are in the process of executing a meaningful change in the way we approach pricing. Our guidance for the fourth quarter does not include any financial impacts we may incur as a result of these changes. And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Mike

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. While we continue to serve the next few months as Executive Chairman of J. C. Penney, this will be the last of 27 quarterly conference calls that I'll be with you. As Chief Executive of one of America's large retail companies for the p
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. While we continue to serve the next few months as Executive Chairman of J. C. Penney, this will be the last of 27 quarterly conference calls that I'll be with you. As Chief Executive of one of America's large retail companies for the past 7 years and a number of other senior leadership position in the ministry before that, I have had a bird's eyeview of the direct impact the economy has had on our consumers wallets. That's been particularly true here in J. C. Penney as we serve more than half of America's families every year. By the time I joined J. C. Penney  in 2004, almost exactly 7 years ago this month, the company had just completed its turnaround. 
My #1 priority as CEO was to move J. C. Penney  out of the turnaround pace and then grow and begin the transformation of the brand. I'm particularly proud of the success we've achieved in 3 key areas as we've laid a strong foundation for the future of J. C. Penney. 
First, the attractions we've built: Sephora inside jcpenney, MNG by Mango, Call it Spring by ALDO, Modern Bride, People Style Watch and the acquisition of Liz Claiborne brand. These great brands have anchored J. C. Penney  dramatic style transformation and attracted new and younger customers to JCPenney, many of whom never shopped with us in the past. 
Second, customer service. I have enormous respect for our customers who are working hard everyday to provide for their families in spite of with economic challenges. Across our organization, I've seen tremendous dedication to ensure that we are meeting our customers' needs and when we can, making their lives a little easier in the process. 
Customers recognized this commitment and award us 3 years in a row as the #1 department store for customer service in the American Express Customers Choice Survey. 
And third, associate engagement. Over last 7 years we've transformed our culture. J. C. Penney now boasts an associate engagement scores at top of the retail industry and the top quartile U.S. companies, moving from 67% engagement, which is the average of the Gallup poll just a few short years ago to over 80% in 2011. People who work for people, not companies. That's why I want to take this opportunity to thank all of our associates for their tremendous dedication the work we've been together to bring new and exciting brands and attractions to our customers, while making our company a great place to work. 
I'd also like to thank those of you on the call whom I've met and spent time with over the years as you follow J. C. Penney, including of course, our shareholders who placed their fate in the company. I personally and we, as a company, from these interactions. 
As many CEOs will tell you the most important thing they can do in their roles to ensure there's an exceptional successor in place. That's certainly been my priority over the last couple of years. I'm very happy report that we realized that goal and we bring someone with Ron Johnson's caliber to J. C. Penney. 
Ron is one of the most talented retail executives in the United States. And a couple years ago identified as someone who has the right talent and vision and values to take J. C. Penney to the next level and approach him about joining us. Ron told at that point, it wasn't the right time. While I respect his position, it didn't stop us from coming back. And I'm delighted to say this time, it was right. 
Working very closely with Ron over the last 4 months has been very exciting and confirm my belief he's the right person to becoming forward. I'm enthusiastic about his ideas and his vision for the next phase of jcpenney. With that I'll turn the call over to Ron, who will say a few words.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. It is great to officially begin my duties here at JCPenney. While I'm 2 weeks into my tenure, if truth be told, I've spent considerable time with Mike and the teams during the past 4 months preparing for my new role. Mike and I have actua
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. It is great to officially begin my duties here at JCPenney. While I'm 2 weeks into my tenure, if truth be told, I've spent considerable time with Mike and the teams during the past 4 months preparing for my new role. Mike and I have actually traveled throughout the world together, visiting stores and partners and developing strategy for jcpenney to win. I would like to publicly thank Mike for his incredible support during the transition and for his 7 years of service at jcpenney. Many of the things we will do in the years ahead will be built on the very solid foundation created by Mike and the teams during his tenure as CEO in the company. 
Now officially here leading jcpenney, I get more excited every day about the potential for jcpenney. Two weeks ago in November 1, my first day, I addressed all of our associates here in Plano. I told them that I'm not here to improve, I am here to transform. 
I shared with them that as America's first store, it is time to assert leadership, reclaim our birthright and become America's favorite store. The energy, excitement and enthusiasm that I received from our associates was overwhelming. It clearly showed me that they are ready to win. 
As Mike said, success begins with people and jcpenney  has great people, people who I know will be able to think differently and work creatively to take the company into the future. With this background, I'm working with our team to rethink, really to imagine everything we do. I am investing considerable energy and a strategic review of our products, our pricing and our promotional strategies in order to create an exceptional, a new, a better way for people to shop. I'm also want to review of our processes with the goal of simplifying our work so that everything we do will focus on efforts to create long-term value for our shareholders. And most importantly, I'm spending time getting in our teams. 
I feel very fortunate that Michael Francis, who I worked with Target for many years, has come onboard as President to help lead the charge. Michael's talents in merchandising and marketing are unmatched and the chance for him to direct all creative functions in jcpenney  will allow us to truly stand out in the marketplace. His energy level is contagious and the teams are responding immediately to his leadership. And his personal excitement of our joining jcpenney  demonstrates to me that the dream for jcpenney to become America's favorite store is within our grasp. 
Talent is a fuel of any company but especially so in a people-intensive business like retailing. I'm excited to announce this morning the addition of 2 exceptional leaders who will all also be joining jcpenney. This Wednesday, Diane Walker, will join our company as Chief Talent Officer. And on December 5, Mike Kramer will joining JCPenney as Chief Operating Officer. 
I worked with Mike and Diane at Apple and I believe they are 2 of the most talented leaders in the retail industry and I look forward to you getting to know them. Diane Walker has over 3 decades of experience as the most Senior HR Executive in a variety of companies and is a winner. 
He, in the department of our industry and was promoted to VP of HR at the, division at the age of 29. He then led Human Resources at General Mills Specialty Retail Division. In the early 1980s, which at that time included Eddie Bauer, Talbots and 3 other specialty retail stores. He then joined the GAP in 1996, working closely with Mickey and the GAP's presidents to build a talent engine that fuel the growth of the core GAP brand and help launch new concepts including GAP Kids, baby GAP, GAP international and a modernized Banana Republic. The talent supply chain then created and helped establish GAP as a world leader in specialty retail in the early 90s. Dan joined Apple as Chief Talent Officer at the same year I joined Apple. He led and built the global human resources team during a period where we saw the launch of the iPod, iTunes, a world-class Application division and the Apple retail stores. His ability to identify, develop and organize talent is unmatched and he is an unbelievably creative and transformational thinker. 
I am thrilled that I'll get the chance to work side-by-side with Dan again. Mike Kramer is leaving his position as CEO of J. C. Penney  team. At Kellwood, Mike oversaw a portfolio of nearly a dozen fashion brands, including Vans, Scotch and Soda and Rebecca Taylor. Prior to that, he was Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Abercrombie and Fitch. 
I first worked with Mike when he was Vice President of Finance at Apple and CFO of retail stores. Mike joined me when we opened our first store and was there through the first 5 formative years of Apple's retail strategy. Mike is an unusual leader and that he combines extraordinary financial acumen with a strategic business perspective. A certified public accountant, he began his career with financial leadership roles at limited and in various divisions at PepsiCo. Since then he has worked in increasingly strategic roles at Apple, Abercrombie and Kellwood, culminating in his role as the Chief Executive Officer. 
He will bring an extraordinary wealth of experience with winning companies to J. C. Penney. And his most experienced with a wholesale company, managing a portfolio of established and emerging brands will be extremely valuable as we reimagine our merchandise portfolio. 
I am convinced that Michael Francis, Mike Kramer and Dan Walker combined with a talented team I've met and worked within the past 4 months at J. C. Penney  will have the courage, boldness and skill to rethink every aspect of our business as we transform J. C. Penney to become America's favorite store. I know you have a lot of questions about our plans to do that and I can't wait to share them with you. However, my approach will be to only talk publicly about our actions at the time we're taking them, not before. 
So with that, we will start shedding light on our strategic approach in late January when we will hold a meeting in New York for the investment community. We will be sending out invitations in the coming weeks with additional details but please block the morning of January 25 on your calendars. Again, I am the thrilled to officially be here now and look forward to meeting all of you in January. 
Since we'll address all long-term strategy questions in the January event I will turn the call back to Mike and Michael right now to handle the Q&A regarding Q3 performance in Q4 expectations

componenttextpreview: I think we feel very confident about our guidance for the following reasons. First of all, throughout the year are worth initiatives have far exceeded our expectations in terms of comp store growth, particularly Sephora, Claiborne brand, Center Core acces
componenttext: I think we feel very confident about our guidance for the following reasons. First of all, throughout the year are worth initiatives have far exceeded our expectations in terms of comp store growth, particularly Sephora, Claiborne brand, Center Core accessories concepts, tops and things we've identified in the spring. The part of our business has been less helpful in terms of the comps has been the basics business and din the things that people can defer in terms of not needing them right away. The one good thing about the Christmas holiday season is it's a gift-giving time. It is time the mall traffic restaurants tends to serve and those has been the areas where we have had most difficulty. We feel good about the guidance we're giving and obviously, we'd happy to have something above that.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, the last several years, we looked at every aspect of our business, particularly in the headquarters as the ways to improve processes to make ourselves more effective. It's not just about cost cutting. It's about making work simpler and
componenttext: Well, as you know, the last several years, we looked at every aspect of our business, particularly in the headquarters as the ways to improve processes to make ourselves more effective. It's not just about cost cutting. It's about making work simpler and our stores organization, the time management system, the store fore activities, those things have evolved so as in our past. Last several months we've been working on supply-chain improvements as we transitioned out the catalog business, we realized there are a lot of infrastructure, there's more catalog focused instead of dot-com focused. And quite honestly most of the year has been transitioning away from print media from a catalog perspective and more toward online. That has been much more painful than we anticipated. It's more than what we saw in CNBC this morning, housing is in depression not a recession. Half of our Online business and half of our Catalog business was home and that's hurt us. Our .com business margins has been hurt by the home business, which we obviously didn't anticipate would linger in this difficult positions for so long. So most of our process have been redesigned and making people's jobs easier and making more effective.

componenttext: Well, that as you may know is a difficult remodel because there is in the store so it's a very complicated and expensive effort. We're doing extremely well in the New York metro market. We're double digit up in Manhattan. We still feel very strongly that we're underrepresented in that market so we thought it a strategic priority to the field. It's responding very well after the remodel has opened. So we will continue to have a robust renovation remodel strategy every time you put Sephora  in existing jcpenney store, it gives us the opportunity to remodel the center core. We continue to have 75 to 85 new Sephora locations in the coming year. So I think that we can afford to have that many, in our fields per year but we are committed to taking on the most important stores in making sure they're level of ambience our customers expect.

componenttextpreview: Mike, perhaps you could talk a little bit about the margins? Obviously, some contraction of the third quarter and yet the outlook looks for much more moderate through flat to slightly down. You called out that is a promotional environment. Would you expec
componenttext: Mike, perhaps you could talk a little bit about the margins? Obviously, some contraction of the third quarter and yet the outlook looks for much more moderate through flat to slightly down. You called out that is a promotional environment. Would you expect it to change to envision that margin to be a lot less impacted? And then following on that, you have alluded to pricing strategy in preparation for spring of 2012. Maybe if you can give us some insight in terms of what that entails would look forward too.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Adrianne. First is the year coming out of the first quarter, if you look at the mall traffic or if you look at the economy as a whole, we're about 400 basis points below the trendline coming out of the first quarter. So much of our margin compress
componenttext: Thanks, Adrianne. First is the year coming out of the first quarter, if you look at the mall traffic or if you look at the economy as a whole, we're about 400 basis points below the trendline coming out of the first quarter. So much of our margin compression over the last 2 quarters has been getting out of the goods that frankly there was no demand for as the economy gradually down closer to a flat line. We feel that we're past the worst of that. In terms of being able to modify the fourth quarter, we were able to pull back on this as we saw that deceleration. I think as I just mentioned just previously, our .com business was impacted negatively on margins so I'd say be combined about half of the margin miss was in .com, which was the cost of shipping, the home business deterioration and the other half was in markdowns to declare the goods that we felt needed to be in the right stock opposition coming in the fourth quarter. We're very satisfied with what we own today in terms of inventory is appropriate for the fourth quarter. I would say as to the outlook for the fourth quarter, we recently feel more confident about maintaining the margin flat or slightly down. Is that last year we had a very difficult margin for the fourth quarter, so we think we have upside to what would have been a normal fourth quarter that we're facing. I'm not prepared to talk about the go-forward strategy. As Ron mentioned, there's an opportunity to do that at the end of January. Fortunately, Ron and I had a lot of time together and feel very confident that on a forward-looking basis that you'll be very satisfied with the strategy.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just following on that the comments in terms of easy comparison. Maybe give us a sense now that we've seen the impact of higher cost of goods flowing through. With the customer response has been to what sort of elasticity demand you've seen as pr
componenttext: And then just following on that the comments in terms of easy comparison. Maybe give us a sense now that we've seen the impact of higher cost of goods flowing through. With the customer response has been to what sort of elasticity demand you've seen as prices have gone up in light of the higher cost of goods?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we've had great clarity up until now because that Mr. Martin is actually reduced the AUR on clearance goods but we are maintaining the AUR on a go-forward goods. So we feel that we're on track the first couple weeks in November we're seeing the ki
componenttext: I think we've had great clarity up until now because that Mr. Martin is actually reduced the AUR on clearance goods but we are maintaining the AUR on a go-forward goods. So we feel that we're on track the first couple weeks in November we're seeing the kind of increase in AUR that we planned. And we are seeing the corresponding decrease in units that we plan. So I think that we have every reason to believe that at this point in time in the fourth quarter, they were on track to achieve our AUR expectations and that we'll have the units necessary to take care of Chrismtas. But I think costs come down modestly going into spring and we're up against much higher cost a year ago. But I don't think we'll go back to a longtime but I don't think it's going to go back soon to the previous comp prices, I think the social costs and other aspects of sourcing issue have taken a step from a customer point of view.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just last question, it seems like a bright spot in the quarter was the expense control. And it seems as if the marketing was a piece of that. Could you give us a sense of what opportunity that presents in the fourth quarter, should we expect cont
componenttext: And then just last question, it seems like a bright spot in the quarter was the expense control. And it seems as if the marketing was a piece of that. Could you give us a sense of what opportunity that presents in the fourth quarter, should we expect continued dialing back of marketing going forward?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we identified late last year and early this year, we're doing the transformation of our cost structure. And part of that was getting out of the catalog business, part of the marketing numbers reflected in print media that was related to catalog. We ide
componenttext: As we identified late last year and early this year, we're doing the transformation of our cost structure. And part of that was getting out of the catalog business, part of the marketing numbers reflected in print media that was related to catalog. We identified $50 million of savings we committed to in this fiscal year. We're going to achieve that or slightly better. So the market expense while some of our competitors actually increased their marketing during this period, we show this as a transition not to build a bigger hurdle climb in terms of promotion going forward. So we've been optimizing the way we use our marketing dollars whether it's the amount of preprints, the geographic, diversity we have in terms of customers' response to various types of media. So we don't see any difference in terms of the way we look at our cost savings in the fourth quarter than what we've seen in the first 3. The cost savings were taken even in the first of increased cost for additional Sephora  locations Mango, Call it Spring so forth. So we feel that we've got a good foundation of costs cost control and there'll be obviously more opportunities going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew with JPMorgan.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you speak to progress initiatives going forward around center core today? And along these lines, can you elaborate a little bit on the recent Lancome 48 store test that you announced earlier this month?
componenttext: Can you speak to progress initiatives going forward around center core today? And along these lines, can you elaborate a little bit on the recent Lancome 48 store test that you announced earlier this month?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we've answered that first. It's exceeding our expectations, so we feel very good about that. It bodes well for further Lancome partnership. As to the center core, we honestly believe that we have a huge opportunity in the center core. Most departmen
componenttext: Well, we've answered that first. It's exceeding our expectations, so we feel very good about that. It bodes well for further Lancome partnership. As to the center core, we honestly believe that we have a huge opportunity in the center core. Most department stores, the highest productivity they have is in the center core because traditionally, we didn't have a comprehensive beauty offer. It was a disadvantage for jcpenney. And frankly, our apparel business was more productive than our accessories business. That doesn't make a lot of sense. So we believe this huge cross shopping opportunities between apparel customers that we now find in the center core are more attractive and accessories that are tied together with our apparel purchases. Our People Style Watch initiative has proven to us that customers want to buy the whole outfit. They particularly like the fact that when they get confidence by People Style Watch endorsing the things that we've put in the assortments. So what we call center core includes beauty, it includes fine jewelry, it includes women's accessories, in many cases, it includes women's shoes. These businesses are accretive to our overall productivity and are very profitable. So we've set that up in a number of stores at this point, it will take probably 2 to 3 years to get to all sorts of terms of the transformation of the center core businesses.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Can you also speak to what you're seeing from a hiring standpoint at the store level? I mean we've heard about the changes at the top. I'm curious any changes in the level of talent that you're seeing come your way at more in the store level organi
componenttext: Great. Can you also speak to what you're seeing from a hiring standpoint at the store level? I mean we've heard about the changes at the top. I'm curious any changes in the level of talent that you're seeing come your way at more in the store level organization?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, that's an interesting and comprehensive question obviously with the voluntary retirement program, we've had an opportunity in certain cases for people who had to celebrate their career with us and chose to take an early retirement, gives us an oppor
componenttext: Well, that's an interesting and comprehensive question obviously with the voluntary retirement program, we've had an opportunity in certain cases for people who had to celebrate their career with us and chose to take an early retirement, gives us an opportunity to bring in new people to the jcpenney. So we're excited for people who were able to take advantage of that and we're also excited about the opportunity we're seeing a huge influx of people that are willing and want to have a career with us. I think the nature of our store staffing has been such that we've been able to put better customer service in place by having more people customers in the store and modifying staffing when there is less traffic so I think reason our customer keep getting better so actually giving customers a better experience. So I'm very optimistic about the quality of people we were able to attract people. We want people for a career. We don't want them for a week and I think our turnover has gone over 100%, which is pretty traditional in retail, down to the 60s. And I think that's an indication that they're having good experience and that good experience is translating into better relationship with customers.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. One last question. Any initiatives to stabilize the home business? Are you seeing anything that gives you confidence in the changes that you've made over the past year since putting your management in place?
componenttext: Great. One last question. Any initiatives to stabilize the home business? Are you seeing anything that gives you confidence in the changes that you've made over the past year since putting your management in place?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: The confidence I have is more about the same and can't be that forever. I think it's been a very protracted, very difficult period. It was one of our core strengths obviously that played out to be difficult particularly, the big ticket business. Ron comes
componenttext: The confidence I have is more about the same and can't be that forever. I think it's been a very protracted, very difficult period. It was one of our core strengths obviously that played out to be difficult particularly, the big ticket business. Ron comes out of the home background and of part of his time at Target. And he is very enthusiastic about the opportunities we see in home. And we have top talent in that area and our merchant team. So I think we feel very strong we're going to win in this category. It's a slow win right now for recovery and furniture, those are the toughest business. We're seeing good response in luggage, good response in housewares, in the bath area, great response all four products. The opportunity to increase the excitement in terms of merchandise there and I'm going to be a lifelong customer of jcpenney home.

componenttext: I can comment on we don't quantify particularly but it was a significant opportunity for us in the third quarter as our new credit agreement over a year old now and provided an obviously a year ago, we issued all new cards. Part of our sales weakness in this last quarter was the fact we launched Liz Claiborne a year ago and didn't have a major fashion launch this year but also we had a major reissuance of 15 million credit cards last year during the third quarter, while we didn't have another reissuance this year. We did have a good experience with that court customers that finding the rewards program is something they enjoyed and it feel that works for them so we think that we've been structured in such a way that both of us can share the upside.

componenttext: Expenses? It will be down because we don't have the catalog infrastructure and we were funding a year ago but we believe that the promotional calendar we have is comparable in terms of its troops of come in the store for great gifts and Christmas. We have not changed our promotional cadence in terms of ramping up in terms of the level of promotion or the amount of discounting and so forth we feel it's highly promotional environment, it will be unwise to change the calendar demand at this point but we are satisfied with the plans laid out.
