componenttext: So when you talk about the financial impact of executing the new pricing strategy, is there anything beyond an inventory write-down that would be included in that? And then just secondly on inventory levels, where do you plan to end fourth quarter, and how are you thinking initially about 2012?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think as Ron mentioned in his remarks, he is looking forward to sharing that in January. The obvious answer is we intend to end this season with the right level of inventory for what we see in the first quarter, so -- but that's already bought, so we kn
componenttext: I think as Ron mentioned in his remarks, he is looking forward to sharing that in January. The obvious answer is we intend to end this season with the right level of inventory for what we see in the first quarter, so -- but that's already bought, so we know that, so it's not a mystery. And we feel quite confident that our costing is so much better, somewhat better than we achieved in the fall but still at a higher level in the previous years. So I think the teams feel very strongly that they have planned well for the transition from January to February.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike, I just 2 questions. I was wondering as you sit down and thought about the business and the next phase of it, how do you kind of balance kind of reimagining the business, as you've called it or Ron has called it, against moving faster than where the
componenttext: Mike, I just 2 questions. I was wondering as you sit down and thought about the business and the next phase of it, how do you kind of balance kind of reimagining the business, as you've called it or Ron has called it, against moving faster than where the customer is, or you start doing things that are away from what they look to you for, so the weakness maybe just a function of the economy, and you start making these changes, and you move away from where the core customer would expect you to provide?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we have a huge opportunity with the existing customer. We're only have 7% of their wallet. So an extra visit means an enormous amount to get about between 4 and 6 visits depending where there's a mall store or not mall store. So our ex
componenttext: Well, first of all, we have a huge opportunity with the existing customer. We're only have 7% of their wallet. So an extra visit means an enormous amount to get about between 4 and 6 visits depending where there's a mall store or not mall store. So our existing customers are our best place to look for additional volume. Half of the families in America is a very large footprint, so I think that's probably the biggest opportunity. Having said that, the new things we've added have attracted the young customers. We know that there's over 0.25 million new customers came that never bought in jcpenney before that bought Liz Claiborne, so we know those are new customers. And I think we can trace the other attractions of having a similar expectation. So I don't think there's a lot of risk in terms of the changes being made. The risk is clearly not the downside. I think the opportunity is in the upside, people finding a broader range of merchandise, more excitement, price merchandise and a customer experience that we think has been certainly recognized by American Express. And in our survey, they're going to get a great customer service when they buy that merchandise. So we're confident that the underrepresented market, the 18- to 35-year old is starting to discover jcpenney, and we'll speak more about it.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: My second question, I guess, is part of this process into '12 and beyond. Is there an ongoing assessment to potentially more store closings? Because it looked like to us some data that we looked at was about 5% of your store base were malls that were putt
componenttext: My second question, I guess, is part of this process into '12 and beyond. Is there an ongoing assessment to potentially more store closings? Because it looked like to us some data that we looked at was about 5% of your store base were malls that were putting out less than $150 a foot, which would imply maybe the malls are very unproductive and maybe your stores aren't productive. I mean, where are you with the assessment of that and being able to maybe work out of those locations better now than you would have been able to a year or 2 years ago?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, our habit has been -- our practice has been to look at all stores every year in terms of their contribution, and that won't change. A number of relocations occurred in the last 3 or 4 years as we moved out of locations that had various diff
componenttext: Well, I think, our habit has been -- our practice has been to look at all stores every year in terms of their contribution, and that won't change. A number of relocations occurred in the last 3 or 4 years as we moved out of locations that had various difficulties, whether it's the mall or a particular store. So I really don't see an acceleration of closings. I think it's a question of analysis of how they're performing, tests done every year. I think, if anything, the well-financed mall developers are starting to reinvest in their properties again. And we stand a benefit from that to the extent they bring new anchors in, new ideas in, like an Apple store, for example. An Apple store is the most productive thing that can happen to a mall. It attracts a broad range of customers, all of those customers. All those customers are opportunities for us. So I think our biggest opportunity frankly is the jcpenney brand. So to the extent we elevate the brand and get people to discover who we are that we have style, we have quality, we have a very compelling price, that should appeal to a much broader audience.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011

componenttext: Just a question about some of your suppliers have talked publicly about your cutting off replenishment orders as part of your reticketing and repricing strategy. I was wondering if you could comment on your Q4 replenishment strategy and if that's the case, how do you plan to make sales plan in those areas of you're not necessarily replenishing key sizes and colors?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's an exaggeration on their part. We are modifying our basic flow in order to get through the transition. It's certainly not going to affect our stock levels to a degree that the customer will notice. We are committed to making sure we're in s
componenttext: I think that's an exaggeration on their part. We are modifying our basic flow in order to get through the transition. It's certainly not going to affect our stock levels to a degree that the customer will notice. We are committed to making sure we're in stock in sizes and colors and the basics. But 40% of our business is run on our basic program, and that won't be affected. I think that while it's a different experience for each supplier in terms of what their needs are, in terms of repricing our merchandise for the spring season, I think most have handled it very, very well. So there may be some carping here and there because we they have to do something different, I think it will pay out in the long run.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relati
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the J. C. Penney Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations for J. C. Penney. Thank you, Ms. Hays. You may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christine, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review J.C. Penney's third quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meani
componenttext: Thank you, Christine, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review J.C. Penney's third quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and the company's future results of operation could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. Also please note that no portion of this call may be rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of jcpenney. Replay of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after November 14, 2011, please note that this recording will not be updated, and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. Now I'll turn the call over to Mike Ullman.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. There are 3 of us on the call this morning: Michael Dastugue; Ron Johnson and myself. I'll open the call by giving you some color on this past quarter as well as our plans for the holiday shopping season.
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. There are 3 of us on the call this morning: Michael Dastugue; Ron Johnson and myself. I'll open the call by giving you some color on this past quarter as well as our plans for the holiday shopping season. Michael will as usual provide you a greater financial detail, including our outlook for the balance of the year. And then Ron will say a few words, now that he's officially taken the CEO helm. Let me start with our results for the quarter. 
It continues to be a difficult consumer environment, and this was evident in mall traffic during the period, which was down 2.4% in our sales performance. While our higher income customers responded very well to our attractions, our moderate income customers delayed their purchases of fall/winter merchandise as they continue to shop closer to need. That said, while it's a little too early to call a trend, we recently seen stronger sales in cold weather apparel and accessories as temperatures across the country became more seasonable. There were some bright spots during the quarter that bear noting. The Liz Claiborne brand remains a standout performer. Sephora is generating strong sales in every location, up double digits for the quarter and year-to-date. And the work we've been doing to build our center core business is resonating, evident in the solid performance of our women's accessory businesses. 
We've also made significant progress in our organizational restructuring we began earlier this year, which is designed to reduce expenses and simplify our organization by reducing investments in areas of the business that no longer contribute meaningfully to our overall financial performance. This includes the sale during the quarter of 15 outlet stores to SB Capital, as well as steps we took to reorganize our supply chain network and our initiatives to reduce SG&A expenses throughout the business. It also includes the work we've done to redesign jcpenney from a people perspective to make our work at all levels of the organization more effective and nimble. As part of this work, we initiated a Voluntary Early Retirement Program, or VERP, for associates who have been with the company for more than 20 years and were at least 55 years of age. Mike will provide more detail on the financial impact of this program in a few moments. 
I should note that even though as we focus on these import organizational changes, we have continued to make investments in the attractions to drive our business, including renovating our stores to showcase our new attractions, like MNG by Mango and Call it Spring by ALDO. 
During the quarter, we opened 405 new Call it Spring by ALDO shoe shops for a total of 505 locations. We opened 208 MNG by Mango shops for a total now of 500 stores, and we opened additional 31 Sephora inside jcpenney shops for a year end total of 308 locations. 
We also accelerate our option to buy the Liz Claiborne family brands from Liz Claiborne Inc., so we can capture all the upside from the strong business. And at the same time, we took the opportunity to acquire the Monet fashion jewelry brand from them as well, which we'll launch in jcpenney in the fall of 2012. 
Outside our core jcpenney brand, we continue to build our growth brand businesses, which include our 2 new additional concepts, Gifting Grace and CLAD. Both websites launched last week and our strategic partnerships between jcpenney and the Hearst Corporation. 
Moving on to holiday. We feel very good about our merchandise offering and our gift assortments which are stronger than ever. While it's still a tough consumer environment, we've planned our business accordingly and will be stocked at the right levels. This combined with our compelling marketing campaign and high level of consumer service we offer means jcpenney once again will be positioned to be a key holiday gift destination this Christmas season. With that, I'll now turn the call over to Michael Dastugue for further information in the quarter. Michael?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings of $0.11 per share, excluding restructuring and management transition charges. This was in line with our most recent guidance. A reconciliation of adjusted net income to the
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported adjusted earnings of $0.11 per share, excluding restructuring and management transition charges. This was in line with our most recent guidance. A reconciliation of adjusted net income to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is included in our release, which is available on our website. 
On a GAAP basis, our EPS this quarter is a loss of $0.67 per share, and I will go overall with the overall charges related to that loss in a few moments. Overall, the quarter was more challenging than we planned. While our SG&A was well managed, sales and gross margins came in below our expectations. That said, we are continuing to take actions necessary to streamline and restructure our organization to position us for the next phase of jcpenney's transformation. 
Turning to our Q3 results. Comp store sales declined 1.6% in the third quarter. Year-to-date, comp store sales were up 1.2% over last year. SG&A for the quarter came in better than anticipated, decreasing $84 million year-over-year to $1.24 billion or 31.2% of sales. This was driven primarily by our decrease in marketing spend, lower credit costs and benefits realized from our expense reduction initiatives. Gross margin, however, decreased approximately 160 basis points to 37.4% of sales. 
Our gross margin in the third quarter was impacted by the softer-than-expected selling environment, which resulted in higher promotional activity and more markdowns in the quarter. We do continue to be in a strong financial position and ended the third quarter with approximately $1.1 billion in cash and short-term investments. 
Capital expenditures for the third quarter were about $469 million in line with our expectations, and we continue to anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $650 million. We ended the quarter with our inventory up 2.6%. So now let me take you through some of the charges we recorded this quarter. 
In aggregate, we recorded $265 million of restructuring and management transition charges in the third quarter. As you recall, we announced on our second quarter call that jcpenney offered a Voluntary Early Retirement Program to approximately 8,200 associates. That program closed on October 15, and close to 4,000 jcpenney associates took advantage of this opportunity to retire from the company with an enhanced financial incentive. With 80% of the cash costs associated with the program being borne by our well-funded pension plan, we recorded a pretax charge of $179 million. 
As associates retire over the next year, we estimate this program to have a favorable impact of approximately $50 million on 2012 operating expenses with a slightly higher benefit realized in 2013. 
Next, we recorded one-time charges of approximately $30 million related to the sale of our outlet store business to SB Capital in October. This included expenses related to the disposition of inventory and severance for associates. The remaining charges, which are detailed in our earnings release are related to the process improvements in our home office and supply chain as well as management transition expenses. 
Also please note, we have broken out the restructuring and management transition charges this quarter as a separate line item on our P&L. At the same time, we reclassified 2 previous quarters of restructuring charges to conform with the current presentation. As a result, these charges no longer flow through real estate and other.
Now let me share with you a few of our assumptions for the fourth quarter. We expect comparable store sales to be flat to up slightly in the fourth quarter and gross margins to be down modestly. Our SG&A is expected to be well managed and slightly below last year's levels. As we continue with our restructuring efforts and transitions in leadership, we expect to incur additional charges in the fourth quarter of approximately $104 million. A portion of these charges will have an impact on our effective tax rate. In other words, they are not tax deductible in the fourth quarter, which is -- and therefore, the tax rate will -- is expected to be approximately 48%. As a result, on approximately $220 million average shares outstanding, we expect fourth quarter earnings before restructuring and management transition charges to be in the range of $1.05 to $1.15 per share. 
On a GAAP basis, including all of the restructuring and management transition charges, earnings for the fourth quarter are now expected to be in a range of $0.64 to $0.74 per share. Additionally, as we stated in our release this morning, we are in the process of executing a meaningful change in the way we approach pricing. Our guidance for the fourth quarter does not include any financial impacts we may incur as the results of these changes. And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Mike

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. While I continue to serve for the next few months as Executive Chairman of jcpenney, this will be the last of 27 quarterly conference calls that I'll be on with you. As Chief Executive of one of America's largest retail companies for t
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. While I continue to serve for the next few months as Executive Chairman of jcpenney, this will be the last of 27 quarterly conference calls that I'll be on with you. As Chief Executive of one of America's largest retail companies for the past 7 years and a number of other senior leadership roles in the industry before that, I've had a bird's eye view of the direct impact the economy has had on the consumers' wallets. That's been particularly true here in jcpenney as we serve more than half of America's families every year. At the time I joined jcpenney in 2004, almost exactly 7 years ago this month, the company had just completed its turnaround. 
My #1 priority as CEO was to move jcpenney out of a turnaround phase and then grow and begin the transformation of the brand. I'm particularly proud of the success we've achieved in 3 key areas as we've laid a strong foundation for the future of jcpenney. 
First, the attractions we've built: Sephora inside jcpenney, MNG by Mango, Call it Spring by ALDO, Modern Bride, People Style Watch and the acquisition of Liz Claiborne brand. These great brands have anchored jcpenney's dramatic style transformation and attracted new and younger customers to jcpenney, many of whom who never shopped with us in the past. 
Second, customer service. I have enormous respect for our customers who are working hard every day to provide for their families in spite of great economic challenges. Across our organization, I've seen tremendous dedication to ensure that we're meeting our customers' needs and when we can, making their lives a little easier in the process.
Customers have recognized this commitment and honored us 3 years in a row as the #1 department store for customer service in the American Express/NRF Customers' Choice survey. 
And third, associate engagement. Over last 7 years we've transformed our culture. jcpenney now boasts an associate engagement score at top of the retail industry and the top quartile of all U.S. companies, moving from 67% engagement, which is about average of the Gallup poll just a few short years ago to over 80% in 2011. People work for people, not companies. That's why I want to take this opportunity to thank all of our associates for the tremendous dedication to the work we've done together to bring new and exciting brands and attractions to our customers while making our company a great place to work. 
I'd also like to thank those of you on the call whom I've met, spent time with over the years as you follow jcpenney, including, of course, our shareholders who placed their faith in our company. I personally and we, as a company, have greatly benefited from these interactions. 
As many CEOs will tell you the most important thing they can do in their roles to ensure there's an exceptional successor in place. That's certainly been my priority over the last couple of years. I'm very happy report that we've realized that goal, and we bring someone with Ron Johnson's caliber to jcpenney. 
Ron is one of the most talented retail executives in the United States and a couple years ago, identified as someone who has the right talent and vision and values to take jcpenney to the next level and approached him about joining us. Ron told me at that point, it wasn't the right time. While I respect his position, it didn't stop us from coming back. And I'm delighted to say this time, it was right. 
Working very closely with Ron over the last 4 months has been very exciting and confirmed my belief he's the right person to lead the company forward. I'm enthusiastic about his ideas and his vision for the next phase of jcpenney. With that, I'll turn the call over to Ron, who will say a few words.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. It is great to have officially begun my duties here at jcpenney. While I'm 2 weeks into my tenure, if truth be told, I've spent considerable time with Mike and the team during the past 4 months preparing for my new role. Mike and I have a
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. It is great to have officially begun my duties here at jcpenney. While I'm 2 weeks into my tenure, if truth be told, I've spent considerable time with Mike and the team during the past 4 months preparing for my new role. Mike and I have actually traveled throughout the world together, visiting stores and partners and developing strategy for jcpenney to win. I would like to publicly thank Mike for his incredible support during the transition and for his 7 years of service at jcpenney. Many of the things we will do in the years ahead will be built on the very solid foundation created by Mike and the team during his tenure as CEO of this company. 
Now officially here leading jcpenney, I get more excited every day about the potential for jcpenney. Two weeks ago in November 1, my first day, I addressed all of our associates here in Plano. I told them that I am not here to improve, I am here to transform. 
I shared with them that as America's first store, it is time to assert leadership, reclaim our birthright and become America's favorite store. The energy, excitement and enthusiasm that I received from our associates was overwhelming. It clearly showed me that they are ready to win. 
As Mike said, success begins with people, and jcpenney has great people, people who I know will be able to think differently and work creatively to take the company into the future. With this background, I'm working with our team to rethink, really to reimagine everything we do. I am investing considerable energy and a strategic review of our product, our pricing and our promotional strategies in order to create an exceptional, a new, a better way for people to shop. I am also launching a review of our processes with the goal of simplifying our work, so that everything we do will focus on efforts to create long-term value for our shareholders. And most importantly, I'm spending time getting to know our teams. 
I feel very fortunate that Michael Francis, who I worked with at Target for many years, has come on board as President to help lead the charge. Michael's talents in merchandising and marketing are unmatched, and the chance for him to direct all creative functions at jcpenney will allow us to truly stand out in the marketplace. His energy level is contagious, and the teams are responding immediately to his leadership. And his personal excitement about joining jcpenney demonstrates to me that the dream for jcpenney to become America's favorite store is within our grasp. 
Talent is a fuel of any company but especially so in a people-intensive business like retailing. I'm excited to announce this morning the addition of 2 exceptional leaders who will all also be joining jcpenney. This Wednesday, Dan Walker will join our company as Chief Talent Officer. And on December 5, Mike Kramer will join jcpenney as Chief Operating Officer. 
I worked with Mike and Dan at Apple, and I believe they are 2 of the most talented leaders in the retail industry, and I look forward to you getting to know them. Dan Walker has over 3 decades of experience as the most senior HR executive in a variety of companies, and he's a winner. 
He cut his teeth in the department industry and was promoted to VP of HR at the Lazarus division of Federated at the age of 29. He then led Human Resources at General Mills Specialty Retail division in the early 1980s, which at that time included Eddie Bauer, Talbots and 3 other specialty retail stores. He then joined the GAP in 1986, working closely with Mickey and the GAP's presidents to build the talent engine that fuel the growth of the core GAP brand and help launch new concepts, including GAPKids, babyGap, GAP International and a modernized Banana Republic. The talent supply chain model Dan created helped establish GAP as a world leader in specialty retail in the early 90s. Dan joined Apple as Chief Talent Officer at the same year I joined Apple. He led and built the global human resources team during a period where we saw the launch of the iPod, iTunes, a world-class application division and the Apple retail stores. His ability to identify, develop and organize talent is unmatched, and he is an unbelievably creative and transformational thinker. 
I am thrilled that I'll get the chance to work side by side with Dan again. Mike Kramer is leaving his position as CEO of Kellwood to join the jcpenney team. At Kellwood, Mike oversaw a portfolio of nearly a dozen fashion brands, including Vince, Scotch & Soda and Rebecca Taylor. Prior to that, he was Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Abercrombie and Fitch. 
I first worked with Mike when he was Vice President of Finance at Apple and CFO of the retail stores. Mike joined me when we opened our first store and was there through the first 5 formative years of Apple's retail strategy. Mike is an unusual leader in that he combines extraordinary financial acumen with a strategic business perspective. A certified public accountant, he began his career with financial leadership roles at limited and in various divisions at PepsiCo. Since then, he has worked in increasingly strategic roles at Apple, Abercrombie and Kellwood, culminating in his role as the Chief Executive Officer. 
He will bring an extraordinary wealth of experience with winning companies to jcpenney. And he's most experienced with a wholesale company, managing a portfolio of established and emerging brands will be extremely valuable as we reimagine our merchandise portfolio. 
I am convinced that Michael Francis, Mike Kramer and Dan Walker, combined with a talented team I've met and worked with in the past 4 months at jcpenney, will have the courage, the boldness and skill to rethink every aspect of our business as we transform jcpenney to become America's favorite store. I know you have a lot of questions about our plans to do that, and I can't wait to share them with you. However, my approach will be to only talk publicly about our actions at the time we're taking them, not before. 
So with that, we will start shedding light on our strategic approach in late January when we will hold a meeting in New York for the investment community. We will be sending out invitations in the coming weeks with additional details, but please block the morning of January 25 on your calendars. Again, I am thrilled to officially be here now and look forward to meeting all of you in January. 
Since we'll address all long-term strategy questions at the January event, I will turn the call back to Mike and Michael right now to handle the Q&A regarding Q3 performance and Q4 expectations

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ron. Operator, we're now open for questions.
componenttext: Thanks, Ron. Operator, we're now open for questions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Deborah Weinswig with Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Deborah Weinswig with Citigroup.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike and Michael, if I can ask a question, can you talk about what gives you the confidence in your comp store guidance because I think you have the most difficult comps for the first quarter on both a 1- and on a 2-year basis?
componenttext: Mike and Michael, if I can ask a question, can you talk about what gives you the confidence in your comp store guidance because I think you have the most difficult comps for the first quarter on both a 1- and on a 2-year basis?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we feel very confident about our guidance for the following reasons. First of all, throughout the year, our growth initiatives have far exceeded our expectations in terms of comp store growth, particularly Sephora, Claiborne brand, center core acc
componenttext: I think we feel very confident about our guidance for the following reasons. First of all, throughout the year, our growth initiatives have far exceeded our expectations in terms of comp store growth, particularly Sephora, Claiborne brand, center core accessories concepts, tops and things we've identified in the spring. The part of our business has been less helpful in terms of the comps has been the basics business and the things that people can defer in terms of not needing them right away. The one good thing about the Christmas holiday season is it's a gift-giving time. This is the time that mall traffic tends to serve, and those have been the areas where we've had most difficulty. So we feel good about the guidance we're giving and obviously, we'd be happy to have said something about that.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: All right. And then, can you also update us on the process improvement technologies and the impact that they're having on the business right now?
componenttext: All right. And then, can you also update us on the process improvement technologies and the impact that they're having on the business right now?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, Deborah, the last several years, we've looked at every aspect of our business, particularly in the headquarters as to ways to improve processes to make ourselves more effective. It's not just about cost cutting. It's about trying to mak
componenttext: Well, as you know, Deborah, the last several years, we've looked at every aspect of our business, particularly in the headquarters as to ways to improve processes to make ourselves more effective. It's not just about cost cutting. It's about trying to make it work simpler in our stores, organization, the time management system, these Door to Floor activities, those things have also -- in our past. For the last several months, we've been working on supply chain improvements. As we transitioned out the catalog business, we realized we have a lot of infrastructure. There's more catalog focused instead of dotcom focused. And quite honestly, most of the year has been transitioning away from print media from a catalog perspective and more toward online. That's been much more painful than we anticipated. As Warren Buffett said on CNBC this morning, housing is in a depression, not a recession. Half of our online business and half of our catalog business was home, and that's hurt us. Our dotcom business margins have been hurt by the home business, which we obviously didn't anticipate would linger in this difficult position for so long. So most of our process things have been redesigned in making people's jobs easier and making them more effective.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then last question, can you talk about the -- I'm not quite sure but talk about the Roosevelt Field remodel and maybe how that -- maybe how that makes you think about capital deployment in the future?
componenttext: And then last question, can you talk about the -- I'm not quite sure but talk about the Roosevelt Field remodel and maybe how that -- maybe how that makes you think about capital deployment in the future?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Deborah, you cut out. Can you just repeat the question?
componenttext: I'm sorry, Deborah, you cut out. Can you just repeat the question?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh sure. Can you talk about the Roosevelt Field remodel, and how that makes you think about capital deployment in the future?
componenttext: Oh sure. Can you talk about the Roosevelt Field remodel, and how that makes you think about capital deployment in the future?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, that as you may know is a particularly difficult remodel because there was asbestos in the store, so it was a very complicated and expensive effort. We're doing extremely well in the New York metro market. We're double digit up in Manhattan. We stil
componenttext: Well, that as you may know is a particularly difficult remodel because there was asbestos in the store, so it was a very complicated and expensive effort. We're doing extremely well in the New York metro market. We're double digit up in Manhattan. We still feel very strongly that we're underrepresented in that market, so we felt it was a strategic priority to do Roosevelt Field. It's responding very well after the remodel has opened. So we will continue to have a robust renovation remodel strategy. Every time we put a Sephora in an existing jcpenney store, it gives us the opportunity to remodel the center core. We continue to have 75 to 85 new Sephora locations in the coming year. So I think that we can‚Äôt afford to have that many Roosevelt Fields per year, but we're committed to taking on the most important stores in making sure they're at the level of ambience that our customers expect.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira with Goldman Sachs.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike, perhaps you could talk a little bit about the margins? Obviously, some contraction in the third quarter and yet the outlook looks for much more moderate, sort of flat to slightly down. You called out that it's a promotional environment. What do you
componenttext: Mike, perhaps you could talk a little bit about the margins? Obviously, some contraction in the third quarter and yet the outlook looks for much more moderate, sort of flat to slightly down. You called out that it's a promotional environment. What do you expect to change to envision that margin to be a lot less impacted? And then following on that, you have alluded to the pricing strategy in preparation for spring 2012. Maybe if you can give us some insight in terms of what that entails what to look forward to.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Adrianne, first as to the year we're coming out of the first quarter, if you look at mall traffic or if you look at the economy as a whole, we're about 400 basis points below the trendline coming out of the first quarter. So much of our margin compression
componenttext: Adrianne, first as to the year we're coming out of the first quarter, if you look at mall traffic or if you look at the economy as a whole, we're about 400 basis points below the trendline coming out of the first quarter. So much of our margin compression over the last 2 quarters has been getting out of the goods that frankly there was no demand for as the economy ratcheted down closer to a flat line. We feel that we're past the worst of that. In terms of being able to modify the fourth quarter, we were able to pull back on goods as we saw that deceleration. I think as I mentioned just recently -- just previously, our dotcom business was impacted negatively on margins, so I would say if you combine about half of the margin miss was in dotcom, which was the cost of shipping. The home business deterioration and the other half was in markdowns to declare the goods that we felt needed to be in the right stock position coming in the fourth quarter. We're very satisfied with what we own today in terms of inventory as appropriate for the fourth quarter. I would say as to the outlook for the fourth quarter, we recently feel more confident about maintaining the margin flat or slightly down. It's that last year we had a very difficult margin for the fourth quarter, so we think we have upside to what would have been a normal fourth quarter that we're facing. I'm not prepared to talk about the go-forward strategy. As Ron mentioned, there's an opportunity to do that at the end of January. Fortunately, Ron and I had a lot of time together. I feel very confident that on a forward-looking basis that you'll be very satisfied with the strategy.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Mike, just following on that the comments in terms of easy comparison. Maybe give us a sense now that we've seen the impact of higher cost of goods flowing through, what the customer response has been to -- what sort of elasticity of deman
componenttext: Okay. And then, Mike, just following on that the comments in terms of easy comparison. Maybe give us a sense now that we've seen the impact of higher cost of goods flowing through, what the customer response has been to -- what sort of elasticity of demand you've seen as prices have gone up in light of the higher cost of goods?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we've not had great clarity up until now because frankly clearing the goods through markdowns has actually reduced the AUR on clearance goods, but we were maintaining the AUR on the go-forward goods. So we feel that we're on track the first couple
componenttext: I think we've not had great clarity up until now because frankly clearing the goods through markdowns has actually reduced the AUR on clearance goods, but we were maintaining the AUR on the go-forward goods. So we feel that we're on track the first couple weeks in November, we're seeing the kind of increase in AUR that we planned. And we're seeing the corresponding decrease in units that we planned. So I think that we have every reason to believe at this point in time in the fourth quarter that we're on track to achieve our AUR expectations, and that we'll have the units necessary to take care of Christmas. But I think costs come down modestly going into spring, and we're up against much higher cotton costs a year ago. But I don't think it'll ever go back -- maybe ever is a long time, but I don't think it's going to go back soon to the previous cotton prices, I think the social costs and other aspects of sourcing in Asia have taken a step in the wrong direction from a cost point of view.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just the last question, it seems like a bright spot in the quarter was the expense control, and it seems as if marketing was a piece of that. Could you give us a sense of what opportunity that presents in the fourth quarter? Should we expec
componenttext: Okay. And then just the last question, it seems like a bright spot in the quarter was the expense control, and it seems as if marketing was a piece of that. Could you give us a sense of what opportunity that presents in the fourth quarter? Should we expect continued dialing back of marketing going forward?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we identified late last year and early this year, we've been doing transformation of our cost structure. And part of that was the -- getting out of the catalog business. A part of the marketing number is reflected in print media that was related to cat
componenttext: As we identified late last year and early this year, we've been doing transformation of our cost structure. And part of that was the -- getting out of the catalog business. A part of the marketing number is reflected in print media that was related to catalog. We identified $50 million of savings we've committed to in this -- for this fiscal year. We're going to achieve that or slightly better. So the market expense while some of our competitors actually increased their marketing during this period, we chose as a transition not to build a bigger hurdle climb in terms of promotion going forward. So we've been optimizing the way we use our marketing dollars, whether it's the amount of preprints, the geographic diversity we have in terms of how customers respond to various types of media. So we don't see any difference in terms of the way we would look at our cost savings in the fourth quarter than what we've seen in the first 3. These cost savings were taken even in the phase of increased costs for additional Sephora locations Mango, Call it Spring and so forth. So we feel that we're -- we've got a good foundation of cost control, and there'll be obviously more opportunities going forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Boss with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Boss with JP Morgan.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you speak to progress initiatives going forward around the center core experience today? And along these lines, can you elaborate a little bit on the recent Lancome 48-store test that you announced earlier this month?
componenttext: Can you speak to progress initiatives going forward around the center core experience today? And along these lines, can you elaborate a little bit on the recent Lancome 48-store test that you announced earlier this month?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let me answer that first. It's exceeding our expectations, so we feel very good about that. It bodes well for further Lancome partnership. As to the center core, we honestly believe that we have a huge opportunity in the center core. Most department
componenttext: Well, let me answer that first. It's exceeding our expectations, so we feel very good about that. It bodes well for further Lancome partnership. As to the center core, we honestly believe that we have a huge opportunity in the center core. Most department stores, the highest productivity they have is in the center core because we traditionally, it didn't really have a comprehensive beauty offer. It was a disadvantage for jcpenney, and frankly our apparel business was more productive than our accessories business. That doesn't make a lot of sense. So we believe these huge cross-shopping opportunities between apparel customers that will find the center core more attractive and accessories that are tied together with our apparel purchases. Our People Style Watch initiative has proven to us that customers want to buy the whole outfit. They particularly like the fact when they get confidence by People Style Watch endorsing the things that we've put in the assortments. So what we call center core includes beauty, it includes fine jewelry, it includes women's accessories. In many cases, it includes women's shoes. These businesses are accretive to our overall productivity and are very profitable. So we've set that up in a number of stores at this point. It will take probably 2 to 3 years to get to all stores in terms of the transformation of the center core businesses.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Can you also speak to what you're seeing from a hiring standpoint at the store level? I mean, we've heard about the changes at the top. But I'm curious any changes in the level of talent that you're seeing come your way at more in the store level o
componenttext: Great. Can you also speak to what you're seeing from a hiring standpoint at the store level? I mean, we've heard about the changes at the top. But I'm curious any changes in the level of talent that you're seeing come your way at more in the store level organization?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, that's an interesting and comprehensive question because obviously with the Voluntary Early Retirement Program, we've had an opportunity in certain cases for people who had to celebrate their career with us and chose to take an early retirement give
componenttext: Well, that's an interesting and comprehensive question because obviously with the Voluntary Early Retirement Program, we've had an opportunity in certain cases for people who had to celebrate their career with us and chose to take an early retirement gives us an opportunity to bring in new people to the jcpenney. So we're excited for people who were able to take advantage of that. We're also excited about the opportunity that we're seeing a huge influx of people that are willing and want to have a career with us. I think that the nature of our store staffing has been such that we've been able to put better customer service in place by having more people when customers are in the store and modifying the staffing when there's less traffic. So I think the reason our customer service scores keep getting better, so we're actually giving the customer a better experience. So I'm very optimistic about the quality of people we were able to attract. We want people for a career. We don't want them for a week, and I think our turnover has gone from over 100%, which is pretty traditional in retail, down to the 60s. And I think that's an indication that they're having a good experience and that good experience is translating into better relationship with customers.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. One last question. Any initiatives to stabilize the home business? Are you seeing anything that gives you confidence in the changes that you've made over the past year since putting new management in place?
componenttext: Great. One last question. Any initiatives to stabilize the home business? Are you seeing anything that gives you confidence in the changes that you've made over the past year since putting new management in place?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: The biggest confidence I have is Warren Buffett saying it can't be bad forever. I think it's been a very protracted, very difficult period. It was one of our core strengths obviously that's played out to be difficult, particularly in big ticket businesses
componenttext: The biggest confidence I have is Warren Buffett saying it can't be bad forever. I think it's been a very protracted, very difficult period. It was one of our core strengths obviously that's played out to be difficult, particularly in big ticket businesses. Ron comes out of a home background and part of his time at Target. And he is very enthusiastic about the opportunities we see in home. And we have top talent in that area and our merchant team. So I think we feel very strong that we're going to win in this category. It's a slog right now for window covering and furniture, those are the toughest businesses. We're seeing good response in luggage, good response in housewares, in the bath area, great response in the quality of our products. The opportunity to increase the excitement in terms of merchandises there, and I'm going to be a lifelong customer of jcpenney home.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on the SG&A line item. Can you quantify the benefit the credit has given you in the past couple of quarters?
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on the SG&A line item. Can you quantify the benefit the credit has given you in the past couple of quarters?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I can't comment on this. We don't quantify particularly, but it was a significant opportunity for us in the third quarter as our new credit agreement is over a year old now, and it provided for a gain sharing. And obviously a year ago, we issued all new c
componenttext: I can't comment on this. We don't quantify particularly, but it was a significant opportunity for us in the third quarter as our new credit agreement is over a year old now, and it provided for a gain sharing. And obviously a year ago, we issued all new cards. Part of our sales weakness in this last quarter was the fact we launched Liz Claiborne a year ago and didn't have a major fashion launch this year but also, we had a major reissuance of 15 million credit cards last year during the third quarter. While we didn't have another reissuance this year, we did have a good experience with our credit customer who's finding that the rewards program is something they enjoy, and they feel it works for them, so we think that we've been structured in such a way that both of us would share the upside.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, and then can you expect some marketing for the fourth quarter to be up or down versus a year ago?
componenttext: Great, and then can you expect some marketing for the fourth quarter to be up or down versus a year ago?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Marketing support?
componenttext: Marketing support?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Marketing expenses.
componenttext: Marketing expenses.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Expenses. Well, it will be down because we don't have the catalog infrastructure that we were funding a year ago, but we believe that the promotional calendar we have is comparable in terms of its intensity in terms of coming to the store for gifts on Chr
componenttext: Expenses. Well, it will be down because we don't have the catalog infrastructure that we were funding a year ago, but we believe that the promotional calendar we have is comparable in terms of its intensity in terms of coming to the store for gifts on Christmas. We have not changed our promotional cadence in terms of ramping up in terms of the level of promotion or the amount of discounting and so forth. We feel it's a highly promotional environment. It will be unwise to change the calendar demand at this point, but we're satisfied with the plans we have.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Drbul with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Drbul with Barclays Capital.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of quick questions. On the priorities for the cash at this point, is there any insider update you could sort of talk about in terms of how the board is looking at cash balances and the uses currently?
componenttext: I have a couple of quick questions. On the priorities for the cash at this point, is there any insider update you could sort of talk about in terms of how the board is looking at cash balances and the uses currently?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you probably know, Bob, you've covered us for a while, the board at least annually takes a look at all the capital structures. Last year, we authorized a $900-million share repurchase program. We have an aggressive capital expenditure program to
componenttext: Well, as you probably know, Bob, you've covered us for a while, the board at least annually takes a look at all the capital structures. Last year, we authorized a $900-million share repurchase program. We have an aggressive capital expenditure program to fund center core and Sephora and the various things that have been accretive to our performance. I wouldn't comment on a forward-looking basis because frankly that's the prerogative of the board to review dividend, capital expenditure and other investments in which we also invested in Liz Claiborne and Monet brand purchases this last year. So given the fact we are about to launch the next phase of growth, I think, it would be a particularly important discussion this year, and I look forward to it.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. And Mike, did you quantify all the spring costs? Or is there any update in terms of as you look forward on the fall cost side to what you‚Äôre  seeing?
componenttext: Got it. And Mike, did you quantify all the spring costs? Or is there any update in terms of as you look forward on the fall cost side to what you‚Äôre  seeing?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the cost side of goods?
componenttext: In terms of the cost side of goods?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Product cost of goods, yes.
componenttext: Yes. Product cost of goods, yes.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, if you remember last spring, we said our cost on purchases was equal to previous years. So we didn't really have any costing that we're up against this fall. We had a modest improvement or a modest increase in the cost of goods, and that's wha
componenttext: Okay. Well, if you remember last spring, we said our cost on purchases was equal to previous years. So we didn't really have any costing that we're up against this fall. We had a modest improvement or a modest increase in the cost of goods, and that's what we're looking to offset by higher average unit retails. So we're on track as I said earlier. We know that we need to get modest single-digit improvements in AUR in the fourth quarter, and we have every anticipation of getting it. The key will be making sure that our markdown levels are within our markdown expectations, and we don't really have an overhang at this point coming into the quarter. We've had an overhang through the second and third quarter due to the falloff in demand by everybody in the general retail sector. So I'd say we're only 2 weeks into the quarter, so it's a little difficult to declare victory, but we're certainly on the right trendline at this point.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: And my last question is, I think in the guidance, I mean, you talked about the inventory levels the guidance doesn't include financial impact for the fourth quarter as you make the changes in the pricing strategy for next year. Is there any way to sort of
componenttext: And my last question is, I think in the guidance, I mean, you talked about the inventory levels the guidance doesn't include financial impact for the fourth quarter as you make the changes in the pricing strategy for next year. Is there any way to sort of quantify how much of the inventory is at risk around a change in pricing strategy as you look forward?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a way to do, but it's going to be much closer to the time we do it. I mean, obviously, there's still a lot of planning, a lot of work being done on making sure we enter the spring season in the right position. You can count on us for being c
componenttext: Well, there's a way to do, but it's going to be much closer to the time we do it. I mean, obviously, there's still a lot of planning, a lot of work being done on making sure we enter the spring season in the right position. You can count on us for being conservative in terms of the way we look at things to be sure that we've accounted for everything, but it's way too early to anticipate what that will be.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Erika Maschmeyer with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Erika Maschmeyer with Robert W. Baird.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Jacob in for Erica. Can you guys talk about your efforts of reaching out to those past catalog customers? I believe you began using some direct mail in the third quarter to target those customers. Did that go as planned, and could that help costs
componenttext: This is Jacob in for Erica. Can you guys talk about your efforts of reaching out to those past catalog customers? I believe you began using some direct mail in the third quarter to target those customers. Did that go as planned, and could that help costs in the fourth quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: While I will say that wasn't our finest hour in terms of making sure we didn't lose any of those customers in the first half of the year. So you're correct that we expanded the distribution of our print media, which we don't call catalogs. We actually cal
componenttext: While I will say that wasn't our finest hour in terms of making sure we didn't lose any of those customers in the first half of the year. So you're correct that we expanded the distribution of our print media, which we don't call catalogs. We actually call it direct mail. But there were customers that used to shop with us online particularly in home that were not necessarily on the store list of customers that we were sending direct mail to. So we feel that we've rectified that and going forward, we want to talk to those customers. They obviously have an allegiance and an affinity for jcpenney home and other merchandise as well. So we've done a lot of the hard lifting and heavy lifting on dotcom this year, and we were poised for growth in the future much. We're in much and much better shape on apparel online than we have been on home during this transition. But I'm happy to say this is the last quarter of catalog that we're up against.
